												There are very few if any RTS's that stand the test of time like Homeworld does. The work that Gearbox have done to this timeless masterpiece is fantastic the graphics have been updated beautifully, the control system still feels the same 95% of the time there is the odd glitches here and there with certain fleet formations and occasionally having to redo a mission due to an event not triggering. But considering they’ve been working with code that is roughly 15 years old I can forgive all that. The missions are still challenging as ever, which seems to be lacking these days with quite a few AAA titles. Gearbox had a lot to live up to with this and from what I’ve read they’ve done the most intelligent thing any company can do with reviving a franchise they engaged with the community continually and took on board their comments and suggestions and still post release.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												HW vet says something different, still disapointedLong post get readyI played the games when they first came out of course... im 31 and was just a young kid at the time. The game was the greatest of its time as so many have pointed out. The Ui at the time was revolutionary, and so many games have tried to reproduce it but failed.The many great points of this game is what kept many playing and playing again. And for good reason, it has stood the test of time with the greats like the starcraft/warcraft series, age of empire series, and command & conquer seriesFirst some changes that I like...Fuel for fighters (except for the fact that ai fighters never had the fuel restrictions)and thats itThe "Reboot (because it is not a remasted edition in my eyes) Edition" is a complete farce because...--There are no more tactical fleet setups- no need for interceptors now that you can build bombers- no need for assault frigates, you have access to drone frigates- no need for frigates at all cause you can build destroyersThe original game had this, if you had a fleet of assault frigates you were gonna die to a swarm of fighters. why was this changed? It is intuitavly a tactical desicion thats missing--Formations no longer matterAgain so many have said this before but so many new players do not realize why they were so integral to the game. or understand why people complain about them-a wall formation would attempt to hold that formation as they attack while retreating-an x or claw formation would hold that formation while strafing-a sphere formation would attempt to guard the strongest ships at their center while attackingAs it is now every formation devolves into chaos at the first sign of enemy contactAlso The 3d management of the map no longer matters (or exists)As stated in even the first mission of Hw 1 you can do more damage on capital ships from below, above, or behind... Without the cohesive formations we had before this is a non-factor now because once they engage its a free for allCampaign Difficulty ScalingThis was something else way ahead of its time, instead of a difficulty slider the campaign progressed based on how good you were doing... the original did this well by placing a few more corvettes or frigates in at innopportune times.The new version just slams em in there."oh you played smart and made 5 interceptors on mission 1?""im gonna destroy your world and put in 20 light corvettes before the mission starts"or"you had just a mothership? oh you must be a noob, there will be no fighters to defend the carrier on day 2 ever i dont care how many you produce there will never be defenses for me cause you are such a noob"Test this one for yourselfIt is my hope that every new player to the franchise finds this post helpful as to why those veterans of the franchise fine this game so frustrating and disapointing.I know a lot of balance changes were made for the players of hw1 and hw2 multiplayer but that should never have been done, let the players choose which game they want to play multiplayer and balance accordingly dont intermingle that bull.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												'Homeworld Remasted Collection' is a package that includes the remastered version of Homeworld, a game from 1999, as well as the remastered version of Homeworld 2, that was released in 2003. Additionally the package includes the classic version of both games. Although Homeworld and Homeworld 2 are both very similar real-time strategy games, they both play and feel very different. The discovery of an ancient stone plate showing an engraved course through the galaxy, triggers your people on a journey through space to find your original home world. As expected this journey comes with many obstacles and as commander of fleet it is your task to overcome them. In other words, you have to fight. Think of Battlestar Galactica and you get the idea.The concept of the game is really cool and takes you on an intense science fiction journey that feels very unique. Every hyper-jump brings you to a new level in the game. Your remaining fleet arrives centred around your mother-ship. The mother-ship is capable of constructing all kind of different ships. Frigates, cruisers, corvettes, fighters or destroyers, you name it. Additionally you can research new technologies to upgrade your equipment. In order to build new ships you need to collect resources. Resources can be found in asteroid fields and shipwrecks.As for Homeworld 1 most levels are slow paced. Most of the time you are not attacked unless you engage the enemy. This allows you to take your time, which is a wonderful thing. You can drink a cup of tea or relax with a glass of whisky, harvest nearby resources, explore your surroundings and plan your strategy. In this way Homeworld 1 almost feels like a game of chess.Homeworld 2 is the complete opposite. In Homeworld 2 you are constantly put under pressure by never-ending scripting events that force you to permanently fight for survival. Additionally the amount of enemies seems endless at times because the developers implemented a variable AI that automatically adjusts to your fleet size and makes sure it's stronger than yours. The relaxing atmosphere from Homeworld 1 is diminished to a few isolated occasions in Homeworld 2, which makes both games two very different experiences.Both games are generally considered to be hard games. And while I really had to struggle with some levels in Homeworld 1 I was always able to manage them by re-trying one way or the other. This is not necessarily the case for Homeworld 2. The achievement statistic on Steams shop page shows that many players gave up on Homeworld 2. This impression is mirrored in the forums. Homeworld 2 is an extremely difficult game and can be very frustrating at times.Pros: (both games)- beautiful graphics, still not like games from today but considering the age of the games the developers did a great job- tutorials- good keyboard interface- very good music- good voice acting, well designed ship communications- option to manually save at any time, very important!- addictive, after failing to complete a level I went to bed and woke up at three o'clock at night, re-tried and made it :-)- interesting story- very good cutscenes with regard to contentsPros: (Homeworld 1)- relaxing, great atmosphere- difficulty is well balanced, rather easy in the beginning and pretty hard in the end (but still not as hard as every single level in Homeworld 2)- freedom to self-initiate the hyper-jump to the next levelPros: (Homeworld 2)- resource collectors and repair ships are now combined in one unit- more ship upgrade options- Cons: (both games)- games come without manual. Thankfully players provided links to the manuals in the forums that left me with four documents of 173 pages, nice- if you end up finishing a level with a remaining fleet that is unfit to beat the next level you need to replay the last level to make sure your remaining fleet is prepared for the upcoming challenge- one achievement asks you to play the tutorial of the classic game. Unfortunately this is not possible because the classic version keeps crashing. Forums are full of players with this problem. Adding this kind of achievement was a really dumb move from the devs.- Cons: (Homeworld 1)- last level seemed a little to hard- Cons: (Homeworld 2) - stressful most of the time- can be frustrating at times- too difficult- if your last main objective has been completed the game automatically hyper-jumps into the next level. This can be a huge problem if your fleet is diminished after a lengthy fight and you jump right into the next fight. In order to prepare your fleet before jumping you have to wait before completing the final main objective- salvage corvettes make no more sense because they have become far to expensive to justify the risk- maximum number of ships in a group is restricted. In Homeworld 1 you can exceed the maximum number by capturing enemy ships.- stuttering cutscenesAll in all I really enjoyed both games. They offer a very unique atmosphere. I don't know any other game with a similar mood. Homeworld 1 deserves a 100% recommendation while Homeworld 2 deserves a recommendation for the hard core fans but probably not for everybody.

number of helpful: 25 of 37 people (68%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												While it's great to have Homeworld looked at again, especially as games like No One Lives Forever fades into being forgotten as a result of publishers not giving a ****, Homeworld Remastered Collection boasts some impressive visual updates at the cost of some of the gameplay mechanics that made the predecessors what they were.The best part happens to be the visual updates involved with Homeworld 1's remastering. It's absolutely stunning, texture detail beautiful. For Homeworld 1, this comparison is outsdanding, but for Homeworld 2 the improvements aren't as radical due to the game still being in the same engine. That's not to say that both aren't improved, but it's much more significant for the original.Some of the audio has been re-recorded and while it sounds alright there are portions where old (albeit not as compressed) samples are used. This makes it sound jarring since the same settings aren't used between both recording as well as the actor's ages have dramatically changed since the original releases. For Homeworld 1, it's nice to not hear as much compression on things, giving better clarity.The biggest problem with Homeworld 1's remaster is that old tactics aren't working. Formations are fundementally broken, shedding the fact that these fights are in space and momentum is a thing, instead going for a jet-fighter approach. The problem is that makes guard orders useless as you might assign a sphere formation around a target with guard orders, but as soon as enemies get within range, your ships break off and take forever to get shots on target.The good news is that having the Classic version is great, but while the Classic version does run, it does have problems with multi-monitor systems.

number of helpful: 31 of 48 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												FantasticIs it a perfect remake? No. Some of the mechanics in HW1 in particular have been removed, and make certain missions that were monstrously difficult (at least when I was young) rather easy - like Gardens of Kadesh. The removal of strike craft fuel and the change in formation tactics makes it a very different level. There are also some bugs here and there like you'd expect from any new release. None of them I encountered were game-breaking.What surprised me is that nostalgia didn't cloud my recollection of this series. These games are truly incredible, and unlike any other game you'll experience. They require patience and deliberation that many games now have done away with, but it is every bit as rewarding as I recall. A millenia-spanning story, gorgeous visuals done the justice they deserve, and demanding, yet oddly relaxing gameplay married to one of the most unique UI's in all of gaming. Thank you Gearbox. I had considered this series lost in IP limbo until the THQ auction, and now a new generation can appreciate a flawed, astounding masterpiece along with its excellent sequel. TLDR: If you haven't played Homeworld and you like the RTS genre, buy it. You're in for something truly special. These remakes are awesome, and if you don't like the changes made, enjoy the originals in all their glory.

Sure the graphics are better, and there are some UI improvements, but oveall the gameplay is not improved. If you care about graphics then upgrade, if not then stick with originals.Thirdly: Why should I get it when i can get the originals for a few bucks?Becasue by buying it you prove that such an awesome game deserves developers to be rewarded. Homeworld remains one of the most unique and awesome strategy games. Show how much you love it by buying it.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Disclaimer: I'm assuming a long-standing familiarity with the Homeworld series here, for anyone who reads this.I'm very torn on this game. On one hand, I am a long-time fan of the Homeworld series of games. From the moment I'd played the original HW demo prior to the game's release, I was in love with the game. So much that over the years I've wound up with several copies of it so I could play with friends who didn't have their own at the time.Fast forward past Homeworld: Cataclysm (since it's not in this collection), to Homeworld 2. I was still quite happy with the game, although I was not so impressed with the new game engine. Also, I was quite confused with some of the continuity errors introduced into the units. Why were capital ships no longer capable of jumping themselves, with the exception of ships that could build the hyperspace module? In HW 1, all frigates and up were jump-capable without support. Why were formations and tactics effectively non-existant? They played such a huge role in carrying out a successful combat action in the original. The list goes on.So, here we are today, with the Homeworld Remastered Collection. As a lover of the series, I'm thrilled with its existence. From a collector's standpoint, this is a wonderful addition to the Homeworld Universe. It preserves the story and music from the original versions, and does indeed do a very nice job of updating the appearance of the setting.Now, the gripes...First off, they made subtle modifications to the classic version of Homeworld included in the collection. There is a queue-limit, restricting how many active build queues per mothership and carrier. Want to queue a whole mixed corvette wing at once? Nope, you can only build 2 types at once, regardless of how many of each. This continues on through to capitals ships. Also, they removed all capablity for multiplayer. There isn't even a LAN option. If LAN was still an option, through some network trickery people could still play multiplayer, even if there was no ability to just find and hop into a game like before the multiplayer lobby finally was shut down.Regarding the multiplayer side of things in general, I've only tried one game over the beta system (well, beta as of this writing, anyway), and I was unimpressed. About 15 minutes in, just as my teammate and I finished fending off an initial assault from the other players (6 went in via lobby, 4 of us wound up in game), the game just up&closes on me. No error, no crash message, nothing. Just back to my desktop.Now, onto my gripes with the "Remastered" version of Homeworld 1. In short, it's just a mod for the original Homeworld 2 engine (as "improved" for the remastered version of HW2). Unit caps, insanely-decreased hangar capacity on the mothership, a queue that can only build 2 or 3 different things at a time per production ship, RUs required for research (and no parallel researching anymore, just one tech at a time no matter how many sections you build for the research ship), and otherwise the same failings of the Homeworld 2 engine that the original HW2 suffered from. Namely the joke they called tactics and formations. And the same, clunky&screen cluttering interface (I loved the simplicity of the original HW's interface, it let me spend more time dealing with events in the gameplay, rather than trying to wrestle with which panel or convoluted "shortcut" I needed).As it stands now (and any patches/updates aside, will ultimately probably remain so), I really can't recommend the game collection. I really only bought it for the inclusion of "Homeworld Classic," and while mostly happy with that part of the collection, I still have some complaints about the changes made to the game.Only get this if you have a similar love of the franchise as I do, otherwise you should save your money and look for something else to scratch your space RTS itch.

number of helpful: 23 of 34 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												It's almost as if they said to themselves, "Let's make homeworld look twice as good, but play half as well".I can't say much about homeworld 2: remastered since I haven't played the original too many times  but homeworld 1: remastered is a tragic disappointment when compared to the original. I wish I'd read the reviews before buying. It's baffling that they haven't ironed out such major bugs in such a long time.Bottom Line: I can't recommend this game to new comers with all of the broken elements that made the original so good. You will be left wondering what all the fuss is about with such a mediocre game.I definitely can't recommend this game to veterans who've already tasted the goodness of the original. You will go 'Wow' when you see the graphics on level 1, and then you'll be mounting frustration as you discover one broken feature after the other.Details:- Formations: Don't work. Ships break formation as soon as they engage enemies which defeats the purpose entirely. Battles are basically a free for all. This occurs in hw2 as well.- Tactics: Don't work. There is no discernible difference between the 3 tactics. The buttons are just eye/ear candy.- Tactical map: Homeworld 1 allowed you to specify a 'move to' point, then hold the shift key to lock that point while panning with rmb to adjust elevation. This is no longer possible, and you have to specify both the 'move to' location and the elevation from a single angle. Not possible, not impressed. Also applies to hw2.- Salvaging: It's nice that they've made it possible to salvage those standard and missle corvettes in the early missions (without painful scuttle tactics).  It's NOT nice that the 6 assault frigates from mission 3 simply disappear when captured (and are down to 4 for some reason).- Resourcing: Nerfed to 500 RU's per load (down from 600) for no apparent reason. Takes an eternity to collect resources. Also there's a whole lot more resources available in each level, severely hurting the fine tuned balance of the original game. But I guess that was an easier fix than trying to fix the balance.- Balance: Downright terrible. Battles that should be over in a flash take forever and with unacceptible losses. An army of 21 interceptors, 7 heavy corvettes and 4 assault frigates should suffer no losses when facing 5 interceptors + 2 corvettes. Neither should they take more than 5 minutes. But that's not homeworld "remastered".- Interface: I, for one, preferred the original build manager to the homeworld 2 multi page build manager since it's easier building everything from a single page.If it ain't broke, don't make a half-a!$@d attempt at 'remastering' the game.

												Nostalgia aside, this is one hell of a grand remake.Better Graphics, Better Gameplay, Better UI, and Better AI.The Multiplayer and Skirmishes have been redone and improved.Homeworld has an excellent and deep dark story that is gritty and tribal.The Music is great and very atmospheric, dark and epic.This remastered edition is one to pick up for those new and old to the series. 												Simply put, a game everyone needs to see. If you love RTS and atmospheric stories then dont pass this up. I wont try to ice it over, this game has some aggrivating bugs at times, and I wouldnt recommend trying the multiplayer yet (or if you do prepare for some... "fun"). I wish they left the first games mechanics how they were and not to implement the seconds into it. That way it would have kept its original feel. Recommend this game? Of course! Hopefully they fix the problems and support this game like it should. Those complaing have good reason to do so, however there are a few faults in their accusations:1: These games are from a different era where you had to really think and plan ahead, most may find the game a bit hard and frusterating as each mission always throws loops at you so in a sense you had to keep in mind what you brought to the table each time you finish a mission and start a new one.2: They CLEARLY SAID that they were integrating HW2 mechanics into HW1, sad but they emphisized this multiple times3: Many memebers of the Original Team were involved in this...dont go blaming Gearbox. Games must evolve, and adapt to changes in the industry. I also dont agree with everything but you have to ask yourself the basic question "Is it fun?"As someone whos played this game since its first release and still have the original disks, I bought this for 2 reasons. First being Steams support (Which could add a much bigger fanbase, and easier way to setup mods) and that I simply felt the need to assist this series by buying it. They were never perfect but they were inspiring in their time... Just like now, its not perfect but why get so upset? Especially when they INCLUDED THE ORIGINALS!

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												TL/DR: Game breaking bugs.  Wait for bug fixes and the next steam sale to get this one.I have fond memories of the original Homeworld, so I decided to pay full price to reward Gearbox for refreshing a classic franchise.  With all the good reviews from critics and some of the original Homeworld devs working on the project I was confident it would be a solid experience.  Gearbox you burned me on this one.  I didn’t pay full price to beta test your code!  Frequent crashes.  Also game breaking bugs.  For example, if you have to reload a mission from an auto save, mission events will fail to trigger, preventing you from completing it.  Serious bugs in the AI behavior too.  Critical to success in Homeworld is capturing enemy ships.   Imagine my frustration when my own ships continue to shoot enemy vessels after I’ve captured them, often destroying both the captured ship and my own salvage corvettes in the process.  I almost threw a monitor.  Don’t reward Gearbox for rushing this out the door and expecting us to Q&A it for them.  Refuse to buy it until they’ve resolved the issues and it goes on a big sale.  If you’d like to know what kind of a hot mess you’re in for, start here: http://forums.gearboxsoftware.com/t/gameplay-bugs-feedback-megathread/95069

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												If you are planning to buy this because you were a big fan of HW1, don't. Much of what you'll remember of HW1 was lost when it was brought over to the HW2 engine. A few changes to HW1 (Most not for the better)-Fighter/Corvettes no longer require fuel-Formations don't hold in battle (all) and often do not work outside of it (sphere, parade)-Minefields require constant maintenance-Ship evasion is severely diminished-Research costs RUs and Research ships can no longer research independently-Balance of many missions has been changed, often for the worse (looking at you Sea of Lost Souls)Despite being very pretty, this game feels rushed. As a community, Homeworld fans were kept in the dark regarding what the remastering was going to bring to the table. Updates were non-existant and the only newsletter I got after signing up when it was initially offered was the release date email a year later. I imagine mounting negative feedback on this got Gearbox to kick it out the door before it was done =/Gearbox did not do right by fans of the original title.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Homeworld Remastered is a remake of two classic and very popular games, Homeworld 1 and 2. It's a real-time strategy space game that is basically the best one to this date with no game to overcome it, in most peoples eyes.This is going to be a thoughts on the game, my thoughts, as a person who never played the originals, and a friend who did play them and now playing the remake. Also, neither that friend or I have finished the game, just to note.Both of us thought that the graphics are, for how old this game is, compared to the classics, it's beautifully remade.The ship models are a lot more pleasing and awesome, same with the background (space), and the UI is adjustable which is neat, but for me that UI could have been better.The story, for my friend has always been great, and to me it is just great. The presentation is fantastic, which include the story, the cut scenes, and the battles, all of which are awesome and emphasizes that space is scary and there's a lot of powerful forces out there, showing that to you directly opposing your power.The only complaint so far for the game is that me and my friend thought that moving the camera around can be a pain, not hard, just annoying, and most of the other issues for the game are coming from the fact this is a remastered game, of an old game, that didn't get a makeup of modern technicalities and controls that we get in most new games nowadays, which isn't necessarily a negative thing, but it would have been great if it were tweaked to have them.So overall the game is great, for new players and for the fans, and for the price it has, for two remade games in one, with the mixed multiplayer, it's a great purchase, and a cleaned up superb old/new game/s.Shameless link[ksalue.com]

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Definitely a good game, quite pleased with the graphical update, audio update, and also the UI update. It plays very smoothly and I am having loads of fun in both the campaign and multiplayer. Definitely recommend anyone to give this game a go, especially if you like space opera and a strong story coupled with good RTS gameplay.However, it does have some bugs. For example, the speech audio sometimes randomly mutes itself during the campaign, which results in me needing to save and reload the game to get the speech audio back on. Another bug both me and a friend encountered was with the garden of Kadesh mission: When you attempt to enter hyperspace and fail and you have your units docked, it will force them to launch  and you cannot dock them again. The swarmers then wreck my salvage corvetts.Also, it would be nice if the game were more 'unified'. In other words, I want to be able to access HW1 campaign, HW2 campaign, and the multiplayer without needing to close the game and open the launcher again. Those should all be options in the menu, not separate 'games' you need to launch.Despite that, I tend to overlook bugs and UX issues on the first day, as long as developers get them fixed in good time. So for now, I shall keep my review as overall positive. Definitely looking forward to the many more hours of fun completing these campaigns again!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Everything I remembered it to be and more.  I remembered the tight controls and surprisingly simple style for tactics (BTW definitely play the tutorial).  I remembered how cool it looked to send squadrons of ships in claw formations against enemy carriers (which looks amazing now compared to then).  And I remembered how the game gives you simple missions at first to ease you into the action.  But I forgot (I'm not sure how) the gripping narratives of the two games.  I was immediately sucked back into the journey across the galaxy and the aggressive response to enemy threats.Now I've barely touched the remastered game thus far: hardly restarted the story as of writing this.  It may be early for a review.  They could have bugs further on that I don't know about yet.  So far it's played smooth and error free (despite turning my gaming laptop into a blast furnace).  But I've played through the old versions before and this stands up to and exceeds my expectations for a modernization.Pros:                   .Gripping story       .tight controls               .great visuals.gentle learning curve (simple missions at first familiarizing you with the game).Bug free and plays smooth..Two games plus expansions in one!Cons:.You better play the tutorial or that gentle learning curve is going to be much steeper..new visuals (outside of the new lighting and weapon effects) are simply hi-res textures pasted onto relatively simple ship models from the original game so don't expect elite dangerous graphics..You don't own it yet.

number of helpful: 20 of 30 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I'm writing this review mere minutes after beating the remastered Homeworld campaigns. Bear in mind that this review talks about the remastered games ONLY.I cannot overstate how much I looked forward to something like this, since Homeworld never had a digital release (good luck getting those old CDs to run).The remaster is done well, but not perfectly. My biggest gripe being ship squads. In multiplayer, the Homeworld 1 races simply don't stand a chance in the fighter/corvetter categories. Of course that could change with future patches (as I'm sure it will).Campaign wise, the Homeworld 2 campaign feels nigh-on identical to how it was before. The Homeworld 1 campaign though definitely felt different. It seemed a bit easier, maybe because of the rock-paper-scissors combat system associated with the Homeworld 2 engine. Either way, it was fun and a great trip down memory lane... except it looked a hellova lot better!But there are some issues, almost all being Homeworld 1 related. Formations need work, simple as that. If I put my ships into a sphere I expect them to hug around a guarded ship, not sit next to it in a ball. Fuel is gone, but TBH, to me (!) that was a positive change overall. The UI is neat and better to me than the old one. This one (like Homeworld 2's original UI) allows you to monitor the action while issueing build and research orders.Most of the other changes are minor, such as Kadeshi Multibeam frigates not doing a barrel roll when firing or research ships not spinning anymore. All of that could be patched in later though, or modded.If you can live with the above differences and consider the amazing visual upgrade, then this is absolutely a good buy!Homeworld is an RTS franchise you OWE yourself to at least try.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
Homeworld is unlike anything that's out there, it's a game who defined the space strategy genre as we know it, becoming a high standard. I remember myself playing with friends when Homeworld2 came out, the amount of incredible games we had, and still have. That was the best experience I had in strategy video games thus far.As much as I love strategy games, I fell in love for this title the first time I played it. I will probably always consider it as my favourite one, and that's probably the most valuable reason I started developing mods on it, not just because I wanted to create something related to my favourite science fiction universes, but because this game brought us so many possibilities that I had to do it.I seriously believe Gearbox gave Homeworld the respect it deserves, like other people think. This Remastered version is definitely what we can consider as "Remastered"... in opposition to other studios who tend to promote remastered games just because they changed the textures or the screen resolution. It's not a Remastered version, it's.. a Renovation. Now highlighting high definition score, great voices, Full-HD animated cutscenes and one of the latest version of OpenGL, Homeworld Remastered makes the whole game really epic, with a well-told story.My unique complain is that they decided to remove audios from other languages (such as French, Spanish, Italian...) while they still have them and that the original records are already in HD. They said that "they don't have them anymore", so they would have needed to remake all of them with foreign recording studios, and I don't believe Gearbox wanted to spend money on this, as they're not a publisher, and don't have the same amount of ressources.Pros of this Remastered Version:✓ Brillant and stunning visuals.✓ A better campaign (improved cutscenes).✓ A great multiplayer mode.✓ Far better Interface, and god we needed it.✓ A great User Interface, which proves Homeworld rhymes with Modernity.✓ Awesome multiplayer games in perspective.✓ New tracks and remastered awe-inspiring score.✓ Better movements and improved AI.✓ Steam multiplayer platform, a good point to play with your friends.✓ Mod tools, although not finished.Cons of this Remastered Version:✖ Audio strictly limited to English. A shame because foreign languages had really great voice overs.✖ Some missions could have been improved (strange movements).✖ Formations and BC should be improved as well.✖ Steam exclusive. Even the CD version requires Steam, which is something I consider as "bull****".There are cons, of course, but let us all remember than this Remastered version is a way for Homeworld fans to support the future of the franchise. Thank you Gearbox, command line green. Homeworld Forever!VERDICT: IT'S A MASTERPIECE!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												The best stab at a truly 3D RTS the gaming industry has ever taken. The easy and intuitive interface, and the three dimensional weak spots on assorted craft makes your movement on the field of battle meaningful. The story, artwork, and voice acting bring the struggle of the inheritants of the former Kushan empire to life in this unparalleled masterpiece.After languishing over a decade in relative obscurity, Gearbox has brought the universe of Homeworld back to the forefronts of our imagination in a master stroke born of proper reverence for the titles. The Remastered Collection breathes new life into the game's backdrop in a way that does it more justice than our own imaginations could during the game's initial release. The magnitude and quality of the effort—and the joy it brings to my sense of nostalgia—cannot be understated.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												A truly unique RTS (and the only one I know of that truly has 3d maps), HWR gives you the ability to move craft in literally any direction.  Don't know if the videos shown display this ability or not, I do apologise.  The remastered version is about as close to the original than any other game I have ever played that has been remastered to such an extent except for the 1st halo maybe. I have not played it, I will not buy a console for only 1 game (**** you square enix, for making FF15 exclusive to PS4).  All craft are very unique, in what craft they are intended to combat.  The story is very rich for what you can expect, ships communicating to each other with icon thumbnails that are usually not an actual face (outside of some cinematics between missions).  There are 4 different playable factions, each with their own unique strategies for multiplayer and skirmish mode.  Only 1 race is playable in both games during storymode.  There is only 1 type of currency for both games, mined from asteroids (or dust clouds as well in HW1).  Most missions require careful tactics, lest your currency dries up before the next mission (still possible with just resources that are in each map - but not likely.The only critisism I have seen from the community, in the remastered versions, is that weapon projectiles function differently from HW1 classics.'  I personally didn't really care enough to get upset by it, I was just happy enough for the remastered versions to be as good as they are, but there are some players who are not too happy about that.Be aware, however, most missions can take a substantial of time to complete.  Although, there are setable parameters to make multiplayer games go faster and during anytime you can save on singleplayer.P.S.:  there is a third homeworld game that occurred between HM1 and HM2 named HW:Cataclysm.  I do not know why it wasn't remastered but the story of it not essential to the plot of HW2 (outside a near extinction event of a non-playable species).

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Fun, old sci-fi strategy games in space that got a pretty good "facelift". Includes Homeworld and Homeworld 2, both in classic and remastered versions, that work on modern systems.It's not easy game at first and it will take you some trial and error to complete the campaign. All ships have their strengths and weaknesses, some are better at dealing damage yet can't take much damage themselves, others are faster and more agile so they can overwhelm the larger ships if they have the numbers. Ships have either a projectile attack, missiles or energy weapon attacks. Some may have combination of all three like few of the larger capital ships.There are many different starships in game that are divided into fighters, corvettes, frigates and capital ships. Some ships you will use for specific tasks, not just attacking but repairing, gather resources, cloaking allies, capturing enemy ships, disabling them, shielding allies from damage and much more.In battle, ships can miss their shots, so 10 on 10 fighter battle can have different outcome depending on how lucky your shots are. And in large battles it's all about tactics and knowing your enemy weaknesses. Apart from solo campaign there's skirmish and multiplayer for some custom matches with friends.Homeworld 2 bring all that was great in Homeworld and adds more enemies, ships, modification modules, new research options for ships as well as new campaign. It's hard to review a "bundle" of sorts, because it's 4 games in one package, even though they are similar, the remastered versions have a lot of new features as well as improved visuals and game user interface.[Tutorial lady]: If you liked this review, click OK to continue.[ OK ];8)

number of helpful: 25 of 40 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I usually do a bit more research before I make a Steam purchase, as a result most of the games I own were either given to me or I bought because I knew I would love them.I was a little wary of paying $35 dollars for a 15 year old game no matter how "remastered" it sounded, but I genuinely lovd the original Homeworld so much I decided to go ahead (I thought it would be great to be able to play online against friends for the first time in ages, as well!) I was worried about that when I was still using the traditional definition of Remastered and not, "turned into complete trash." Between the bugs and the changes the game flounders near the area of unplayable. For examples of changes, fundamental tactical abilities like telling your fighters to be "evasive" has simply been ripped out of the game. Whether or not this was to foment HWI vs HWII multiplayer is as irrelevant as it is uncertain, it renders figher groups so much less meaningful or useful. Fighters instead seem to behave in a sort of constant half aassed evasive which means that their aggressive behavior has also been scuttled. For examples of bugs, from mission to mission my groups would fail to properly select. If I hightlighted, say, all the ships in group one then they might all show they were in group one, but if I actually hit one, only a few respond to the hail. I have to reselect and reassaign them all to "rebuilld" between missions. But this is nothing compared to ships simply REFUSING TO OBEY ORDERS. I have tried playing The Wastelands three times now and in each instance a point was reached where some group of ships simply refused to move or engage no matter what they were instructed. I was especially impressed by my salvage frigates staring dumbly at me as I repeatedly tried to get them to capture a destroyer or, indeed, any ship as they slowly got picked off one by one. I have never before felt compelled to write a negative review for Steam. It's one thing to simply make a bad game, that happens all the time. But this is a case of taking a masterpiece and destroying it. And I've been offered the chance to waste $35 dollars for the priviledge of watching one of my favorite games of old trashed in this manner. Simply releasing the games for $5 apiece and rebuilding the multiplayer environment would have been the right move. As it stands, I regret this purchase without reservation and cannot recommend it, at least not until the myriad gameplay issues have been resolved. Even then, the graphis upgrades hardly justify $35. In my opinion, if you make this purcahse you are probably getting ripped off.

												Homeworld remastered is a broken and disapointing PORT of the  origonal Homeworld into the Homeworld 2 engine.Due to being a port into a different engine, alot of the base mechanics just dont work anymore, major changes have been made to ships health, cost, unit caps, and damage to try and balance Homeworld 1 in the Homeworld 2 Engine. there are still many features that still just dont work, formations,  the cease fire command, captured carriers cannot build and contain enemy fighters after capture (fun!).if your looking to play a graphically updated Homeworld 1, this is not the game for you.if you have never played Homeworld, you will probably have fun, as you wont notice the changes.But as someone who absolutly loved the origonal to bits, it hurts to play the remaster, seeing the shortcomings in every facit of the game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												The short of it: grognard vote of approval.The long of it: Homeworld (its demo, in fact) was the first game I installed on my first computer. I've kept at it constantly through the years. The Remastered edition does contain Homeworld and Homeworld 2, they are as good as ever, and this is reason enough for a thumbs up.The Remastered edition adds a lot of visual improvements, and some gameplay modifications as well. The awesome Homeworld story is brought into the Homeworld 2 engine - some players might choose this opportunity to experience it, since you can now issue orders while the game is paused, and thus deal with the more hectic moments of space combat.Apart from more detailed textures, 3D models, lightning system, here are some pros and cons at a glance:PROS:- the gameplay tried to remain faithful to the original- game runs well- good sound quality- everything said in cinematics has a subtitle, including the launch game-engine cinematic- good first day support (got a game update immediately after my first crashed, which got fixed)- you can pit Kushan against Hiigaran, or any of the 4 factions of the two games in skirmish- it is funCONS:- though technically impressive, the visual aspect of the game needs some more polishing and fitting together- some HW1 ships don't work well yet, like Hive Frigates- HW1 Salvage Corvette numbers are now drastically limited; doing the campaign junkyard style seems doubtfulNitpicking:- The starting cinematic ends with the view centered on the Resource Collector; however, due to the orientation of the camera, the backdrop is outer space, rather than Kharak, as was in the original game. I feel this disrupts the narratively important visual repetition of Kharak (multiple times in the starting cinematic, then contrasted in mission 3), and I would like the developer to 'fix' the narrative element back.Bottom line: good, fun games, done in the spirit of the old and improved upon. Still need a few patches.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I bought this on sale expecting to play HW1 with better graphics and to have a copy of this game forever preserved on the cloud somewhere, even though I have the original CD. So far, things have been a huge disappointment. The following only applies to HW1 as I have not attempted to play HW2:+ The graphics have indeed been modernized and fleet combat is spectacular to watch- Every single ship has had their resource cost and battle prowess completely changed- The AI of strike craft has been completely changed,  making fighters nearly useless in every type of battle- Damage dealt by larger craft has been greatly increased, shortening combat and making tactical movement orders unnecessary- Enemy fleet scaling has been completely changed, causing some missions to be stacked ludicrously against you and punishing you for playing wellThe net result is that battles play out completely different. In HW1 Classic you had a framework for what to expect in combat: fighters would beat capital ships, capital ships would beat corvettes, and corvettes would beat fighters. Several craft would break these rules, but you always had the option through smart gameplay to even the odds - formations, tactics, and tactical movement could swing unfavorable fights in your favor. Now, in the Remastered version, all of that is pointless. Spend all your resources building as many of the biggest ships you can, and just drag a box around the enemy fleet to issue an attack order. Whichever side has the biggest fleet wins in a matter of seconds.No thanks.+ The classic HW1 game is included if you don't want to deal with any of this nonsense. Unfortunately, my experience with HW1 classic has been filled with bugs and crashes, something I do not experience when I install from the original CD

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Why, Gearbox?  Why couldn't you have either just cleaned it up, or given it the love it needed?  This frankenstein's monster of a game is offensively disrespectful to your history and your legends.The upgraded graphics break the game - many people report a 'general failure' any time they try to load, and disabling many graphical features seems to be the only (unreliable) fix.  Formations and simulated projectile bullets are gone, both foundational mechanics.Whereas HW1 achieved it's balance by making ships and weapons actually function according to their role, HWC:RM achieves its balance via HW2's rock/paper/scissors balance, by arbitrarily weighting certain ships to function less effectively against ships they aren't meant to be useful against. Actual simulated projectiles and formations were never made to function in HWC:RM.If they had just upgraded textures and models and called it a day, they would have shown this game more respect.  Instead, they crammed it into an engine it wasn't meant for, ignored everything that became broken because that new engine doesn't support foundational game mechanics, and released it with numerous game-breaking bugs that after almost two years they never bothered to patch, despite a number of balance patches.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												I'm not entirely sure what they were thinking with Homeworld 1 remastered, especially putting the original in there beside it. Strikecraft, tactics and formations feel incredibly neutered and pointless in the remastered game. All it does is just confuse a fight more times than it helps, unlike the original where it was an important part of small unit tactics. Still, the story and pacing are mostly the same and it feels right.Homeworld 2 remastered... Where do I start? The story they give you is strange and vaguely nonsensical that wrecks some of the plot points from the first one for absolutely no reason that is apparent to me. It lacks the relaxed pace of the first game with crisis' piling up in your lap before you have a chance to deal with previous ones. Your opponents, the Vaygr, not only vastly outnumber you in each mission, but you quickly notice the quality of their craft also outstrip your own in most instances, this leaves every single engagement an attempt to overwhelm them and the fact that the mission automatically ends (also unlike the first one) means you have no chance to rebuild or reinforce your fleet before heading to the next mission.The game looks pretty, but I feel that was Gearboxes ONLY concern when they remastered this game.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Homeworld Remastered - One of the Best Remakes Ever! 

			Views: 406		

			Homeworld is one of the most unique RTS's ever made! There is still no other game (that I know of, anyway) that's anything like it.		

Homeworld is one of the most unique RTS's ever made! There is still no other game (that I know of, anyway) that's anything like it. Not only was the fully 3D environment groundbreaking, the graphics had a beauty unlike anything ever seen before. This is how space games were meant to look!The remastered version is everything that the original was, and so much more. This isn't just an update to make the game compatible with modern machines, this is an honest, thorough HD remake of the game. The game looks fantastic, even by today's graphical standards. The gameplay still feels fresh and unique. I've played this game 15 hours since it was released, and not ready to quit anytime soon! In all those 15 hours, I have not run into any bugs or game breakers. The game has been smooth the whole way through,. I haven't tried multiplayer yet, as I want to finish the campaigns first, so maybe there are some bugs there (it is still in beta, after all) but the single player experience is flawless.If you were a fan of the original Homeworlds, this is a must have for you! If you have never played the originals, then now is definitely the time to experience this gem of a game!

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												I played Homeworld 1 not long after it first came out, some 14-15 years ago. I got stuck early on as it was too hard for me, but I still remember it well. I was pleased seeing this come to me from Humble Monthly, as I kept hearing how good the originals were. Maybe the remaster is just as good?I suppose most people don't expect an amazing story when they go to play an RTS. And this is how Homeworld stands out in my eyes. Sure, some strategies had really cool campaigns (ex. Red Alert, Starcraft...) but Homeworld is like a class of its own. In terms of lasting, emotional impact it is perhaps unrivaled in its genre (although still not a tearjerker proper since it's still a strategy). The "we are away" moment at the beginning of the first campaign is - for me - one of the most memorable moments in all of gaming and how they redid it at the beginning of the second? Excellent. The whole game just feels surprisingly artsy a lot of time. Maybe it's the semi-choral pieces. Maybe the ambient, dead-silent camera pans at the height of drama during cutscenes. Maybe the gorgeous backgrounds that fail to convey the size and scope of the universe but do their best trying. Maybe the attention to detail in the writing and establishing a vast world.Before you run off to get it, let me warn you. This is not an effortless feels dispenser. This is still a remaster of a game designed and made in the 20th century. Back then they made games hard. I mean hard. Homeworld got a graphical facelift but it's still as difficult for me as it was 15 years ago. Giving move and attack orders in 3D in the middle of battle without pausing, when all the forces intertwine is a right cluster*uck. You can actually pause and give orders but the tutorial didn't say so and thus I had to complete the whole game without it. But the absolutely worst thing is a system that scales up the amount of enemies spawned against you based on your resources. That means not only the ships you have on the field but also the amount of resources (money) you have in the bank. If that sounds as abhorrent to you as it does to me, then you probably've guessed that this game had a close shave with the thumbs down button. Luckily, there is a brilliant mod here, which allows to adjust that mechanic (or turn it off altogether). With this, the game is actually manageable.I had fairly high expectations for this game and it lived up to them. Both in the quality of the source material (which was unknown to me up to this point) and its remastering into a modern product. If you'll hear people say Homeworld was a milestone for gaming they generally are not lying, although it was a bit niche due to its uncompromising difficulty and thus this milestone was quickly left behind.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												I cannot tell you the countless hours I've put into the original homeworld series. I was a super huge fan of the entire thing, even the never mentioned cataclysm. To say I was excited to see this game remastered was an understatement.For those that are not familiar with homeworld: It's a fantastic space strategy simulation game. You use your massive motherships as space factories and face off against other ships/factions. The scale of combat expands quickly from smaller fightercraft all the way up to massive capital ship battles. It features a harvesting economy, salvage, ship theft & invasion, and a lot of research and development to keep your fleet operating and developing in a fashion of gameplay that you enjoy. The HIGHLIGHT of this game is that it's fully 3D. You can make attacks and travel along the Z axis freely.As a returning player, the remastered game has exceeded all my expectations.1) The new graphics engine upgrades are gorgeous, giving you a much more believable/enjoyable visual experience.2) Multiplayer: Has been masterfully reworked so that the kushan, higaaran, taidan & vagyr all fight in the same maps. Each one has it's own distinct (yet familiar) style of gameplay, and benefits.3) With Steam support, the mod packs of this game are exceptionally easy to use! You can quickly "subscribe" to mods, and flick them on & off at a whim!I HIGHLY suggest this to anyone who is either a returning player wishing to re-kindle some nostalgea, or to new players who wish to experience one of the best space tactical games out there to-date.P.S. For those who throught homeworld was great buy easy, try the complex 9.1 mod! It upgrades the game in almost every way!

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												This was one of the very first space RTS games I have ever played back in my early teens. With the remastered edition, graphics are slightly updated and everything (especially UI) is given a better polish. For it's age (and update), it can still hold value for space fans.I haven't completed the first Homeworld but have the second (and am still sort of unfamiliar with the story). Basically, you play as this race called the Hiigarans. The game starts with the Hiigarans attempting to finish constructing their mothership but are quickly interrupted by attacking Vaygr enemies. From what I understood from the first game, there are 3 ancient power cores in the universe that if all three are collected by the wrong people, "end times" can ensue.The gameplay follows a somewhat unique sequence. There is no base to build. There are no supply depots. There are no factories. There is only the mothership! The mothership is capable of building resource collectors, battle units from interceptor to capitol ship size and mobile resource centers. It is the headquarters that will provide everything necessary and will take your leftover units to the next level. Capitol ships and space stations are also units that can create more units. The issue here is that certain units require certain modules to build. A capitol ship cannot build frigates unless a frigate module has been built. Same concept applies with the space station. The challenge here is trying to balance out the fleet while being conservative with resources. The RTS factor to the game is unique in the sense that most of the crafts you build come in squadrons (except for the larger units like frigates). The space in which you can tell the units to move is on a 3D plane (the Z axis positioning can be modified by holding shift and the right mouse button). This adds some substance to the game as you can ambush your opponent in 3D! Having the right setup and formation can really bolster defense. Choosing units isn't too much of a hassle. If you find that your selecting repair units as well as military units, there is a special setting within the options to prioritize selection of military units. This is a good way to keep your peon units out of fights. There can be a lot going on at times and it can be hard to keep track of units. Pressing space will allow the player to zoom out and see the ENTIRE battlefield. This is a good way to manage your units. To make the camera go up and down for a better view, simply press insert or delete.There are a few categories of units : strike craft, utility class, capital and frigate. Strike crafts usually come in groups (of 3 to 5) and consist of interceptors, bombers and corvettes. Bombers are more or less meant to strike larger ships and structures. Corvettes are quite slower than interceptors but pack more of a punch in their armor and weapons. Frigate classes have the ability to heal themselves but quite slowly. There are two types of frigates, marine and flak. Flak is meant to deal some heavy damage to structures and larger ships while marine frigates are meant to invade and seize control of structures or even opposing ships. Capital ships consists of carriers (which can build ships) and two battle focused units : destroyers and battle-cruisers. The mothership is the only ship capable of creating such behemoths. Destroyers are quite obvious and are meant to be like boulders rolling from afar but battle-cruisers are definitely devastators. They are able to have 5 strike crafts docked with them and give an additional 2 module slots. These guys are definitely the bad boys of the game. Resources are harvested by specialty units called resource collectors. Resource collectors need to be told where to go in order to start their operation. They may stop in their tracks when there are no more resources left in an area and will most likely have to be told to move on to somewhere else. A mobile resource center can be created to cover more area and allow your resource collectors to submit their resources there instead of going all the way back to the mothership. Resource collectors are also able to repair units and structures but require additional research to unlock this ability. Research upgrades are available for a lot of units to improve their defense, mobility or offense. New unit types also have to be unlocked through research. Additionally, a few units will have special abilities available to unlock (such as corvettes laying out mines).The visuals are pretty good. Definitely an upgrade from the original. The sounds are good and provide a decent atmosphere. The explosions sound varied as well as the weapons. The dialogue is as intriguing as the story line. Honestly, going from the old graphics to this is really enjoyable. I feel though you could have done just a bit more to make it that much more appealing to the eyes.Overall, a good game. The ability to fight in three dimensions coupled with it's unique approach to creating units makes the game poke it's head from the crowd. I found the price to be a bit steep and bought this game off a humble bundle. I think if it's for sale under $15 and you're a real space fan, you'll like it. If you're looking for ground breaking space RTS/battle simulator, this isn't it.RATING : 7.35/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B- Replay-ability B- Overall  B-ScreenShots :  Ship size varies greatly in this game You can target sub-systems What the view looks like after pressing space Even though I'm a little overzealous in saying that the graphics could have been better, it's still pretty good Welcoming a destroyer to this world The camera is quite flexible

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I played this game back in 2000, and it consumed a good part of my freshman year of high school. It's a perfect storm of perfection - perfect music, perfect crackling, crisp audio comm from your pilots, perfect sound effects.The graphics in this remake are stunning, just as the original game was stunning back in 1999. Seeing the re-meshed, re-textured ships for the first time again as they fly out of the Mothership's bays is like greeting old friends after years away. I may have actually shed a tear of delight when I saw the good ol' bug-shaped Salvage Corvette, ready to steal slow moving Ion Cannon Frigates at my command.If you like RTS games, there is no question that you should get this game. If you've never played Homeworld, you're in for a treat.(my only downside is that Gearbox seems to have been a bit overzealous in bringing Homeworld2 engine-based strategy into Homeworld. There are plenty of threads about this elsewhere. I'd prefer if they patch the game to make the original game remaster as close to, well, the original game, as possible).

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Well, 15yrs later I returnSadly, I think its a game that was probably better in the past, due to its ground breaking nature. Its lost none of the appeal however, but kept the bugs you had long forgotten!Returns are the bad formations, when your forces are slow to move and allocate firepower, that allow the AI's smaller forces deal more damage to you. Firing at salvaged ships. Building fighters that do nothing. However, you get to relive the story mode, which gives you love for the faceless race you represent. You travel the known galaxy in your attempt to see your old Homeworld. You get to feel the immense power of having a Heavy Cruiser. It really is about reliving your past with this game, is it worth the money you spent to get the game? probably not, but thats not the point of this game. You write the story as your people return home!In all, I'm enjoying the game, its nice to see a game where just building a massive force doesn't mean victory. Brute force means nothing if your taking damage from a Super Nova. Or when your larger ships become enemies versus a ghost ship. Then you get to try to fight enemies on your terms, using your tactics...which mostly involve salvage corvettes....I would say get the game, its past of your past, and with Steam Workshop, the endless mods should add hours of gameplay.Pro'sImpressive and heartwarming storylineA 3D enviroment Con'sDodgy formations which can give the enemy the advantageStrange ship discissionsHarvasting system is very strange and just plain annoying, as they spend ages getting place to place. and when you hyperspace, you are given ALL the RU's on the map, making the harvasting of little point (the hyperspace tip is fantastic for the super nova mission, where you can lose all harvasters)

												Spoiler Free Review: Once you step into the realm of Homeworld, a flood of memories will hit you like an onslaught, meeting an old friend, a friend who is out to kill you.  I remember the game being hard, but I totally forgot how hard.  If you like a challenge, this is the game.  It is both engaging and challenging.  You're not playing for the story, which is contrived, but it's the game play where this game shines. Controls are excellent for moving in 3D space, and the graphics are quite an improvement over the originals.  I wish the graphics were a bit better though, they aren't the best of what is currently out there, a little room for improvement.Be prepared for a challenge.  You'll replay levels that you won just so you can have a few more ships and resources left over to give you an edge in the next mission.   Rating: 8 out of 10. Recommended. Playing on i7-6700, 16Gb Ram, GTX1070

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												I cannot in good conscience recommend this "remaster" of Homeworld 1 & 2. The new graphics are fantastic (when they aren't glitching out) but the game takes a step backwards in almost every other regard.Fuel consumption is gone, which while convenient, almost entirely negates the necessity of support frigates and carriers. Fighter screens now break formation at the first sign of enemy contact, and tactical stances are seemingly nonexistent.Some aesthetic flourishes from the original have been removed, things only a vet would notice. Research stations no longer rotate idly. The game automatically collects all resources between missions, which bugs the heck out of me. One of my favorite atmospheric touches in the original was the time spent quietly and patiently gathering minerals after a fight. The sluggishness of this process gave you time to reflect on the story, made you admire the beautiful outer space vistas and felt like something a real life space commander would have to endure. It was cool. Now the game just slurps everything up after it's too late to make any use of it.The song "Homeworld" by Yes has also been removed from the credits, due to legal reasons. Give me a break.What bothers me the most, however, is the complete removal of title cards for in-game speech. A nifty rectangular box with a character portrait used to pop up whenever someone talked to you. Now it's just a boring line of floating text.Some of the in-game triggers no longer function. In the last mission, Captain Elson never showed up with his relief fleet and I was left to attack the enemy flagship on my own. And before I forget: Every other time I played the game I'd be greeted with flickering textures or see-through ships. No matter how many graphical options I switched on or off, raised or lowered, nothing could be done. It was distracting. Unacceptable for a release priding itself on its updated graphics.Lastly, the game just feels dumbed-down and generally easier.Basically, Gearbox just "upgraded" every design aspect of Homeworld 1 to that of Homeworld 2, a game which, despite the graphical overhall, inspired ship designs and stellar soundtrack, always failed to capture my imagination. The lack of manual Hyperspace is ultimately what killed it for me.Perhaps the most grievous sin in this "remaster" is the absense of the best game in the Homeworld series: Cataclysm. Yes, I understand they've "lost" the source code. How hard would it be to rip a copy off the disc and include it in the download? If you haven't played Cataclysm, you are missing out. It is one of the best real-time strategy games ever made, and probably the only title in the genre to fall under the unique label, "horror-RTS".If you have never played a Homeworld game then this is a must buy, as classic versions of both 1 & 2 are included. If you were already a fan, like me, skip it or wait for a proper patch.

number of helpful: 18 of 29 people (62%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												The term "HD Remake" is thrown around a lot these days and conveys almost the same amount of infamy as "Early Access". Homeworld Remastered, however, is an absolute exception. Gearbox seemed to have made it their goal to stay as true to the original as possible, while still carrying it over to 2015. Very successfully so, I might add!Quick overview:Homeworld's core game mechanics have been entirely preserved for Homeworld Remastered, down the smallest detail. It is delightful to see how extremely well Homeworld's rather unique approach to 3D real time strategy has aged.Graphics have been revamped while absolutely keeping in line with the game's distinctive art style. It's beyond anything I expected. NB: The original Homeworld 1 user interface has been forfeited in favour of Homeworld 2's much leaner and less cluttered UI. Smart move, really.Sound and music, both in terms of recording quality and ingame sound engine, had major overhauls. Very noticeable. After all, they got none other than Paul Ruskay himself, who scored Homeworld's original soundtrack.This "remastered" version was clearly done by people who appreciated the original game for what it represented back in 1999 (and many years to follow). They gave it a loving, respectful, much desired and much needed facelift to bring it to modern systems.The result is nothing short of stunning. Players new to the series are absolutely recommended to take a closer look at the revival of an RTS cult classic; Homeworld veterans will immediately feel at home and - as in my case - nostalgic as hell.10/10, easily.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												TLDR: Wait a few months for gearbox to fix it or for the mod community to fix it.If you were a huge fan like myself you may be dissappointed with the First homeworld remastered game. As that was the main one I was looking forward to. It makes a great first impression till you start to realize that the hotkeys are now more complicated then they were in the past. So it feels like you are trying to dance with the keyboard. Having units autotarget friendlies and enemies is a tedieous task. The worst example is with repair vessels. Before you could tell them to fix any damaged ships you selected. Now they only focus on a single ship till you tell them to change. Sphere formations guarding a vunerable ship was a great startegy in the past. Not anymore. If you tell a ship to guard another. It would be distracted by something as a single probe and forget about its target you told to guard. Because of this I have the odd feeling that is why they decreased the number of enemy ships you have to fight on some missions. Because they must have been like  "Oh crap we made this game harder then the orignial to play. Maybe we should give them a tiny bit of slack if we want them to micromanaged every single ship. Also you know how you could easily select formation of ships in the orignal as well? not anymore. Now you select every single ship of that type on screen when you double click. And not just the formation you want to seperatly move. That is all I found so far before I gave up and replayed the orignal to make sure my memory of how it controlled and played was the same. Sure enough the orignal plays as great as it always has but this remastered edition feels like 1 step forward and 2 steps back. Wait a month or two before buying and maybe gearbox might patch some of the old gameplay features back in. If not we will have to rely on the mod community to help fix the remastered versions. So far they been doing a good job but to fix everything is going to take awhile. If they ever make a homeworld 3 I will not buy it because gearbox tricked me into thinking it would be fun. They made it look pretty but not fun. If you don't beleive me and having troubles with the remastered version. Go give the orignal version a try and you will see how much better it controls.Only nice thing with this collection is the inclusion of the orignal 2 games to make up for the fact they dropped the ball in various areas.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Where to begin? Homeworld 1 and 2 probably form the basis for the late THQ's success in the RTS genre; an excellent story driven campaign, X,Y,Z axis space combat, an epic sense of scale in relation to said combat and one of the best soundtracks to any game, not to mention the stylish cut scenes that convey the story to the player. However the remastered collection has reworked both titles (HW1 and HW2) in an improved homeworld 2 engine and thus delivers what we all wanted; HW1 in high definition jaw dropping glory. Also players can now enjoy a combined multiplayer experience with the factions from both games available to play against one another; so if you ever wondered who was the more hard core out of the Tiadan and the Vagyr you can now find out! Last and by no means least the steam workshop adds mods from many diverse sci fi franchises such as star wars, star trek, BSG, mass effect, wing commander etc etc. Therefore in conclusion I am rather grateful that nothing crazy like Homeworld 3 was attempted as the original two games have been unsurpassed for over a decade - until now.

content:
Posted: January 30
												The good-Mothership-A classic restored. Homeworld is a gem i regret missing out back in its hey day. There is a reason why its the Granddaddy of space RTS.-RTS is rock solid. You assign control groups into several different formations. There is a good reason to delay finishing a mission to harvest resources. Surviving untis carry over to the next mission and each has a purpose, some have abilities, but each has strenghs and weakness to consider. -Each level bring a unique obstacle to overcome. -Some enemy units and tactics can feel cheap but preperation and good strategy will always win out. It helps to be patient and methodical and it feels tremendous when you overcome.-Tactical overlay is awesome and i wish more space RTS had it. -Strong narrative. The lore is an interesting take on space fantasy and the far future. Its dramatic, somber, compelling and well paced.-Remastered visuals are pretty. Explosions are vibrant and explody. Wear and tear show up on selected ships and debris liters space. You can pause the action to take snapshots if compelled.-The audio is outstanding. The voice work, sound effects, the OST in particular is, in my opinion, the best in this genre.The bad-The game can and will crash. Its a given with games today sure but when you're  30mins+ into a mission that's going well nothing is more irratating than an unexpected crash.-Unit management can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Despite ordering a group to be defensive and gaurd another unit (which you assume they would hold their ground and fire at incoming enemy) they'll go off and chase an enemy and get slaughtered.You really have to consider what all units are doing at once which gets tricky when the fighting heats up. Just know that units you assign to gaurd WILL fly off to assault what the gaurded is ordered to attack. Formations is key.-♥♥♥♥ the Junkyard Dog.-Some mission objectives might not register despite having done excatly as instructed forcing you to restart Steam or at worst redo the whole mission.The ugly-My system more than meets the requirements but the game can get glitchy in long play sessons. RUs and captured units can dissapear from the screen but be in game.-Units can freeze in place-Acheivements, whether you care or not, might not unlock forcing you to redo missions. Despite the bugs if you're an RTS fan, Homeworld is definitely worth playing and worth the price of admission. Thank you Gearbox and Blackbird for restoring this classic. Thank you Relic

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Homeworld is two games I have spent hours and hours playing. From the (incredible) main campaigns to the excellent mods for them. So Remastered comes and polishes them up (and ports HW1 to the HW2 engine) which seems like the perfect of perfects. Except its not. Except it is.HW1 mechanics are flawed. Badly. Sometimes hilariously. The port of the game over to the HW2 engine is not as smooth as I hoped it would be. They nerfed the salvette everything strategy, but the HW2 AI is kind of laughable in HW1's tactical situations anyway, plus the addition of default "jump with all map resources" from HW2 takes out the need for fleet tooling and resource op micromanagement which was kind of a staple for me in the first game. But it does (largely) function like it should. Homeworld 1 still feels like Homeworld 1. And it. is. glorious. But where remastered really shines is with Homeworld 2. Designed for the engine already the gameplay and visuals are just absolutely flooring if you've played the game back in the day. It's easily the best looking space RTS. Even beating out Sins. Gearbox nailed the graphics and sound for both packages and the game is gorgeous and plays very well on my system, even in large engagements. There's rough areas, MP is broken, it took a while for me to even get the game to launch, and HW1's mechanics are iffy at parts. However this is still the Homeworld I remember, redone in highest quality that could command AAA prices. I have no personal ties to Cataclysm though, so I can't comment on that too much. I know its some kind of hugemassive problem for some people. They shouldn't look this gifthorse in the mouth though. 10/10 AI still reks me at mission 3 of HW2 :|

												As much reverence as I have for Homeworld, this game feels like it's in beta.Broken damage from ion cannons and capital ships, pitifully low salvage corvette cap, fighter pathing issues that will make you throw your monitor, dumbed down missions, dumbed down resource collection (rendered moot after misison five due to auto collect), dumbed down AI (refusing to use capital ships to defend primary missions objectives, not using gravity well generators, not using cloak generators), and most importantly, the game RANDOMLY HAVING MISSION OBJECTIVES GO BLANK, which renders your current mission unable to be completed.That was fun, after I took three hours to capture the entire enemy fleet on mission 14, Bridge of Sighs, and my objectives went blank, refusing to let me finish the mission despite destroying the inhibitor array.The game feels watered down and panders to the "can't be bothered to figure it out" type of gamer. Much as I dislike badmouthing studios, this is the reason gearbox is sketchy. It honestly feels like an EA product: well intentioned but relentlessly frustrating. If steam had better customer support I'd try to get my money back.The pretty skins and good memories of creepy space don't outweigh the absolute frustration of trying to bumble my way through this trainwreck.

												I played the original game way back in 2000. I played the two sequels when they came out, as well. I loved them to bits. But then I heard Gearbox was doing a remastering of the games. Say what you will about Gearbox, they hit it out of the park with this collection. I nearly cried when I started Homeworld up for the first time in a decade and a half.The good: Basically everything. The audio was remastered based on the original recordings and it all sounds incredible. The graphics have been updated and look gorgeous. The UI now using the Homeworld 2 UI for both games, which is a massive improvement over the original Homeworld.The bad: No one knows what happened to the source code for Homeworld: Cataclysm, which was a cool, albeit strange, spin off from Barking Dog Stuidios. Therefore, the Collection is, in my opinion, incomplete. Maybe we'll get lucky and the source code will turn up.The takeaway: I had felt that Homeworld had held up pretty well, given it's age. I still think that, but the Remastered Collection brought the game to being as close to perfect as a game can get.
