Posted: June 7, 2016
												If you had asked me to review this Remastered version of Homeworld back when it released.  I wouldn't have rated it very positively.  The big problem I had with the game then was that the Homeworld 1 assets and campaign were superimposed on the mechanics and engine of the 2nd game.  Unfortunately Homeworld 2 changed the way fighters were built and controlled from the first game.  This creates a game-breaking problem in the Homeworld 1 campaign (which is worth playing on the original release).The latest 2.0 update to Homeworld: Remastered has largely fixed those issues.  Fighter formations and behaviors for Homeworld 1 fighters have returned which is crucial to success in the campaign.  I have yet to try this in Multiplayer to see how this affects balance.  That being said, I'm very happy with the update Gearbox has made to this game with regards to the single player campaign and I look very much forward to completing it again in the remastered edition.

Posted: March 2, 2015
												(only addressing HW1R, not the others in the set)A beautiful reskin of the original, but a surprising amount of gameplay bugs are pretty readily apparent:- formations do not work AT ALL: ships can be moved into one, but they disintegrate entirely upon combat, and strike craft are now almost a complete waste of money since they get individually picked off way too fast.- no evasive tactics mode to harass/delay enemy units- salvaged ships can't be retired until the next map- friendly units will fire on ships on their way to be salvaged- salvage corvettes can't intelligently divide up multi-ship captures anymore- healing units don't watch over not-yet-damaged units correctlyOther surprising design choices:- research cost a bit of money now (OK)- LOTS more resources on maps, including salvagable capital wreck scap, means things feel MUCH easier now- strike craft no longer use fuel, reducing need for forward support frigate/carrier deploymentThis game need one or more patches BADLY.I will be happy to change my review to recommend it once the issues get fixed, since it's still a solid design at its core.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												I know there are far more detailed reviews out there, and far more emotional, too. I'm not trying to compete with those, just expressing my personal feelings.For those that haven't played HW1, just two words: go ahead. This won't disappoint, and you won't even notice the things us ♥♥♥♥♥♥s are unhappy about. For the likes of me, however, here's what to expect.First off, this is not Homeworld 1. Close, much closer than expected, but still no. All those tiny details will make you feel something isn't quite right, no matter how well or poorly you remember the original. The UI, of course, is probably the worst offender, feeling too modern, too... I just don't know the right words. I guess the UI aesthetics have changed greatly over time, and I am sad to see Gearbox going the HW2 route when it came to styling (hopefully, it's not as clunky as HW2 was, but the overall UI art is on the same track). But this is a minor issue, and once you get over it, you will notice it is quite playable. Make no mistake, the old one wasn't perfect either, it was just much more "in theme".Next thing you notice (unless, you crash on mission load as I did numerous times, in that case make sure you aren't overgenerous selecting texture quality), it looks gorgeous (albeit, a bit too "sleek" when compared to the first game. That is just a feeling, and it comes from the game defaulting to HW2 colour scheme, nothing else. Once you select original HW1 colours you're back with the old feel of "newbies to space". It is a great thing, really.They did choose to port HW1 into HW2 engine, which made the game lose some of its original features, like simulated projectiles, and it fails miserably at holding formations, plus there are differences in resources available, ship costs, oh, and research now costs too. That all said, I am glad to say I didn't pick most of these things till I've been told about them. And, what's most important to me, the original feeling of being alone out there, a small island of life in the middle of cold indifferent space, it all has translated well into the remake.Furthermore, most of these changes weren't there to "make the game better", rather because the new engine wasn't capable of supporting these things (although, research costs seem like a strange thing, it's not that difficult to set cost to 0, while timers are all there already). And, while it may be a minor thing to some, fighters SHOULD cost 55, not 100.And assault frigates were at 625, unless I'm mistaken.Ok, enough, I'm just being too picky. This is a fine remake, none the less. It actually tries hard to be as close to the original as possible (although, heaven knows, we'd love to see nothing but new textures here). It is far more honest to the original than X-COM was to its grandfather, X-COM: Enemy Unknown, the latter I'd call a major disappointment - you don't make an excellent game better by screwing with it. This one isn't screwed nearly as much.In the end, is it worth playing? It sure is for me - I did try to replay the original again, but that game has aged visually far too much. There are two space games for me that define the 90's. MOO II and HW1. Sadly, 3D does age faster. Playing this doesn't make me cringe as bad, as trying the original would. And yes, it is an enjoyment. Maybe there is this uncanny valley for remakes as well, when the original and the remake are just too close to be called a different game, yet are still not 100% the same, and this would fall into it. But, again, HW:Rem is almost where the original is. X-COM was right in the middle of that abyss.Be a bit more open-minded about it, and you'll love it. Just don't forget you can't enter the same water twice.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Really short review. Probably won't update in the future.The whole package is great, especially for me since I'd never played the originals. It's important to note for Classic players, though, that there are a few changes to ship behavior and mission structure in HW1R(remastered). Aggressive/Evasive tactics are out, literally removed, and some of the missions appear to have been nerfed for some reason, the Kadesh in particular. The game also hosts a dynamic difficulty setting based on your fleet size, though the specifics of its behavior evade me. Strike group behavior is also altered, making behaviors like setting a Defender squadron to Sphere Formation and guard your target behave differently from Classic. The way damage and accuracy are rolled when ships fire are also different (iirc, it's based far more on dice rolling now).Why is it like that? Well, HW1R runs in the HW2 engine.That being said, I enjoyed HW1R a lot. The story is very vague and built on a lot of mysticism and prophetic themes. The game itself was enjoyable, although I wish that the AI on ships were far more intelligent. You do have to babysit your units (in HW2, too).HW2's a lot better as a gameplay experience though, although its story is a bit less interesting. I felt like a greater number of my ships were valuable throughout the course of the game, vs HW1, where the majority of the units you can build become obsolete very quickly.HW1 had a huge pacing problem because there was no form of time-compression to harvest resources, leading to post-mission lulls lasting over 30 minutes at a time where all you're doing is waiting for utility ships to mine up the money. HW2 solved the problem by crediting you with the resources when a mission was completed, and its overall campaign pacing is much more intense and demanding, definitely welcome, than HW1.I wish Cataclysm was in the remaster pack, but apparently Gearbox couldn't secure the source code for the game.Lastly, I haven't played multiplayer.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I sit here at my computer desk in the wee hours of the morning after just completing the first part of the Homeworld: Remastered games that were recently released on Steam, and as I type away I find it hard to come to the correct words for what I just experienced, so here’s me trying to sum it up for you with what to me is no longer a game, or a footnote on a sheet to check out and play sometime in the future without really ever getting to it, but an idea that was realised in it’s fullest potential and is now at the public’s door once again.Let’s get one thing out the door right away, I never played the original Homeworld. I was too young at the time to really decide what I wanted to play, and what I did play was mostly Starcraft: Brood War (Still in my top games of all time) or rummage through the bucket of Lego in my corner.  So when the news that Homeworld was getting a remaster… I didn’t really celebrate at all and I certainly did not pre-order out the door like I do for way too many games.  Though as the ball kept turning and the time of it’s release drew nearer and nearer I grew infatuated with Homeworld, it’s lore and story that drew me instantly into it, and the sheer scale and effort being put into a game that was cracking on by now.  So this Monday, which is Monday the 2nd of March (I am writing this review on the 7th, in the early hours) I bought it as soon as I could, and here is the result.Homeworld is now what I consider the best story told in gaming.Or at least up there with the greats, of course.The way it was told to me, and how it slowly started to show me this lore that spanned back millions of years in the games universe, the different races and characters I met along the way all felt amazing and diverse, each one beautifully voice acted and all done with space ships on a screen.  There’s no portraits, we aren’t given a face, it’s voices we go on in this experience, and holy hell it knocks it out of the park with that regard.It’s game play (While frustrating at times) is brilliant fun to toy with, there’s nothing more satisfying then launching a full Missile Destroyer attack on the unsuspecting foe below as your attack bombers soar in to deal the final blow, it’s god damned addicting and the fun just comes from finding the ways to out manoeuvre your enemies in the slyest of ways.And finally it’s the music, and how it complements each scene perfectly to the point I was left in awe at what was beset upon my eyes, to the point where this game brought me to tears with the myriad of feelings it produced.  Emotion is key with this tittle, and for the first time in a good long while I was feeling it while playing a game, the twinge of my heart as my favourite Frigate bit the dust, or the cut scenes I will not spoil.Homeworld is an experience for everyone, RTS and non RTS fan alike need to play this game and make it through to the end for the most satisfying ending in gaming.  This game gets my rating of ‘Bury it with me so I can take it to hell’

Posted: February 26, 2015
												Be careful before you buy.If you were expecting a complete port of the original homeworld with a graphical update then this is not the game you're looking for, save your money and play the classic version. There's features in the remastered HW1 that aren't working as intended, Tactics and Formations are broken and are (apparently) not likely to be fixed. It is impossible for anyone who played HW1 to not notice that these things are broken and any claim that they're working as intended, or that it doesn't negatively effect gameplay is patently false. Listen, I'm not a purist but the developers had to of known this wasn't working correctly. Why they couldn't have been up front with people and say that there were certain things they couldn't port and let us decide whether or not we wanted to make the trade offs for the better graphics? Probably because they now have my 30 dollars and don't really give a crap. That sort of dishonest buy-now-patch-later crap is what is ruining PC gaming.The game is playable although buggy, and from what I am reading HW2 is working as intended, but not going to lie when I say that HW1 remaster is a let down.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I love Homeworld. I read about, and waited for the original. I managed to get into the original beta (I have the CD framed). I played this game for hours and days on end. I was depressed when it turned out that the remote turrets were op in mass, and a created nearly unbeatable playing strategy. I felt like a hero when I found a way to beat it. I endured many losses, and more victories playing friends online. I once managed to steal an entire enemy players capital ship fleet with my own fleet of salvage corvettes and a cloaking frigate. THIS, This was Homeworld. Strategy, intuitive interface, as may ships as your computer could handle, and ships that did what you told them.This is not what Gearbox released. They didn't understand the game they were remastering, and because of this, they created an atrocity compare to the original. It is as if they tried to recreate the Mona Lisa using Crayons. They didn't get it. I was afraid this was going to happen when Team Pixel lost the bid for the THQ Bankruptcy. They got it, they understood what made this game so amazing. I was right to fear. GearBox didn't understand; they thought that they could just make it pretty, and as simple as possible. They didn't get that what made Homeworld great wasn't the beauty of the game (though it was spectacular visually), but rather the way everything functioned. If you never played the original, you won't know what you are missing. You will probably enjoy the game just fine.  If you did, don't bother, this game will just make you sad. It will kill off part of your youth. P.S. Most of the hours I have played were just trying to get the game to work on three monitors.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Played HW1 campaign and it is very much as advertised a remastered HD-Version of the original with all the good and bad this entails. Graphics and audio are really well done and atmospherical however unit AI, formations and controls are just as wonky and 2000 like the original. Hell even the Salvage-Corvette powerplay to trick the force-limit has been carried over. All in all 9/10. Would have wished for a bit more improvement on the AI and Interface-Front but for 30 bucks I can't complain too much. Loved this game back then, still love it now and I happily throw this kinda money at people allowing me to re-play one of my old-time-favourites on a modern 64-bit machine with upgraded visuals.

But they do give up every so often, so you need to renew their orders.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												In the past I've heard a bit about how cool Homeworld was, and I have to say I am thoroughly impressed. Being a big fan of the RTS genre, when I heard about this game I immediately wanted to try it out, but alas, it was unavailable. So when I saw "Homeworld Remastered" on Steam's front page a few weeks ago it went straight to my wishlist, and I ended up buying it the day before release.I was concerned that I might have impulsively spent $30 on something that wasn't really worth it, but now I have no idea why.Having played around 4 hours of this game over the two days since release, I've only gotten more endeared to the game and how epic it feels. Building a huge fleet of frigates, destroyers, and battlecruisers and then proceeding to wipe out some poor AI... Awesome.Some Quick Pros and ConsPROS:-- Phenomenal feel, moving ships around in 3D space doesn't feel confusing or difficult. While I have yet to employ it significantly, I'm sure it will make things quite interesting.-- AI is, for the most part, pretty smart. While it makes some dumb moves from time to time it doesn't give up unless all is lost.-- Oh my word, the visuals are incredible! Next time you have a large group of fighters engaging the enemy, select one of them, focus and zoom in. Large-scale, small-scale, everything looks beautiful, even on my puny GT 630.CONS:-- There's some minor bugs, like when moving ships I'll occasionally lose my mouse cursor for a second or two. Every so often the sound skips and repeats 1-2 second snippets of a clip.NEUTRAL:-- Gameplay moves a bit slower. It requires patience to build up a sizable attack force and deploy it to wipe out the enemy, but once that combat starts you really grasp the benefit of taking the time to work.I may expand on this review as I spend more time playing the game, but if you're still doubting whether you want to buy this, let me eliminate any doubt. The Homeworld Remastered Collection is an awesome piece of work. For $35, you get an incredible RTS, its sequel, and the remastered versions of both. Hopefully Gearbox will provide a demo at some point, but if you're a fan of the RTS genre, purchasing this shouldn't be a question.

Posted: August 13, 2016
												An epic and artful strategy with finely tuned mechanics and plenty of replay value. Includes 2 distinct single-player campaigns and 4 (but more like 3) playable races in multiplayer mode. Recent updates have helped to clarify the roles of each unit in the game and to allow for different play styles. Though the online community is relatively small compared to other AAA titles, the game rewards those who come back to it with depth and variety, making it worth the asking price in my opinion.

Posted: June 29, 2016
												The entire feel of the orginal games has been lost in a failed attempt at remastering them. Somehow even after considerable time after its release, the collection still feels broken. Pros: -Everything is beautiful compared to the very aged graphics of the originals.Cons: -The AI is buggy at best. HW 1, Mission 5 I had enemy intereceptors doing loops across the map endlessly. Other times, your own units failed to listen to orders at random. -Somehow units are defaulting themselves to passive stance, and while they do stay in formation, all they do is stay, and die. -In HW1 remastered, you are punished unexpectingly for building up your fleet in the previous mission. Mission 3: Captured a bunch of Turanic Raider corvettes in previous mission only to find 6 Taiidan assault frigates obliterating the cryopods I was to save. Redid mission 2, scrapped all corvettes, 2 frigates in mission 3 second time around. Wtf? This happens again in mission 5 where the AI throws 5+ destroyers at you when you cannot even build one at all. Well, that escalated quickly, so much for preparing ahead of time for the battle. -There are many other cons I haven't the time to write a novel to explain.

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Before I get into the review I want to address the criticisms of the game's units. There's been a long standing criticism that the game's "rock, paper, scissors" gameplay, where everything has a counter. It appears some people are pretty irritated about that. Well, here's the thing: that's warfare. Look at modern militaries today. Everything has a counter. Infantry carry shoulder fired missile systems to destroy vehicles and hard points to remove those threats. Tanks carry both AP and HE rounds to deal with infantry and vehicles. Aircraft can be shot down like nothing by guided missile and surface to air missile systems. Everything has a counter. The game's system for units is actually the more realistic one, believe it or not. So, I don't understand the gripes about it. Just make sure you've got solid recon and you're fine. It's important to note though that even modern militaries have combined arms forces, so don't think that just because you've got the counter to something that you won't get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked. A well rounded, combined arms force, regardless of its composition, is still a big part of your overall fleet strategy. The next thing I want to address is a big gripe I've seen about fighter strategies. With the hindrance given to fighters in the remastered edition, interceptors no longer play a large role in the battle. They're weaker, and that's also realistic. One thing that should be understood is that air superiority and interceptor aircraft are made for a single purpose: to fight other aircraft. Unless a large ship has no support, there's really no reason why you should be using interceptors to attack a large vessel. The fact of the matter is that you're not going to make a dent in the hull of a ship with a massive superstructure, and a hull designed to both take weapons fire and the force of gravity, in the vacuum of space where a hull breach vents an entire compartment, and possibly an explosive decompression. It just isn't logical to believe that you can make that happen. Historically, the Japanese in world war 2 would run suicide kamikaze attack against a large ship, because that's really the only way a fighter can cause a severe amount of damage against something that big, unless it's carrying bombs. The same goes for any unit in the game, where every unit has a purpose, be it specialized attacks against certain kinds of unit or support for the important vessels in your fleet. But, I digress. If you're looking for a deeply strategic and tactical space simulation with an excellent storyline and back story (seriously, it's fantastic!), then you've come to the right place. With mods being ported over to the Remastered collection, you won't have to wait long for your replay ability value to skyrocket. It's even better that, as I write this review, the game is discounted for the winter sales. You should already have this game in your steam library. As far as I'm concerned, it's blown games like Sins of a Solar Empire off the planet.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Homeworlds 1 and 2 are among the best games ever made for PC. This "Remastered" version does a good job of preserving that legacy and also adds increased graphic fidelity and performance. The single player missions are engaging, the original's voice acting and artwork remain haunting and first class, the storyline is compelling. If you love science fiction and don't get goose bumps at least once, there is something wrong with you. My sole complaint is that for a game which championed free movement in three dimensional space, that element of strategy is often overlooked in the campaign: like Kahn, your enemies suffer from two-dimensional thinking. But if you've never played Homeworld and you see this game on sale, don't hesitate.Meanwhile multiplayer remains a shabby amateur mess with horrific balance issues, even after a one year wait for patches, and the bulk of the "community" is toxic beyond belief, but this is Gearbox and Steam, so you already knew that.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I missed Homeworld the first time around and I absolutely do not regret picking up the remastered collection. This game is a must for RTS fans for the campaign alone. Having units, tech, and resources arry over from mission to mission makes the campaign feel connected rather than random instances. You actually feel attatched to your mothership in way. The story is actually worth paying attention to and is aided by some great voice-acting, scoring, and a beautiful graphical update. The UI take a bit to get used to but is solid and has options to make long-time Homeworld players feel at home. The implementation of actual 3-D space isn't just for show either, it had me thinking about formations and unit placement in a whole new way.TLDR; There's a reason this game is often considered the best RTS of all time and it isn't nostalgia.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												I was about 12 when the original came. I had a friend who would go on and on about it to me, at the time I was silly enough to have no interest in sci-fi though and was too absorbed in Age of Empires 2. That certainly changed in time!I knew I'd love this game because it was conceived by Relic and, as a long time RTS fan, I'd never played one set in space before!One minor grievance is probably simply that the callouts for nearly every unit are identical and spoken in a rather monotone voice and the dialogue lacks any humour or personal touch, from my experience. The music is the absolute opposite though, beautiful and with a uniquely middle eastern flavour! I'm definitely lucky enough to be perhaps one of the rarer people here who are able to enjoy these masterpieces now for the first time, with shiny graphics!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Most real-time strategy games I've played are quite lacking in storytelling.  This is not one of those games.  The original creators of this game, Relic (known for the Company of Heroes and Dawn of War Series) are masters of blending storytelling with real-time strategy while not ignoring the importance of replayability through multiplayer.  Homeworld probably has the most poignant stories I've ever seen without the need for fully animated, fully voiced, lip synched characters.Without revealing the plot, I can tell you that you will feel invested for the safety of the people you are commanding and fighting for.On the more technical side, this game was way ahead of its time in 1999 and holds up well for being nearly 20 years old.  The graphical improvements are a welcome change and a more modern, post-dialup era multiplayer lobby is also welcome.  The voice acting of the narrator, the Mothership's computer, and all your units is outstanding and has not changed from the original.The music also deserves an honorable mention for its ability to add to the feeling of every cutscene, every battle, and every dialogue you encounter.  Top notch stuff.  Especially if you like ambient electronic music.The game is not perfect, however.  Like most RTS games from the 90's, it can be heavy in the micromanaging department.    I also have to dock the games for having somewhat clumsy default controls, a UI that leaves a lot to be desired, and a rather steep learning curve.Another con for some may be the rock-paper-scissor formula that Relic is known for throughout their games.  In this game, there are units that are simply a hard counter to another unit.  In later Relic RTS games, you can see where they added in more unit versatility and soft counters through combined arms.  This leads to some rather spammy gameplay that might be a turn-off for some.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												*Note This is a work in progress review, it will change if devs address the major issues with a few of the mechanics.Even though the graphics, audio and UI redesigns are good I cannot recommend this game right now. It seems like gearbox has broken gameplay mechanics entirely in the remaster of HW1 because of the porting of engine to HW2 engine. Here are just a few of the issues:-The formations are wonky and don't work. You need formations to strike enemy ships effectively. In these games they just use their own flight patterns after they get close to enemy and don't stay in formation.-Game is not using balistic system of the original and instead uses rng, so there are too much hard counters to everything. It is not physics based.-Support frigates are useless unless you get them to follow around and make sure they are healing targets.-Capturing mechanics broken, it is too easy.-salvage corvettes easily capture enemy corvettes because evasion mechanics disabled(they are not part of the rng system)-Salvage ships not showing their beam animation-Why is queues limited to 2?-Collision system is broke, stuff like resource collecters and other ship crash into astroids or other objects and then attempt to push through them instead of moving back.-Some shortcuts do work but its inconsistent, like some keys open certain menus but don't close them when pressed again, while others close when pressed again. Its weird.EDIT:Seems I was wrong with some of the UI mechanics. You can highlight and then choose what ships to select, or you can double click a selected ship and it will highlight all similar ships nearby. You can also select military only ships to be highlighted.This is a very good UI mechanic in the game, just wish they would explain in the tutorials.

												Summary: This is the remake that Homeworld fans have been waiting for. The Homeworld Remastered Collection features everything included in Homeworld and Homeworld 2, with a modern UI and vastly improved graphics.Pros:Multiplayer thus far is working well.AI is FAR more sophisticated and difficult than in the older games.Campaign cinematics have been updated.Sound design is greatly improved, with many of the old familiar effects redone.Game setup options are greatly increased over the original.Classic Homeworld complexity and gameplay.Cons:Menu lag persists, but developers seem to be patching often.Multiplayer is still in beta, and can still crash.Some minor graphical glitches at release.Overal: Definitely reccomend. I gave this game/remake 9 out of 10.

content:
Posted: February 6
												i have been playing a lot of RTS games revently and a lot of them are older games like the first star craft and dawn of war and this game which is almost as old as i am is probably the best playing RTS i have ever played and the story is very well done with few games even coming close to how good the story is this is a perfect way to make a story for this type of gamethe difficulty is very wierd in this game there are some missions where if you just have a lot of frigates and capital ships its a cake walk because all the enemy had brought is interceptors that are useless against bigger ships. and then there are others that are hard because they are confusing and dont explain to you how to do them like the dust cloud mission where the game at this point never told you how to change your ships altitude so you ships are lost from radiation. then there is the last mission where i felt it was unfair and to the point where i actually went back and replayed the second to last mission just to change my fleet to be capable of winning because the enemy in the first wave goes full force right off the bat at your mother ship and at first it seems to be impossible to beat when the enemy only uses bombers ion cannons and capital ships which are all the hardest hitting ships in the game and they ignore your fleet and only attack the mother ship. it catches you so off gaurd because the last few missions where not all that difficult and then the mission starts off with a full on assault and when you arent expecting it because most missions give you some room to breath and build ships or set up strike groups and the enemy ends up killing your mother ship in about 2 minutes other then that i feel like the game was well paced.the whole way through and the whole time the faction you play as is very misterious because you dont know much about them and it seems that most of them dont even know much about their own race either all they know is the name of their homeworld written on one of their artifacts which is a map and you slowly learn that you where at one point a huge empire that ruled the galaxy and then reduced to nothing and most of your race is wipped out and exiled to a desert planet its a very intersting story which is unusuall for a RTS game i have not played homeworld 2 yet but honestly i think this game is worth buying just for the first game alone its strange that a game that came out in 1999 plays better then most RTS games that have recently came out

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												One of the best games from the late 90's has been overhauled and finally been given the look that the game deserves. Not only has this game sent me back to my own youth but its also rekindled an unhealthy relationship with the game series that I spent most of my teens playing, mainly when I should have been doing my homework! Homeworld Remastered beings homeworld 1 and homeworld 2 into today with vastly improved graphics and a remastered audio track. The look and feel of the game is very similar to homeworld 2 as both the remastered games use an upgraded version of the HW2 game engine but with upgrades to improve the look.Neither game however have lost anything but only gained. Infact homeworld 1 now plays with the options you had in homeworld 2. Homeworld 1 remastered even let you build in single units rather than small groups of fighters as you do in 2.The campaigns are better than ever with the storyline not changed, the increasingly difficult missions of HW1 gets transfered over in homeworld remastered nicely. The player vs CPU, or skirmish mode has a stange feel to it, but has been upgraded to feature some new modes including tasks such as harvest x resources for a bonus; and crates. However the best feature allows you to pit HW1 factions against HW2. Although in BETA at the time of writing this review, the multiplayer mode shows some promise.I do feel that the pitting of sides from HW1 and HW2 against eachother is a nice feature, it does need some ironing out. So far the HW2 sides seem to have the edge on the HW1 sides. It would be nice to see some new features other than game modes. Maybe some more maps, special units for skirmish, maybe even a turanic raiders or kadeshi faction to play in skirmish/multiplayer.Not only do you get the remastered games, the classic versions are also here too for that ultimate look back.I do have to admit though, it was nice to play the entire game in a few days and it took me back a fair few years. I can highly recommend. If you loved the classic games back in the day, then remastered is for you.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I pre-ordered the Collector's Edition, but I'll be honest - loading up the first Homeworld, getting told to put your ships in formation, and then have that formation mean absolutely nothing in terms of gameplay initially irritated me and eventually put me off on playing the game.Mind you, everything else was pretty much top-notch. Art, sound, visuals - all there. Most of the gameplay still there, too.Anyway, Gearbox have made it clear that this is a labor of love. They have been promising for a while now that a huge "mega-patch" was coming that fixes a whole lot of stuff, including adding in proper formations (which required them to rewrite the entire movement code) - and that patch has landed. I've never been more happy with a game. They released a 5.2GB patch! Insane.Highly recommended to old fans such as myself or new-comers who want to fall in love with an entire universe. Between playing The Witcher 3 and this, I think I'll be spoiled plot and universe-wise for a while to come.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												i have been playing a lot of RTS games revently and a lot of them are older games like the first star craft and dawn of war and this game which is almost as old as i am is probably the best playing RTS i have ever played and the story is very well done with few games even coming close to how good the story is this is a perfect way to make a story for this type of gamethe difficulty is very wierd in this game there are some missions where if you just have a lot of frigates and capital ships its a cake walk because all the enemy had brought is interceptors that are useless against bigger ships. and then there are others that are hard because they are confusing and dont explain to you how to do them like the dust cloud mission where the game at this point never told you how to change your ships altitude so you ships are lost from radiation. then there is the last mission where i felt it was unfair and to the point where i actually went back and replayed the second to last mission just to change my fleet to be capable of winning because the enemy in the first wave goes full force right off the bat at your mother ship and at first it seems to be impossible to beat when the enemy only uses bombers ion cannons and capital ships which are all the hardest hitting ships in the game and they ignore your fleet and only attack the mother ship. it catches you so off gaurd because the last few missions where not all that difficult and then the mission starts off with a full on assault and when you arent expecting it because most missions give you some room to breath and build ships or set up strike groups and the enemy ends up killing your mother ship in about 2 minutes other then that i feel like the game was well paced.the whole way through and the whole time the faction you play as is very misterious because you dont know much about them and it seems that most of them dont even know much about their own race either all they know is the name of their homeworld written on one of their artifacts which is a map and you slowly learn that you where at one point a huge empire that ruled the galaxy and then reduced to nothing and most of your race is wipped out and exiled to a desert planet its a very intersting story which is unusuall for a RTS game i have not played homeworld 2 yet but honestly i think this game is worth buying just for the first game alone its strange that a game that came out in 1999 plays better then most RTS games that have recently came out

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												After playing this game for a few hours and reliving the nostalgia of my childhood I'd have to say that the game definitely delivered. However! There are a few bugs or irritations (namely 2 during my playthrough) that should be prioritized for a fix above all else if I'm to call it the "closest to perfect" remaster and that is to recalibrate the formations so that they actually have a meaning in the game. There have been so many instances (practically the whole game) where formations didn't decide the flow of battle. The units just scattered in combat and thus left a lot of undeserved casualties.The second thing to fix is the AI for the harvesters. In the original you could send them out to do their business and wouldn't need to worry about them unless being attacked. But after finishing the first nebula mission and sending them to harvest the rest of the area, they went out, took care of one vein and then just went stationary like there wasn't any resources left (but of course there still were). So I had to manually send them to another vein and have them continue.These need to be fixed if it is to be remembered fully to the original. Many things have been done great but there are still a few things that just ruin the game for me. Overall it is of course a beautiful remaster of the game and the graphics are set on. Just needs a bit of fixing but since it just released I can definitely give the developers some time.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												One does not simply recognize that this is already a 15 year old game without being told XDAfter 15 years this game is still the best at what it does and it has certainly aged beautifully. Why so much complaining?My advice to those with issues, complaints or problems :* Wait for bugfixes or the modding community to fix it, which they certainly will :D just be patient. You have to bear in mind that this game is already 15 years old and was just remastered, not remade.* Play the Homeworld 2 Classic ( which what Ive been doing ) . I honestly think it is better than the remastered version ( looks aside ) because of all those great mods! Which are:a. Complex modb. Homefront mod ( they have very awesome looking ships )c. Complex Enhanced ( kinda like complex but without the ranks, energy and research points )d. Tactical Fleet Simulator ( makes the game more fast paced and has cool new ships ) e. FreeSpace: Fleet CommandThese mods make the classic better than the remastered and i could never again go back to playing vanilla homeworld because they just add so much more to the game You can all download these mods in the workshop with just a single click.I hope this helped! See you in the Homeworld everyone! Because of its fair price and the 4 games that it contains i give it a score of:9/10 Please start developing Homeworld 3!( might be 10/10 in the future when they patch things up and some awesome mods gets released )

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												If you have never played any of the other Home World games you are in for a treat, jaw dropping graphics, beautiful visuals, astonishing audio. If you have, leave your memories at the door, they will be shattered. This is definitely not a remastered collection. This is little more than a re-imaging of HW2 with HW1 ships added in. If you have fond memories of the multiplayer lobby experience, don't come here expecting to make new ones, that key feature is totally absent and no plans are in the works currently to add one. This is definitely NOT a remastering of the originals.If you can live with those differences more power to you, me, I give it the following scores:Visuals: 5 out of 5Audio: 4.5 out of 5Controls: 2.5 out of 5Game play Single play: 3.5 out of 5Game play Multiplay: 2 out of 5**IMHO lack of a lobby seriously drops the score for multiplay, game play can be really fun, but no chance to talk with your team mates after a game or to discuss games in a lobby while waiting for games to start, really drops the longevity of the title.UPDATE:Since this original review was posted the developers surprized the community with a functioning lobby. It isn't the lobby system we had in either of the originals but it does raise the fun factor and multi-playability a tremendous amount. Now you can talk with anyone  in the main lobby or in the game lobby while waiting to get enough people to join. That alone is enough to raise the score I put for multiplay to 4 out of 5.The developers also released a major patch that fixed a lot of issues but there is still a load of work needing completion. The game is better now than it was at release and hopefully we will see the final polish put on the game in 2017.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												This collection is amazing. First about the collection itself, the collection has a whole bunch of content that at the time of writing I haven't even got to yet. Not only do they have the original homeworld 1 and 2, but also the re-mastered version which clearly had a lot of love put into them.Now, I know some people will call this blasphemous, but I haven't played the original versions, and I'll give a review for each game in the collection. There may be changes in the originals and remasters like the UI and apparently some unit balancing issues? Again, the changes seem small and don't seem to impact the gameplay for the casual or moderate homeworld fan.Anyway, onto the review, I'll go in order of Homeworld and Homeworld 2 had to be cut short due to me running out of characters. [grumble grumble]Homeworld was an amazing experience to go through, and gave me a feeling a game hasn't given me in awhile. This is a sense of mystery and the feeling of being a small speck in the midst of outer space. An insignificant spec, just managing to survive. But as you go along, the largest foe opposing you who seem like an unstoppable force that will wipe you out in the blink of an eye. But you just bite at the small, weak appendages of this large creature until you (hopefully) become large enough to stand a chance.But as the game goes along, and you realise you're hatred of this foe is not alone, you end up becoming stronger, as you gain more and more victories, and you become something greater than what you started, you don't feel weak against your foe, you end up feeling like you can just make it.Now, for the gameplay of the game, the gameplay is very strategic, much more strategic than what I was expecting. You can't just throw your mighty battleships at the enemy and expect to win, because since you may of destroyed their first offensive, you're heavily crippled, and it just so happens that there are, admittedly smaller, but far scarier foes awaiting just outside the range of your sensors, and they are hungry. I find myself later in the game attempting to break off their fleet in chasing something small, but leading them where my ships lay, and I have the advantage by planning the whole thing in advance. Your experience might be different but I had a blast.Now for some memorable moments from my playthrough of the game, some spoilers.The first moment I can think of is the first attack on the foe (completely forgot their name, some federation). When we warp in, my battle relay guy(?) notifies me that the hostile fleet is right ahead. Here, I'm a bit scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because I saw what they can do, and even though its weakened, they still have a substantial fleet. He gave the order to exterminate the fleet. At this moment of time, I still see that fleat as an unstoppable force, and they had battlecruisers and I didn't. Did I mention I was scared? Anyway, I mass produced these vehicle extraction units (forgot the name) which basically steals ships in hopes of capturing one of the ships. However, it turned out that I overestimated the foe (which is what I always do, it's better to overestimate and crush your foe with overwhelming force them to not be prepared for a superior force) and I ended up destroying most of their ships, except for one. I then got this evil grin on my face as this carrier was trying to escape from me, I ordered my ships to shoot out the engines, and I sent in the extractors. I ended up stealing their carrier as a trophy, a claim of "I annihilated your force and now I'm using your ship against you" sort of fashion. That ship eventually became invaluable to the fleet, acting as a medical station for the smaller ships and as a transport bay for them as well. Protection from attack.The second moment I'll share is this moment when you enter a nebula and there is deadly radiation flooding the area. You had to plan your moves carefully to not have your ship's be dissolved in the radiation (a bit unrealistic but it's a videogame so I'll let it slide) I'm moving through this cloud and I spot a minelayer. This is the first one I encountered one, I quickly destroy it and think to myself, "Job well done, no mines! Onwards to glory!" but a little bit later, I found the mine field it set up, it crippled some of my most powerful ships, and when I'm getting my repair frigates ready, I spot 2 destroyers peek out from the nebula. At this point in time, I had about 3 destroyers, the carrier (the one I stole earlier) and a fleet of frigates. "Piece of cake" I thought to myself. Bad mistake, because with them, they had missile frigates that were staying JUST out of sight, but firing on my ships nonetheless. And whatever the hell that destroyer was made from, my whole fleet of 25 ish ships was completely and utterly obliterated by 5 ships and a few mines. Then I started planning out my path for the target, and I had an escort, and everything, finding small bands of these ships and crushing them under suprise.The third, and final moment I can share is the junkyard. During this level, you enter a creepy junkyard, with a bunch of gun platforms dotting the place, protecting...something...still don't know what it was. No biggy I thought, but something didn't feel right, so I sent my capital ships in with caution, and to obliterate the gun platform obviously. But after I sent them out, I started doing some micromanaging at base, when I heard "one of your ships have gone missing". "What do you mean, 'one of your ships have gone missing'? How the hell can you lose a capital ship?" I'm thinking to myself. then I look over, and I see the missing ship warp back into view, but it was hostile. I had no idea what was going on until I saw this one small-ish ship coming in, only known as the Junkyard Dog, and it was barreling straight for one of the capital ships. The it just snatches it and warped out at a becon. I was stunned, but also very♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥so I restarted the level. After about 3 ish restarts, I got very♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at this dog and after my attempts of sending small ships through the junkyard failed miserably, I got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and made ships that could freeze it. I had like 5 of them, so the dog couldn't escape. I had my whole fleet waiting nervously for any signs of the dog. And when my guard was low, it came within 1 km from one of my ships! I know, 1 kilometer seems far, but remember, these ships are several kilometers in length so that was WAY too close for comfort. I froze it and with all the might of my fleet, and about 10 minutes of continuous fire from all ships, I finally killed the dog. I was never so happy to kill a dog until now.After all the praise I gave for homeworld, you would think I would give homeworld 2 as much praise, but to be honest, it was a bit disappointing. I feel the collection is worth it for homeworld alone. So just buy it, and if you want to play homeworld 2, just do it. It's still enjoyable in a morbid way. Sadly, steam won't let me finish the review, because I have a lot of worlds for homeworld 2 that's not exactly flattering. But again, just buy it and see it for yourself. You have nothing to lose (Except for possibly your time) so just do whatever you feel is best.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
SummaryI love this game, but it has some serious growing up to do in the genre of Sci-Fi.One thing about this game that I love is the wide variety of ships we can choose from and also the ability to customize our ships to our liking. Now the one thing that saddens me the most is the fact the Frontier Developments basically stated that they player will never be able to pilot ships as big as Farragut which puts a dampers. One the greatest feelings in space theme games is piloting a capital class ship, commanding squadrons of fighters while laying massive firepower that turns the tide of a battle or defending the ship against ambush of fighters. Eve Online brought a never ending hunger for player driven wars between two player ran corporations or alliances over vast expansions of space in attempt to control the non-settled frontiers of space. There is also player built stations, player build fortifications, player held planets, player owned solar systems, and player owned shipyards that make it feels like the galaxy is alive. For such a vast open end game, it feels like there is very little purpose for the player except for tagging along for the ride, we barely shape the galaxy.Why Capital Ships Are Unobtainable?By limiting players ability to interact with your galaxy, you are faced with the outcome that players will not be able to do much in a vast open end world that you have created. The only thing that us players do have forward to look too is playing the vast variety of ships available in the game. When you deny two ships to the players who play, Frontier Developments are hurting their ability to be flexible in their approach. Basically you are putting a artificial block on the growth of ship variety by doing this, you can never build bigger than that single capital ship. Once players hit Corvette and Cutter, they can’t advance any further while NPC have Farragut and Majestic class ships that dwarf player owned ships. It isn’t because these ships are rare and limited in numbers, in-fact they are very common because you find them throughout all conflict zones regardless of where you are in the galaxy. We should be asking why capital ships are unobtainable when they are not unique or rare?Why Can’t Players Have Groups?Groups are so important in massive multiplayer online games, it connects players together and helps them do things that they can’t normally do alone. Look at Eve Online that is built around players working together, they achieve amazing and epic accomplishments that are a envy of thousands of players while being big enough to be featured in national news articles. This advertises the game in a way that no other game has achieved because players want to be a part of this and willing to dedicate years to achieving something. By offering the ability to own solar systems, stations, shipyards, and factions; they are not only giving room for this game to grow, they are creating a environment that will advertise itself and help the game community to grow. By letting players be able to shape and expand the galaxy, Frontier Development are basically making it easier to establish the world around the players as things evolve and grow. Why must you limit the expansion of the bubble to your time schedule?The Point?So basically what I am saying is, stop trying to force the galaxy to grow, let it grow on its own by giving the tools to the players. You can shape the basic story-line which players will follow without much of a issue, but once you are trying to micro-manage a galaxy of players, you will be limited severely to the point you will practically lose steam quicker. Players love the ability to shape, choose, and control their galaxy more than  tagging along for the ride with limited options to experience it. So do yourself a favor, be more flexible.Rating: 8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												I think my sentiment for this version of Homeworld echoes every single one who played the original: this game is a huge disappointment.I played the orginal Homeworld, Homeworld Cataclysm Homeworld 2 and countless mods of HW2. By far, Homeworld orginal is my favourite. The atmosphere, the feeling of panic when overwhelmed by enemies, the awe of the Graveyard... Homeworld itself was astounding. Even the music keeps you wrapped up in the HW universe; you really feel as though you are safeguarding the last of your kind with every little ship you capture or build.What has been done here is the story and script of Homeworld has been plopped into the Homeworld 2 engine, which is a completely different game. Different UI, different mapped controls, different AI.  HW2 is designed as a massive Space Battle RTS. Original Homeworld is a strategy game, but the emphasis is not always on battle; you are encouraged to use whatever strategy you need to get the better of the Taidan.The result? A very busy UI, many interfering visual elements and a flow of information completely unsuitable to the original Homworld story.What's worse is that the AI and control mechanics are awful. For example, any original HW player will tell you that the most fun strategy is capturing ships. In HW Remastered, this is completely broken. You can't just take a group of salvage corvettes with the correct number to capture, say, the Assault Frigates in Mission 3, Return to Kharak, and tell them to go capture. No, you have to pause, count the number of frigates, make a bunch of groups of 2 and tell each group to go capture ONE frigate. Totally ridiculous.All of this could be forgiven, it would be. And on top of this, the visuals aren't that fantastic. The textures and modelling are pretty bad by today's standard. The mod community had already done a fantastic job with several whole-game conversions for HW2... Now THESE are amazing, the attention to detail is crazy! Seems sad to think so little attention was paid to this.I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't get into it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												This is a remastered game from back in the day when RTS ruled the PC. Back in the day i used to love this game, unlike its competitors at the time you aren't fighting on a 2d plane but in an actual 3d environment. Given this is a space game you actually get a tactical advantage from attacking enemy ships from the top of bottom, so it added literally another dimension to the RTS genre. Another great feature of the game is you dont build a base, but maintained a fleet (think Battlestar Galactica), that fleet stays with you throughout the game. You have the mother ship that acts as production facility and when that is lost, its game over, all other ships can just be produced and captured. It adds a lot to the story.And the story that was told is great, for those of you who have never played it, i wont spoil it, but the story itself is kind of standard, but because you are with traveling with your fleet, you feel more connected to the story! And the best part is, that was how i remember it, and it all still holds true!! and now it looks great also. So i do recommend this game if you are into RTS games or really atmospheric games!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I nominated this for Best Singleplayer Story Narrative in the make your own category. For me, at the time this came out almost twenty years ago originally around the same time frame as the first Half Life game it had a story and background elements that unfolded and left a mark in your mind as you progressed through it.I still have the retail box cd version of this tucked away in a box in the closet with a bunch of other games. The thing about this one to me was because it was a Real Time Strategy game and not a First Person Shooter that took storytelling in an original idea at the time and framed it beautifully for the kind of game it is.The introduction sequences along with the first few levels is some of the best opening gameplay of any game I have ever played. It's why I nominated this because I still remember it to this day without having played it in so long until this remastered version came out.The writing is top notch, what I liked best about it was playing and hearing all the little combat chatter from units the choices of words that were used. Similar to how I love the combat chatter from the units in the StarCraft games.Can't say the same about a lot of games I have played. It also really helps if you are a big fan of the genre in both science fiction and real time strategy games. That old classic resource gathering base building model from the command and conquer games is used to a great effect in this game. At the time this game took that formula and put into 3D space, you no longer were scrolling across a 2D map. You played this game and had 360 degree awareness all around your mothership.The guys at Relic Entertainment came up with what's called the Sensors Manager for the game to handle that extra dimension and it was mind blowing when you saw it for the first time way back then. Because it was in real-time, you didn't wait for it to load up. You tapped the space bar and toggled it on and off at will, it's a common feature now but back in the early 2000's when you first used that it was fantastic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												While not perfect, there is little reason not to recommend this game. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------There are a few "unforgivable" issues which Gearbox needs to address sooner rather than later in terms of impacting an RTS game's playability. - Mouse Input lag. This is a no-no of the highest order in an RTS. The good news is that this is not an RTS that really relies heavily on your APM. but mouse accuracy is pretty high up there, especially if you are zoomed out to control the battlefield. - Going to black screen somewhat randomly during the campaign is hard to fathom - but based on it's behaviour with a dual monitor set up, I wouldn't be surprised if they are related. - Speaking of dual monitor, it has some very odd behaviour related to the mouse to pan and dual screen set up. I generally don't mouse pan the camera due to a Starcraft background, but it is a bit disconcerting to nudge the screen in one situation, then have the mouse leap off the game completely in another situation with no clear reason why. - Finally, and much like mouse input lag, a fairly unforgivable issue for an RTS player - inexplicable freezing. This is a very intermittant, seems not to impact the Frame rate which can get up to 260 if you let it, and stutters the game. The game doesn't ask all that much of the system resources that I could tell. GTX 970 with a processor that chilled right around 30% with some other software doing it's stuff... so I really can't explain the freezing. On a non-bug topic, I find the tutorial to be woefully weak, leaving out some really pretty key fundamentals of the game - like the importance of some of the utility ships. So not perfect, and needs to pretty significant patching and updating to get some of these fairly regrettable bugs handled. That all out the way... The remastering of this game is a rare case where the term remastered actually applies. The audio (which is original) has been significantly cleaned up, and the graphical overhaul is... remarkable. Additionally, some advancements between 1 and 2 were retroactively added to 1, including some of the significant UI improvements. Some old-time players will feel this is a detriment to the game, but I think first time players of the game will certainly appreciate the changes. The campaign is very good - but I have not played through enough of the campaign to offer thoughts on any changes they have made the story, so I assume there aren't too many, so I feel safe saying... the campaign is very good. The game difficulty varies, during the campaign, between easy enough, and well... not easy at all. You will find the instructions for some of the objectives are a touch vague (see the point earlier about the tutorial deficiencies and say ... salvaging a larger ship), but the pace of the game is not such that you can't figure out most everything on the fly. There is, as I recall, some level of dynamic difficulty added - so that you can't build up a powerful fleet before the mission starts.The game is lacking it's multiplayer in any real way right now - though its in beta for a steam implementation. All in all, a pretty stunning "remaster" of what is still a top notch RTS  that I do recommend, but offer a few caveats. 1) If you are a big fan of the homeworld series, be ready for changes in the remaster you may not entirely appreciate - but you do get a digital version of the originals so that's probably worth the cash right there. 2) If you don't want to deal with the bugs, wait for some patches before you buy3) It is a remaster - so some old school game design elements are clearly in force, if you are looking for a slick reimagining of the RTS genre with a sci fi theme and new UI and design innovations, check out Grey Goo instead. twitch.tv/sanlumiere

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Well well well....it seems that homeworld has finally made it back onto the main gaming stream at last, thank you gear box software. Onto what you all want to hear however, how does it play? Well then lets break this beast down.Age:Well lets face facts, homeworld one came out in the summer of 1999, and its sequel came out in the fall of 2003, so having said that, I bought both of these bad boys when they came out. I was so very young, and I was into all sorts of RTS games at the time. Command and Conquer, Starcraft, Warcraft, Red Alert, and Tiberian Sun, so I loved all RTS. To that point, this game destroyed all of them.Gameplay:Well since Gearbox was so very forward thinking, this game comes with a pretty awesome multiplayer, however its still in beta, and there are still some persistant glitches here and there. The campaign on the other hand is a differnet matter, long gone is the ability to choose between the Kushaan and the Tidann when starting the campaigns, you can only play the Kushaan (the mother ship race that is pictured on the box). While this is not a big thing, I was more of a fan of the Tidann mothership as well as the look of their fighters, however this is a small gripe. This game suffers from most RTS problems about missions, the curse of variety. What I mean by that is the pure fact that not ever mission is going to be, "Warp in, look around, fight baddies, then warp to the next mission." Some missions have you doing different things, and some of these things tend to slow the pacing down just a little bit. This is the only complaint, this game has brought me to tears many times as a child, the music, the atomsphere, everything is just spot on. Graphics:The first game looked amazing back in the day, this time around it just looks eye bleeding amazing, I could not ask for anything more. Also the cutscenes are still pretty awesome, and now that they are redone with some glorious 1080p resolution, they look even better. Think of the cutscenes like reading and animated comic book, if that sounds confusing then you will understand when you play the game. Controls:These controls are a little different than your standard RTS game, since you can move in three planes it makes controlling a bit different. Using the mouse works well, but to move freely you need to use the keyboard as well. It does take a little time to get the hang of things, but a pro vs a novice will only be able to look and move things faster in the end, it will not make or break gameplay.Overall: 10/10If you are a fan of RTS games then this thing should be in your cart before you finish reading my review, its such fun to play, and not to mention the pacing of multiplayer is both laid back and pure tense action. Get it, love it, and just enjoy the sin out of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												While not perfect, there is little reason not to recommend this game. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------There are a few "unforgivable" issues which Gearbox needs to address sooner rather than later in terms of impacting an RTS game's playability. - Mouse Input lag. This is a no-no of the highest order in an RTS. The good news is that this is not an RTS that really relies heavily on your APM. but mouse accuracy is pretty high up there, especially if you are zoomed out to control the battlefield. - Going to black screen somewhat randomly during the campaign is hard to fathom - but based on it's behaviour with a dual monitor set up, I wouldn't be surprised if they are related. - Speaking of dual monitor, it has some very odd behaviour related to the mouse to pan and dual screen set up. I generally don't mouse pan the camera due to a Starcraft background, but it is a bit disconcerting to nudge the screen in one situation, then have the mouse leap off the game completely in another situation with no clear reason why. - Finally, and much like mouse input lag, a fairly unforgivable issue for an RTS player - inexplicable freezing. This is a very intermittant, seems not to impact the Frame rate which can get up to 260 if you let it, and stutters the game. The game doesn't ask all that much of the system resources that I could tell. GTX 970 with a processor that chilled right around 30% with some other software doing it's stuff... so I really can't explain the freezing. On a non-bug topic, I find the tutorial to be woefully weak, leaving out some really pretty key fundamentals of the game - like the importance of some of the utility ships. So not perfect, and needs to pretty significant patching and updating to get some of these fairly regrettable bugs handled. That all out the way... The remastering of this game is a rare case where the term remastered actually applies. The audio (which is original) has been significantly cleaned up, and the graphical overhaul is... remarkable. Additionally, some advancements between 1 and 2 were retroactively added to 1, including some of the significant UI improvements. Some old-time players will feel this is a detriment to the game, but I think first time players of the game will certainly appreciate the changes. The campaign is very good - but I have not played through enough of the campaign to offer thoughts on any changes they have made the story, so I assume there aren't too many, so I feel safe saying... the campaign is very good. The game difficulty varies, during the campaign, between easy enough, and well... not easy at all. You will find the instructions for some of the objectives are a touch vague (see the point earlier about the tutorial deficiencies and say ... salvaging a larger ship), but the pace of the game is not such that you can't figure out most everything on the fly. There is, as I recall, some level of dynamic difficulty added - so that you can't build up a powerful fleet before the mission starts.The game is lacking it's multiplayer in any real way right now - though its in beta for a steam implementation. All in all, a pretty stunning "remaster" of what is still a top notch RTS  that I do recommend, but offer a few caveats. 1) If you are a big fan of the homeworld series, be ready for changes in the remaster you may not entirely appreciate - but you do get a digital version of the originals so that's probably worth the cash right there. 2) If you don't want to deal with the bugs, wait for some patches before you buy3) It is a remaster - so some old school game design elements are clearly in force, if you are looking for a slick reimagining of the RTS genre with a sci fi theme and new UI and design innovations, check out Grey Goo instead. twitch.tv/sanlumiere

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												There seems to only be one major flaw in this game. The AI...I will not pretend that it is as bad as Rome II at release, but its not exactly amazing. Even if you put it in aggresive tactics in expert mode it still doesn't pose much of a threat. It just builds a bunch of carriers then sends wave after wave of the same group of units at you. The AI also won't use hyperspace to any effect and will often use Gravwells to disable there own fighters even if they have the advantage.This thankfully doesn't affect the singleplayer campaign as the enemy is scripted but the player vs CPU is not very challenging.Despite all of this Homeworld Remastered is still a great game and I would still recomend it to you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Homeworld is one of those exceedingly rare gems in gaming that seem to get everything just right. The story is set in a rich universe with interesting races and characters. The gameplay is fun and complex without being complicated.The sound design is captivatingly immersive. The visuals are absolutely stellar. Its rare enough these days to find a game that looks, sounds and plays great all at once, but Homeworld's genius is in how well all those apects are so masterfully integrated... What does that mean? Well, without spoiling the game for you, imagine loading into a new stage:...Your fleet just emerged from hyperspace. Judging from the earlier cutscene, you are heading to the outskirts of the system, a fact now illustrated by how distant the sun has become in the 3D space. You start to feel isolated, a feeling not eased by how haunting the in game music has become. Fleet command just issued an objective: Send a ship to investigate an anomaly. In response you open up your sensors manager to get your bearings. You find some resource asteroids and send your collectors to harvest them. The collectors reply with acknowledgments, you zoom in closer to marvel at how well detailed and utilitarian the design of the resource collector is. You hear fleet command reporting that they can research a new ship model. You glance at your resource unit indicator and calculate that you can do the research and build one new ship or forgo the research and build five more weaker but more manuverable ships. You decide to go for quality than quantity. You decide to split your fleet into two groups, one to go forth and investigate the anomaly and another to stand guard and protect the Mothership. As you monitor your fleets you notice that the music is changing, something bad is going to happen! you feel your palms getting sweaty as you issue commands to your ships, strikecraft to aggressive stance, set claw formation. You open your sensors manager, you see two large groups of red pings heading towards your fleets. Your uneasiness changes into fear as you realise how outnumbered you are and wonder if your fleet will make it... Homeworld is filled with amazing moments like that, moments where you will be immersed in the game; its tension, its conflict and  in how real the stakes feel. As one tactical mistake can end in strategic failure and your losses will carry over as resources are finite and your fleet is persistent. If you lose a ship, its gone forever. This makes all the defeats all the more painful and all the victories you will achieve all the more cathartic and meaningful.To sum up; get this game! you will not regret it!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												I write this review from the perspective of someone who did not play the original HW, or its sequel HW2. Negative reviews by old-timers seem to focus on gameplay changes from HW1 due to that Gearbox based both HW1 and HW2 in their remastered versions largely on HW2...but the lack of 'tactics' and such didn't faze me much. I also didn't rate it negatively because of it being released (I had pre-ordered) with some nagging bugs which, among others, meant that I couldn't even get in for a week after a mis-guided patch. My 'thumbs down' is because I much disliked two core game mechanics which go back to HW1, into which I get after one paragraph on what I liked.The game has a lot going for it - it's pretty, the music is nice, and the setting and writing is suitably dark scifi. I enjoyed simply watching resource harvesting; little details like the related animations show that the developers cared about making this look good. When I got to battle, I found the battles engaging and fun as well...but here's:PROBLEM 1:You don't really get to battle. In the game, you receive a spacecraft that can capture opposing spacecraft. And it's very good at it. If you're the optimizing, obsessive type (I am), this means that you build this craft and essentially nothing but this craft (to its limit of 14, but that's plenty), then go capture (almost) the entire opposing fleet. My battles looked as follows: (a) I park spacecraft I already own far away so they don't accidentally as much as shoot at the enemy, and then (b) I go hunting for the incoming ships, which, once captured, I (c) park with the rest of my fleet. That's not very epic...but the following I liked even less -PROBLEM 2:Scaling of the strength of your enemy to your own strength. You carry over your fleet from prior missions. In an early mission (MINOR SPOILER), you enter the mission seeing the enemy attack six giant habitats which hold the rest of your race. I first entered this mission facing, I believe, 4-5 enemy ships, all larger than those you can have at that time. From a roleplaying perspective, it made me sad that I could only save about 2/3 of my remaining race...so I went back, this time diligently using what I describe under Problem 1 to amass a rather large fleet before this mission. I enter feeling good about myself...then see TEN or so big ships hammer away at my habitats, far enough away that, this time, they killed 2/3 of them before I even reached them. In fact, I think I saved 1/6, even though I abandoned the 'capture only' strategy I mention above and both hammered them and captured what I could.That's just stupid. I read in forum posts regarding the original, that the cool winning strategy in the olden days was to completely dismantle your fleet at the end of a mission (you get almost all the money back; and if you captured the ships for free, it's even better), then, as soon as the next mission starts, re-build your fleet.  As the game scales to your strength, you then face puny enemies in each mission - easily captured all, added to your fleet, dismantled with it at the end of the mission, and rebuilt at the start of the next...This completely destroys any kind of immersion. I'm not a fan of scaling-to-your-strength games anyway as that lack of immersion is almost inevitable.A shame.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												I never played Homeworld back when it came out, I was playing Starcraft and Warcraft.  Now I'm wishing I had.  Being that I never played the original, I don't have some of the complaints that the veterans do with the changes made due to importing HW1 into the HW2 engine.  I understand why they did it and it doesn't bother me.  It shouldn't bother you either.  The game is a blast to play, the storytelling is amazing and it really looks and sounds beautiful.  Yes, there are bugs at the moment (release week) but Gearbox has said on their forums they are collecting feedback for future patches to address many of the issues the veterans have (if possible within the constraints of the engine) and should have the first bug patch ready less than a week after launch.  So long as Gearbox lives up to that, everyone should be happy.  Is it worth $35?  If you like space RTS games (of which there are pitiful few available) then yes.  If you liked Sins of a Solar Empire but wanted a campaign for it, then this is what you've always dreamed of.  Get it today.
