content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												Homeworld Remastered looks great, but I wouldn't call it a polished (or even finished) product. If you're reading this review, you're doing more due diligence than I did. I saw "User Reviews: Very Positive" and "$17.49," and went for it. Ten hours of playtime later, my refund request has been denied and my local content has been deleted. I really really wanted to enjoy HWRC, but I can't. There are a LOT of bugs. I never played the original Homeworld 2, but apparently in converting HW1 to the HW2 engine, lots of unit behavior changed (or just went away), and unit balance is totally different. Strike craft are nearly useless now. You can't select-box-repair with a support frigate. Formations are more of a suggestion than an order. But the number one show-stopper for me is that resource harvesters will just ... stop. For no reason. I'll be on the other side of the map, micromanaging something, and notice that there is NO $$$ coming in. I'll focus back on my mothership and 5 out of 6 harvesters will just be stuck in space. This is unacceptable. I might come back to this game if Gearbox releases a comprehensive bug fix patch.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												*Gregorian Chants fill the expanse of space as the light of a distant star filters through the red gas clouds of the local nebula*For those of you who played Homeworld or Homeworld 2...you know why you should buy this.  For those of you who have never had the priveledge...this game is still considered by many experts of the RTS genre to be the defining RTS experience.  One of the most polished, best story-driven RTS games ever made, AND the sequel.It is a space saga...an epic journey of a people to reclaim their homeworld...and then...an aeon later, to flee said homeworld before destruction rains down upon them.It is...the most beautiful RTS I have ever seen.   Even before the remaster, I would've said so.  Now...it is updated in every way one could hope for, without ANY changes to the core mechanics.  The story is the same, but the voice acting is all-new, from the same actors who voiced the original.  The graphics are modernized, and the game feels...fresh.  It feels as it should;  essentially unchanged, but better than ever before!I recommend this game to anyone who seriously wishes to give the RTS genre a genuine try.   If you don't like this, you probably won't like many other RTS games. On the other hand; If you like RTS games, this will likely be the jewel of your collection.

												alright, before I begin I want to point out that I played the originals a long time ago. So when This came out, I went on a nostalgia trip. But, I will try my best to be fair in this.First off, They have done an amazing job with the graphical updates. the game is beautiful. In the matches, your opponent can infinitely go up or down. with a movement system that they have, that makes pursueing them a hassle.The actual combat is very satisfying, however. when a missile impacts your battlecruiser, there's an actual hole where it hit. so as the battles progress, your ships that have been around for a long time look increasingly battered and bruised. That's a very nice touch.At the end of it, I would definitely recommend this.-----------------Oh, I almost forgot. This has a launcher that allows you to play the classic version of both games. That is a seriously nice touch.

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												For those who wanted to play Homeword 1 with a new coat of paint and maybe a some UI (User Interface) improvements, this ain't it. Instead what you get is a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥mod of the Homeworld 1 capaign for Homeworld 2. Almost nothing works as expected. The UI looks awful, feels awful and is in most ways no improvement over the original one. There is a reason there was no Homeworld 3.The graphics look good. They did a fine job remodeling the ships. Unfortunately with none of the actual behavior modeled, the ships feel like empty husks. Turrets of corvettes don't seem to independently track and shoot enemy ships like they used to, and when big ships fire their giant cannons, there is no recoil on the turret. Everything feels like a 3d-Max model making pew pew sounds.Formations don't work. Instead of the giant walls of capital ships surrounded by spheres of corvettes and wings of fighters you get to choose between a few different amorphous blobs and any time the ships move or see an enemy, the blog disintegrates.Battles don't work. If you follow a fighter, you see that it couldn't hit a side of a mothership if it was docked inside it, making fights between fighters and corvettes take forever. On the other hand, assault frigates swat fighters out of the sky like so many flies. It's obvious Gearbox didn't even slightly try to match the balance of the original game.Salvaging enemy ships doesn't work. Or one could argue that in all their bugginess they work too well. Just make a few of these and capture the whole enemy fleet: fighters, corvettes, everything, and you are done. Just don't build any of your own ships because they will shoot at the captured ships. You see, Homeworld 2 had boarding frigates that captured the targeted ships in place, so the engine doesn't actually support salvage ships that take their prey back into the mothership, and it's obvious that Gearbox didn't want to make any actual changes to the engine, or do any testing.Homeworld 1 classic works. Too bad you don't get any graphical updates or UI features while playing it. Although, it's probably for the best since Gearbox doesn't seem to care about the things that made this classic great. Homeworld 1 is still a fantastic game and doesn't look nearly as dated as they make it look in their comparison videos. All they needed to do was these things:- Use the original physics and game simulation engine.- Update the 3d rendering engine to support modern resolutions and shadows. Although if that was too hard, updating just the models and textures would have been fine too.- Increase the simulation steps per second to at least 30.- Add time control.Instead of doing these things, they made some nice looking ship models for Homeworld 2. Hence the turd that is Homeworld Remastered.

Posted: July 21, 2015
												The remaster for HW1 is absolutely gorgeous. Unfortunately in so doing they gutted the deep AI system for the strike craft.  So one of the most engaging aspects of the original game is gone and it makes the early missions where you more or less rely on strike craft tedious.  I'm disappointed with the port on a lot of levels, but then I remember it's from Gearbox so I'm sure this means that Borderlands 3 will be better off. I was on the fence on whether to vote yes or no on this considering the original games are ported in their unaltered form.  I'd recommend getting it on sale just to experience the classics (so long as you don't mind the graphics or the UI being a little rough.)  Otherwise I'd say no, give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												I'll be up front and not wax prose when not needed: This is one of the most stunningly beautiful games I've ever seen. I loved Homeworld when it first came out, and hotly anticipated this release. There is no disappointment whatsoever. The 3 dimensional space combat is gorgeous and occurs to a breathtaking scale. The balance is still incredible. There are a few levels that you kindof have to game still, and sometimes the mouse goes crazy, but this game still remains possibly the most satisfying RTS I've ever played. It is engaging and relaxing all at once. I cannot recommend this game enough. Get it now, you're actually getting 2 games that will bring you to tears at once.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Homeworld Remastered is genuinely a breath of fresh air in the RTS genre all over again. Gearbox have done a fantastic job of reviving this classic series of 3DRTS action, with a beta multiplayer to boot. At the time of writing this, the multiplayer needs severe balancing and bug fixing, but it shows great potential. All four races (kush, taiidan, hiigaran, vaygr) are now all available in the multiplayer, however the homeworld 1 races need the most adjustments.The remastered collection runs in the Homeworld 2 engine, with revamped graphics and the formations of homeworld 1 are now implemented into the game (however I don't think they function as gearbox intended, most likely will need fixing).The collection also comes with the classic editions of both games if you feel like a trip down nostalgia lane, or if you just want to see the difference between the original games and the remastered editions.If you enjoyed the original games, or have just come across this for the first time, I highly recommend purchasing it.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												One of my all-time favorite RTS games plays just how I remember it used to! A real gem back in its day, the "Classic" game manged to age exceptionally well and still looks good. But now that it graphics have  been improved and brought up to modern graphics standards, complete with UI optimizations that reduce screen clutter; one's view of Homeworld's epic space battles as they unfold is unfettered and rendered in sharp and breathtaking detail. It's absolutely gorgeous to behold and there hasn't been an RTS game to match its theme and style in 16 years! If you're an RTS fan and you haven't had a chance to give this title a shot in the past, you owe it to yourself to pick this legendary title up now! This old gem has been brought to a high and lustrous polish!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I am very pleased to get a working copy of HW on my system again and to play it at 4k UHD.  Unfortunetly, I have crashed a dozen times, had weird graphical glitches that resolved themselves with lowering graphical settings and restarting the client repeatedly and the story line missions are buggy as all get out.  MAKE SURE TO SAVE BEFORE JUMPING TO THE NEXT SYSTEM.  And saving between major events helps too.  If you restart a mission for whatever reason, or it crashed, using the auto-generated saves the mission often won't flag completion, you'll miss research and you will be very frustrated.All in all, the graphics are beautiful, controls intuitive, and the game nostolgic.  With all the bugs, this REMASTERing feels more like a visually pretty but unstable beta product.  They may fix the problems over time, but, I am quite dissappointed that my '99 experience of HW was more stable then this remake.*EDIT* On Mission 12 of HW1:RMI have reached a Can Not Continue bug where the mission objectives are not completing and the cloaked ships are not spawning.  HW1:RM is much too easy and not giving the same replability of Classic.  Lacking controls, UI, tactics and difficulty. Very disillusioned.HW2:RM feels much more integrated and even prettier then it was originally. I would suggest waiting for Steam Summer Sale and get HW:RM for 50%.  Hopefully they will have fixed the bugs, problems and multiplayer by then.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I bought, played, and enjoyed Homeworld when it came out and Homeworld 2 as soon as it came out. Excited about the remaster? Yes!Happy with it? No ♥♥♥♥ing way.Homeworld 1 Remastered...Pro's: the graphics have been updated.Con's: special abilities are ♥♥♥♥ed (salvaging? useful repairs?), pathfinding is rubbish, the AI is usless, for some reason resources have increased tenfold. Formations barely work, the ships sort of move and then go YOLO as soon as an enemy ship appears. Most of the keyboard commands don't work. They have used the HW2 engine, so none of the fabulous features of HW1 have remained, but at the same time, none of the features of HW2 have been implemented.I bought this remaster without reading any reviews or criticisms, DESPITE having the original game installed and recently played. I never once thought that a 'remaster' would LOSE FEATURES. It plays like a buggy, poor thought out beta version. It has none of the easy playability of the 1999 release.If this review is unclear, I would like to state: there are very, very few gaming experiences that have been as disappointing as this.

												This is a classic remastered! Sure its buggy but what the heck do you expect? They basically took and old classic and added some modern upgrades to it. Almost similar to adding modern parts to an old classic car, you are going to have your "bugs" and other issues, but in time you find them, fix them and soon its purring like a kitten (or you run out of money).  I look at it this way. Gearbox brought back this game to give some joy and nostalgia to those that loved this game (and of course make some money). And I am sure that it will be running right in time (fingers crossed). I still enjoy this classic even with the bugs. If you have played the game in the past, I would recommend you to turn a blind eye to the nay say'rs. Go ahead and get the game if you have the itch or wait for the sale.

Posted: March 15, 2015
												Bugged pathfinding, bugged AI, bugged camera control, bugged mission event trigger.The game looks beautiful but that is the only positive point. Besides that there are- bugged events that don't trigger and won't allow you to advance in the mission- bugged AI that makes your ships crash and explode into the asteroids they were meant to destroy- bugged pathfinding that doesn't allow you to attack a target because the move command is issued way off into the distance instead of where the contact marker is represented.- probably the most anoying bug of them all is the camera control. You can't move up or down relative to the system plane because the movement controls will freeze and no further input is registered. Frustrating remake of a good old game. My review is only based on the Homeworld 1 game, because I didn't have the heart to try and see what they broke about Homeworld 2 yet.I wouldn't even think of spending money on this title as it is right now.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												I'm bitterly disappointed in this remaster of Homeworld 1.  Formations are pretty much ignored and tactics...who knows?  The UI is totally revamped, which is for the most part ok.  But the basic gameplay is altered for the worse. The "classic" version of Homeworld is exactly that, no upgraded graphics or models.  This was a complete waste of my money.  I may try to get a refund.  I have the original disk from when the game originally launched in 1999.  This remaster adds nothing better.  The remaster just doesn't have the fidelity that the original deserves.  And I was so excited to get this.  What a waste.

												Remastered is one of those words that the entertainment industry is making a spirited attempt to define as "prettier but shallower” a lot of fun mechanics have been stripped out and the difficulty curve not reassessed to reflect that, which keeps the campaign slightly off the tone of the original and renders the skirmish mode a flop.The art is lovingly crafted and I have no bones to pick with that side of the team. content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Wow. What a delightful surprise. I played HW1 casually when I was a kid, but when I picked up this remaster as an adult, the graphics, voice acting, and soundtrack blew me away.Never have I played an RTS and experienced so much beauty that I just had to sit there and gawk at the screen for extended periods of time. I found myself locking the camera on fighters and rooting for them in massive battles. After a while, I felt like I was spending the night stargazing and admiring the beauty of the cosmos, not playing a video game. In a break in the action, I thought to myself, "I think I just had a spiritual experience in a video game..."

												I've played Homeworld and Homeworld 2 several times since their release. With Remastered's release, I find myself fighting the interface more than the enemy.  Certain actions, such as repair, or capture, refuse to target mulitple targets as you could with both of the original games. One-command sending of a swarm of salvage corvettes against a pair of destroyers was one of my joys, which simply can't be done now, to say nothing of the removal of Military Parade formation (an easy way of getting your fleet back under control when it's all scattered) I have repeatedly lost simple battles simply because the revamped interface is so... difficult to work with, compared to the original games. It is non intuitive, unlike the original.Skip this iteration until it's been patched, possibly even a few times.

number of helpful: 38 of 77 people (49%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I'm a diehard Homeworld fan, but this "Remastered" collection is very disappointing so far in playing my first several hours.  It is riddled with bugs, even more than the original (which is saying something).  Even with Gearbox saying they rewrote the engine, I see some extremely similar issues to the old game.  I can deal with minor change such as ship costs (and apparently Fuel is no longer a resource for Strike craft), and I'm still a fan of the plodding pace and solitary atmosphere, but the issues I'm going to talk about make the price tag of this remake painful to have forked over.  It's amazing this was released in this state and I'm having a hard time believing that much work really went into it.Here is my current laundry list after playing for about 7 hours today (release day):Hotkeys and information.  Some ships have "special attacks"; good luck finding out what those are or whether they exist, until you find the hotkey for it and try it.  There are no more detailed info panes for ships now, at least that I can find, so you have very limited info on anything's capabilities.  Also, this game causes some kind of interference with system hotkeys... including preventing my ability to use in-game Shadowplay, which is what I use for videos and streaming.  UI for units currently selected is very small, slow and klutzy.Queueing up multiple Research ship pieces will result in only one being built.Capturing and Salvaging problems.  Salvage Corvettes will fight over the same pieces, following each other around.  You cannot tell a group of them to capture a group of enemies either; you must pick them one at a time.  Friendly units will happily open fire on any unit you have in tow, even though it is on its way to the mothership to be assimilated and poses no threat.  Harvesters will also fight with them over carried salvage.  Salvage Corvettes or Harvesters carrying salvage will clump up and prevent each other from delivering anything to a Carrier or Mothership.  Likewise as above, you cannot target groups of salvage to gather with a group of ships; it must be one at a time, or waiting for Harvesters to try and do it on their own.  Finally, a personal gripe; why do they make it hard to distinguish what ships you own after capturing them?  At least they could have changed the color of the exhaust trails or something to make it easier to know what's happening in a battle.Pathfinding.  There are clipping issues and other bits of forgiveable things, but sometimes ships of any kind will lose their minds and do a dance in place until you figure out what direction they need to get free.  When you need groups of ships to engage combat quickly, sometimes they will spend 5-15 seconds trying to recover their formation before they'll engage.  Also, as with the original game, rarely (but comically, at least if you're not playing) a ship you ordered to move (whether part of a group or not) will decide to go off in some completely random direction and will not stop.  Ever.Asteroids.  Oh god, these are horrible... This was always a frustrating level, but now when destroying asteroids, they fade away for a moment, and then slowly create a few dangerous new ones that can't be shot at right away.  The biggest problem there is that you can't select these new ones to attack half the time; if you try, sometimes your idiot ships will just start driving straight into them.  Ships will do no defensive or proactive fire whatsoever against the asteroids.  To boot, when you start the mission, if your carrier ships are on Auto-launch, all your little brittle ships will line up in perfect parade order to get themselves killed.  Finally, when you lose the first dodge-the-asteroid mission, the screen fades to black, but the rest of the game keeps running.  No end screen or anything like that, and you can hear your actions on the keyboard still having effects.Drones.  These little morons will kamikaze into your own ships whenever you activate or deactivate them.  Oh by the way, how do you activate them, you say?  Must be a button or something convenient, right?  Nope:  It's Ctrl-Shift-D.  And you'd never know unless you went through the game options for the key bindings.  I also had issues getting a group of Drone Frigates to respond to this command when deactivating; I often had to do it for each one individually.Repairing.  Pathfinding issues aside, it doesn't appear any Repair Corvettes or Frigates will repair some corvettes that you've captured from the enemy, at least some of the time.  Groups of repair ships will also have the same arguing issues between themselves as Salvage Corvette/Harvesters when trying to patch up the same ship.I'm going to keep playing it to get my money's worth, but I'm afraid I can't recommend this remake at all, as compared to just going out there and getting free or almost-free copies of the original games.  The graphics are much prettier but they aren't mind-blowing for 15 years of progress, and certainly not worth this price.  I'll probably find more issues as I go along, but I'll try to stay optimistic.

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												The "remastered" part is well done. Graphics, UI and all that, but I do not remember this many obvious bugs in the old Homeworld.- My research vessel for example is completly invulnerable. I just had 30 enemy fighters and a Heavy Cruiser (!) firing at it and it just kept repairing itself at about 40% health.- Then there is this shrieking sound that seems to come from Corvette and Frigate class ships. It stays even if you move away. Pausing and continueing the game is a workarround.- Captured Taiidan carriers are somehow unable to build anything. Capturing them is semi-useless that way.- Captured ships seem to play the lottery when it comes to their paintjobs. Some stay in Taiidan-yellow while others shine in Kushan-grey. (Edit: I even got one with pink stripes. YMCA-Cruiser!)And this is just Homeworld 1 to about half the missions. None of it is totally gamebreaking, like CTDs or crashes, but it shows a rather unpolished release.Gearbox also couldn't keep their hands off changing things. For example, Fighters don't require fuel anymore, making the Khadesh fuel ships obsolete. While the reasoning behind this is debateable (probably for HW 1&2 multiplayer compatibility), they were somehow unable to fix lacks in the user commands, for example letting Repair Corvettes guard a group of Salvage Corvettes so that they pick targets to repair automatically. This was okay 15 years ago, but today it feels really really annoying to have to micromanagement everything yourself instead of enjoying the broader strategy game in a true three-dimensional environment.Edit: Okay, now that I played through Homeworld 1 I can only say I'm shocked. This is a typical Gearbox game. The beginning is alright and due to the story events epic, but after about half the game it becomes a static "move there and jump". Its like the enemy AI is turned off. At the end I had 7 Heavy Cruisers, not of them built, and also 12 Destroyers. And guess what, the Taiidan rebels gifted me two more, like it wasn't easy enough yet.It was said the enemy fleet scales with what the player has, so I was hoping for an epic battle at the end. What I got was 3 enemy Heavy Cruisers. You can guess how epic that was.Another AI shutdown happend at the giant hyperspace inhibitor 2 missions before the finale. There are three jumpgates which you are supposed to destroy, because they'd send reinforcements otherwise. Thing is, there are no reinforcements, EXCEPT when you go for the gates. But then you are already there to destroy whatever comes through. If you leave the gates in peace, you can do your thing without the AI trying to stop you.This was the easiest RTS I've ever played in 20 years since Dune 2, simply because the AI does absolutly nothing. Combined with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying sound bug, Homeworld Remastered 1 is a complete waste of time!

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Much has been written about the improved graphics in the game. The screenshots speak for themselves. But, unfortunately, apart from enchanced graphics there are few positive moments to notice.The in-game speech seems to be recorded anew. I liked Makaan's voice. Fleet Command and Cpt. Soban are good, too. Karan is a bit… not like herself. But you won't probably notice that. Planet Killers theme from the last HW2 mission I've been anticipating the most is just absent. All the other aspects of sound and music are ok.Cutscenes are renedered in 1080p and look just awesome. But the in-game video player is implemented poorly: horrifying lags are obvious, while Media Player Classic plays the same smoothly even at x4 speed, let alone at normal.That is all for the good part. Now the bad part.First, despite nice textures, all the animations and VFx are left as it was. No new interesting additions (such as docking bays holding grip of resource collectors while unloading resource units or a destroyer losing a part of hull being heavily damaged). The repair beams and welding flashes stay as they were, while the soul craves for something more spectacular and immersive. Some of capital ships just don't fit the Mothership docking bay, going through textures. The Junkyard Dog turns ships in space as if they were made of near-weightless thin indestructible cardboard!. Hiigaran miners dock "through" Vaygr refineries, piercing the solid metal with antennas. Damage model is exactly as it was in Homeworld 2 — weird and unimpressive. And so on. Nothing positive has been done here since the Classics.Procedure of taking a "clean" screenshot is spectacular. To do that, you must manually disable all the HUD elements and deselect all ships, and having taken a screenshot set everything back as it was. All in all, nearly 10 key presses are necesarry to make a screenshot.As the game is about playing, not watching, and the Homeworld series is a thrilling experience to play through, in 20-30 minutes you will completely forget about graphics and concentrate all efforts and attention on gameplay.Hotkeys map seems to remain at the initial state. Most keystrokes are 2 or 3 keys combinations, scattered all over the keyboard without pretty much structuring. Learning and using those is a piano challenge. Nothing has been done to improve the keyboard controls.The campaign felt hopelessly easy. Closer to the end of the game (each one) the resource pool grows to 6-digit magnitude. That causes "why don't I build a full fleet of these and try them on something hopelessly well defended" thoughts. The overall state of the campaing indicates that by the time of release no one of the developers had taken a notepad and made a full playthrough of the campaign, marking bugs. When the junkyard Dog at Karos snatches a ship, you are supposed to lose contact with it, but you do not. The ships are supposed to be disabled after that, but sometimes they are not. Sometimes the Dog just tries to place the second ship to where the first is located, thus getting stuck. The Karos Proximity sensors Net is composed of freshly-painted sensors with Hiigaran insignia on them.... I have spotted a swarm of such mistakes during the playthrough.Enemy AI can make a grown man cry. No cooperation between ships is observed, and any signs of intellectual activity within the enemy ranks seem absent. Sending frigates wave after wave into the same minefield is just an example of a typical AI routine. The multiplayer AI seemed a bit better to me. In campaign there is none.Ship behavior is untouched (or even wasted a little). Single corvettes are ineffective (due to special placement of their turrets). That concerns all other ship types as well, so the ships with high coverage ratio are the most powerful ones.  Optimal attack patterns or any means to assign them manually are absent: a bomber can grind a resource collector just standing in one place, but instead it will move at max speed, and on the second run won't shot a single round because of asteroids blocking the shot. So, fighters and corvettes are a pity to watch at (especially single ones, with no squads and poor coverage). Whenever a ship escapes to safety through Hyperspace, rest assured: all your forces will target the enemy base to avenge the humiliation. Repair corvettes and minelayers will go in the lead, as the most agressive and eager to fight. The Gehenna border outpost will be as tough a target for a bomber aqs before: the start of the attack run is a fixed radius, the end is hear the enemy hull. So, the length of the run is negligible here and no real damage will be done. And that is instead of standing and grinding the target. There are worse things. Sometimes resource collectors just get stuck in place cutely blinking the engines instead of mining. Sometimes one of the ships boosts to 4000 speed or so and goes darting to the enemy lines or making enormous circles. My opponent once said his collecors are stuck inside one another and unable to move. Sometimes two corvettes try to repair each other, so they can't dock and go waltzing up to the uppermost boung of the map.  Gravitation Wells do not affect Vaygr corvettes, and Assault fighters had the kamikaze damage compared to a full-sized frigate each (has been corrected on 05-03-2015)The user interface. The only thing I did not expect of it is to get this much worse. The largest button on the screen is "Menu" — the button to be used 5-10 times in total. The next one in size toggles sensor view and is never used, as it is bound to the Space key (which is extremely convenient). Right under it is an enormous control group panel that does nothing. Fleet build queue reacts poorly (especially the pause button) and takes 3 keystrokes to open (3 more whenever a build-capable ship is built or lost). The lower right corner is occupied by never-used basic action commands, such as Attack or Move.  Everything listed above and to be listed below is to be scaled manually: extremely small on dtfault and clumsy and self-intersected on larger scales. Build and Research queues provide as few useful information as possible, and have to be scrolled due to the command panel below. Selection and commands do not work near UI objects, selection mechanism is suboptimal, so in combat situations the UI is bound to fail you constantly. Building 50 fighters take 50 clicks. 50 more whenever you change your mind. Overall element placement inUI and credits sequence indicate it has probably been done by a secondary school boy in exchange for a day off school. There is (maybe was corrected on 19-03-2015) a place where one of the names was covered with the white frame around a picture. I haven't even started a talk about possible improvements of the original: robust and fast probe deployment, fast access to compact build options, advanced formation and beharior tweaks (must be implemented in "real life", not only on the GUI.Balancing factions is a great work. Great work yet to be done, as the task seems untouched by the developers. This task is in tight relations with ship behavior, so I don't even know where to start. Stealth figters are worth a special mention: being the most advanced Kushan tech, they have less DPS than a scout, move slower, can't hit smaller targets at all, and can't do real damage to larger ones. With feaures this outstanding they should be permanently cloaked without decloak on attack.SUMMARY: to be straight and honest — this is an alpha. Totally raw; loads of aspects haven't received due attention. Multiplayer platform is good and priceless for seasoned players. Textures and models are great. Everything else has been neglected with or spoiled. And it is not the graphics what makes a really good game.

												Feels sloppy. Basic things are broken. B is the hot-key to the build menu, hitting that while it is up does not toggle it. R is the research menu, that does toggle. content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Simpy put, Excellent game(s). While the originals were epic in their own right, the remastered version changes interface, the graphics (including new features like "battle scars"), and several bug fixes. Plus, it doesn't change the story (at least  didn't notice any changes). another thing, is that it adds the ability to play both the first gen units AND the second gen units, in the same match. So those players that do the whole "oh, X Gen was better than X Gen". you can literally, fight them with those units to settle the score. Another thing is that thier are plenty of mods that change the way the game looks. that way, if you don't like the interface or the way an icon/emblem/ect looks, you can change it.

The game should never have been released in it's current state.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												As I have never played the original Homeworld series before, my comments made here are based on my feelings playing this game as a new player, and not on whether this is a good remake of the original series.In this game, basically what the player needs to do is pretty much like all the other RTS games, such as harvesting the resource, creating a fleet, researching new technology, defending the mothership, and destroying all enemy spaceships, etc.The differences between this game and other RTS games include:1) There is only one type of resource in this game. It's simple but quite boring.2) The battlefield is in the outer space; there is no topographic features of any kind in this game. That is, no roads, no lakes, no mountains, no nothing to speed up or slow down the moving speed of your units. Futhermore, you can't hide behind anything to dodge fire; you can't plan ambush; and you can't make a detour or anything. You just go directly toward the enemy then fight, and so is the enemy. 3) When you assign multiple units in a fleet, you can specify its formation. However, there is no tutorial or hints to tell you what are the advantages and disadvantages of each formation. In fact, after several hours of play, I still have no idea at all whether the selection of formation will affect the attacking or defending ability of the fleet or not.4) Although the player can command a specfic unit to attack a selected enemy, normally you won't have time to do so, as you cannot pause the game and there are simply too many enemy to target and you got so many spaceships to control. As a matter of fact, the program always hung up whenever I continuously move my units around the map. I'm not sure whether it's the problem of my computer (which I bought around a year ago to perform some computationally intensive numerical simulation) or there actually is a bug in this program. As a result, all I did in this game was to produce spaceships, group them as a fleet, assign them to attack, then they will move straightforward to the enemy to kill or get killed.5) The strength of your enemy in each mission is scaled to match the strength of your army at the end of previous mission. You are triumphant to have won a tremendous victory in a mission? You probably won't laugh for long because in the next mission a much stronger enemy is waiting to greet you. 6) The research is boring too. There is no such thing as tech tree in this game. Basically you just click on the research tab whenever the game tells you that there is a new tech available for you to research. And in maybe 30 seconds, the system informs you that the research is completed, and then, you are done. Oh, I almost forget to mention that they didn't even bother to design the icons for the technologies. It's just a text box; you click on the box whenever the system reminds you to do new research.Of course there are some nice features that enable the game to have received an overwhelmingly good review from the players. However, if I were to know those game settings/features as listed above, I would not waste my time or money on this remastered game.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Homeworld. It used to be considered one of best RTS's ever made set in space combat. After it was remastered it still is one of best RTS's ever created. I have never played original games, bought the game during recent steam sale. Money well spent. The game is just amazing. Homeworld 1 Remastered feels like one is playing Battlestar Galactica (2003-2009). On the other hand Homeworld 2 Remastered is more of war story while keeping up mysticism of 1st game.First thing I can tell you now the game is not easy, You need to learn its controls and how it works otherwise you will keep loosing. When you learn ropes of the game its extremely pleasant to play and most importantly enemy will still outnumber you, i.e. in 2nd game the enemy will have 10 battlecruisers while you have a cap allowing you to build 2 bc's. Quite unfair considering their firepower but frigates are perfect cannon fodder for that :PStory of two games is just amazing, both cause you feel rush and despair. Graphics in comparison to original game imporved really well fitting modern standards (including 4k if u can handle it). The soundtrack is purely amazing and is used in appropriate moments to affect us as players when necessary. Adagio for Strings choral by Samuel Barber is actually one of most beautiful songs ever created in our history. Yes, its used in best moments in the Homeworld 1 Remastered! Other soundtrack is also amazing but this very specific song is purest masterpiece of all, Gameplay. It's great. Cant say anything more. Combat is balanced, fights are challanging and its easy to loose if you're not using the thing in ur head at all. This is defiently not casual game where you hop in and immediately become a god in it (like designers of modern games do nowadays with games is just wrong!) Nothing beats sight of full scale fleet vs fleet combat. Bloody yet stunning.Homeworld Remastered Collection is great offer. You get 4 games (2 original + 2 remastered games) and if you are considering to buy it, do not hesitate. You will not regret spending your money on the game (sale or normally). Right now I feel like a thief for buying on summer sale. This game is worth way more than I've paid for it. I feel like I want to keep returning to the game to play it over and over. It is that good, great replayability value and satisfaction from it.To sum things up:+ Nicely improved graphics that fits modern standards+ Masterpiece soundtrack (and im quite hard to impress with music)+ Great Gameplay and replayability value+ Great story that actually makes you feel desperate, in rush+ Want more!+ Not casual...- ... which for some console peasants will be a bad thing.- some bugs - not well explained graphic settings in the video settings

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												FULL OF BUGS and Original Homeworld 1 Gameplay mechanics removed. WAIT FOR THEM TO FIX IT BEFORE YOU BUY IT !!!Both of these things turn what should be a beautiful remaster into a frustrating game.List of bugs in order of appearance:Level 1 - Game camera Went BLACK permanently after a cutscene. I had to restart the level. (This was like 4 minutes into the game, seriously Gearbox have you never heard of BETA TESTING !!!)- 2nd Resource collector I built dissappeared on level 1 after I sent it to harvest some resources. THERE ARE NO ENEMIES ON THAT LEVEL !!!- When the game asks you to stop a Turnanic Carrier from escaping, I destroyed it promptly and it said MISSION FAILED and the Hyperspace button appeared to complete the mission but I could only use the restart the mission button....- Encounter with Bentusi to trade. Bentusi ship and Mothership have a Star Trek esque standoff right in front of each other. This blocks your Mothership from undocking Capital class vessels from its 'side door', so had the mobile resource unit I just built stuck for about 10 minutes.- Support ships fail to dock with resource collectors resulting in a very bizzare dance of the 2 ships which left both ships blown up on the Radiation field level.- Black Camera AGAIN !!!! when you're on the edge of the Homeworld system to destroy a hyperspace inhibitor. Yet another Mission restart.I haven't even completed the game yet but I believe that this prompt review/WARNING was warranted.This severe lack of bug testing tells me that the game was hurried into release, whereas all other assets point to what should be an amazing remake. The Retextures and new graphics look spectacular and really do look amazing.This game needs some serious patching and even more bug testing.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I didn't play the originals like many reviewers have and have just completed the H1:R campaign, havent even touched the second one yet. I will post a review of HW2:R seperately.I will start off by saying I only leave reviews in cases of extreme, has to be so good or so bad to illicit a review. This game is definitely not the latter. I have played many RTS games through my life and very few were able to tell such a tale as well  as this one has. The journey was enthralling and gripping and has so many interesting events along the way. The combat is great and while the scenery leaves room for improvemnet it is hardly missed when your fleet engages the enemy and capital ships trade blows while fighters and corvettes dance through a three dimensional space. I enjoyed every mission many of which had different obstacles and goals to keep you interested and sometimes force you to use very different approaches, spamming a ton of two units wont get you far like many RTS out there. A must buy for anyone who enjoys RTS or space games, seriously get it.11/10 would make the journey again.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												I bought this when it was in the Autumn sale, hoping for a better, more up-to-date experience than the original. Both the remastered and original versions are included. The graphics are indeed very good but then it goes downhill... The audio (music) is very similar but some of the voices have been altered - I prefer the originals. On my original PC this pushed the limits performance-wise so I was pleased when I could now push everything up to 11 - and it all worked well (only occasional crashes). But what has utterly ruined it is the interface. It's clunky, some of the key combinations dont work when they are supposed to, the key bindings have changed from the original game - and some of them cant be re-assigned. Coupled with the lack of *Military (the default) ship formation for setting up squadrons, this makes it sooo hard to play and keep track of everything. I gave up after a couple of hours and got my money back (thanks to the Steam refund policy).I'f you've never played Homeworld you may like it and you would accept it as it is, not knowing any better. Unfortunately if you remember the original as fondly as I do then you are likely to be dissapointed.*You can get the Military formation by docking then re-launching all your ships immediately - but its a faff.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												There is a single reason i cannot reccomend this game. Dynamic difficulty. What is that? You have ships of total power 5, the next encounter has enemy ships of 7 power. You have total power 7? The encounter will be of power 9. You have 10 power? You go against enemy power 13. And so on. You always deal with a supreme force. A fleet equal to yours and somewhat better to counter the human brain superiority against CPU AI.The main supportive idea behind that is that you cannot focus on build a massive fleet and win by numbers. You have to use 'real strategy' and 'real tactics' to win. At least that is what they majority of fans are saying.Well i disagree. And the reason is simple. Firstly, i beat the game and without any save-load-try again stuff. Not a big deal, most players can do, if not they need some retries and that is all. Really, since when load and retry is a deep strategy and tactic?!?! On top of that, why build a lot of ships? The game does not count your stored resources for adjusting difficulty. You go with few ships, face few ships, build a few more and keep going. If that is strategy and tactic i am Napoleon.Not to mention the salvage corvette thing. Two corvette class ships can disable and salvage a frigate (and larger classes) but 2 combet class corvettes cannot take down a frigate. The salvage class ships would make sence if they salvage disabled or heavy damaged ships. This looks like a cheat to me and not a tactic.To make a long story short, do not build many ships, have 2-4-6 and so on salvage corvs, build few ships after the encounter has spawned and you are good for the entire game. Do not use your resources to build ships in advance before you hyperspace. 'To be prepared' obviously is not this game's motto. 'Play dead' is more like it.Nice experience from a view, i do not rememeber any other RTS punishing the hard prepared folks.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Really fun Blanced Game. The game as it stands currently looks great, easy to learn and just all around fun to play with your friends or to changllege yourself. But some of the con's are once one side or the other really gets a supeiror fleet up it ends up being a snowball effect unless you are good with hitting them where they don't expect it or if you have a friend to back you up. Also the game really acts like a rock, paper, sissors game with the fact that each ship class is good against other ship classes. But don't let that get you down about the game, it is still a load of fun to play and the more people we get the more people we will have to mod the living H out of it to make the game even better. I hope this review was helpful and if not please let me know why not so I can improve my reviews.Please note I like to write reviews that are short and straight to the point.

												Seeing how this game's price has completely crashed during the Autumn sale, I figured I would add in my own two cents.My dad introduced me to the original Homeworld when I was about 7 years old. That was about 13 years ago, and even after playing every single spaceship-related game I could get my hands on, I never found anything which went into quite as much depth with story, lore and gameplay as Homeworld. Now believe me I was just as hyped as the next person when Homeworld: Remastered was announced - in fact my dad would tell you I nearly brought the ceiling down with my enthusiasm, especially when I discovered that it was Gearbox, well-known for producing the Borderlands series (which I am also a HUGE fan of) was in charge of spearheading the project and bringing it to us. When it came out I didn't really see much of the shtick it got for myself, but after taking more time to play it since I have unearthed its little issues that the original game lacks. The good thing about this though is that you get the original games bundled with the remastered versions, so if the Remastered versions' issues become a bit much for you, you can easily revert to them to take a break. Now I'll give a breakdown of my own personal pros and cons, make of them what you will!PROS - - The game is, of course, remastered - graphically speaking, the game is stunning - the lighting is perfection, the backgrounds of matches are perfect, and the various ships look beautiful with their new models - the frigates even have moving turrets, which I think was lacking in the original game. There is not a single flaw in the graphical side of the remastering, at least in my opinion.- The campaigns for both games have remained pretty much untouched - but a new GUI allows for easier interaction with the game world and better control over what comes into your mothership and what leaves it. - The ship upgrade system located under the research section allows players to upgrade the stats of their various ships, including damage, defense, health and occasionally speed. They can also be used to teach some ships new abilities. In the campaign mode you are limited to when you get these upgrades however as many of them tie into the story in various ways.- The addition of mod support, although often shaky at times, does allow for the addition of custom races, ship logos, maps and I think even gameplay modes. Some of these mods can even be used in online play, which I think is fantastic. - While the original Homeworld soundtrack has been left untouched and rightly so, the Homeworld 2 soundtrack recieved a remastering which has drastically improved the sound of its music, which was in the original game something of a partial failure (Some of the songs sounded shoddy or rushed for example but these issues have been fixed in the remastered soundtrack).- The lore is extensive and beautiful for this game, but many people are often unaware of this without having access to the original Homeworld manual, which was a hand-me-down from my dad which I still read regularly. The details contained within the manual are available on the Homeworld wikia for those who are curious about learning the extensive background of this universe, as much of it isn't actually mentioned in-game or at least not in a way that some people would really understand or remember. CONS - - The original game didn't have any bugs or glitches that I can remember. This one has a great deal of them, however - simple things like unresponsive ships, the occasional crash and other silly things you could perhaps expect from a game, but still annoying due to how flawless the original felt. - Mods often deselect themselves and don't load after being used in-game for only one match. Sometimes mods don't work at all or crash the game, which is appearntly a very common occurrence.- The patches do help but often don't fix the really important issues, such as common issues with multiplayer and mods.- Some gameplay aspects that people really enjoyed were for some reason removed, such as the ability to Salvage (why they even bothered leaving the poor little Salvage Corvette in the game is beyond me, considering that in the main storyline of Homeworld 1 they are practically useless after the 3rd chapter now and just sit there collecting dust until destroyed by enemies) and also the need to refuel ships. While I actually think of this as a good thing, there have been complaints about it and I can imagine that for some people it must have taken some of the survivability element away from them. - Although I have no solid proof at this time, I've heard that there are serious issues with multiplayer on occasion. Multiplayer also allows you to play as any of the races from the two games, which in some cases could be a little unfair as the races from Homeworld 2 have packs of Interceptors rather than one Interceptor per construction (just an example, I know there are others too), as well as having better ships overall. Overall I'd say this game is worth its sale price, but maybe is only worth its true retail price to the hardcore fans who will appreciate it and can ignore its flaws indefinitely. Also another tip: If you are one of the owners of the original CD of the game which came with the soundtrack on CD, you don't need to buy the Homeworld 1 Remastered Soundtrack. It's literally the same music. If your CD is still around or in good condition, use that instead and save your money :P However the Homeworld 2 Remastered Soundtrack is different from the original as stated above and is very much worth the money in my opinion.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Homeworld is a very niche game. If you like space battles and want to see the absolute best there is on offer from any game to be frank, you'd want this game. The actual game itself here is a bit of a rough diamond. The gameplay involves a spherical map where you can move your ships in basically any direction up or down as well as in the horizontal plane, which in theory would open up tactics and such. In practice, its mostly a minor annoyance, for all it is technically impressive. It is tactically useless, for the most part. You could the vast scope of the map, particularly its height to hide, but hiding is never practical to be honest - unless you're gimping yourself against the AI and carefully setting it up,  you're not making a battlestar galactica style comeback if you get smashed early on. The gameplay boils down to who has the best fleet and the best target acquisition.  You select everything, and send it into the fray all at the same time and then click the enemy to death. The aesthetics are really down to your taste but personally I hate the design of the HW2 ships pretty much across the board while the Kushan in HW1 are in the same boat as looking awful (fighters look like flying ice cream tubs)  the Taidann look far more convincing and the only ships I really enjoy looking at. The NPC races in the campaign look pretty atmospheric and fitting as well. The HW1 campaign is in the vein of traditional RTS games, where there are some missions with some absurd challenge that you need to try multiple times, which is a double edged sword but I think generally it works. It makes the game more interesting and about learning rather than turtling and then sending the biggest possible fleet at something. If you want the best experience, I'd never reload a save, (but you will spend hours waiting for resources to collect or fleets to build) and the reason for this is that with the gimmicky missions there's generally a key lesson that you'll learn or figure out on the first go, so the second attempt is really easy. In one mission, you'll find your small craft will almost always get wiped out due to overwhelming firepower. The solution is to just dock them in your carrier/mothership. Units carry over between missions. In the original game, this meant that if you spent hours waiting to collect all resources before moving on, you'd have a significant advantage in the next mission. In remastered, you get all resources all over the map at the start of the next mission. There's a clear reason why Gearbox has made this change but it makes the last few levels♥♥♥♥♥♥easy.The last 2-3 missions stop being unique like this and essentially become move and attack fests where you move your death fleet across the map and slowly destroy everything. The enemy fleets don't scale well to your own superfleet that is carried between missions and just about the most challenging large fleet action is in one later mission  where you effectively have to leave a small force of  capital ships behind to defend your mothership from flankers while you win the mission.HW2's campaign is better designed such that a few of these problems are less significant or non-existent. The difficulty is more consistent throughout unlike in the first game where the difficulty is far worse at the beginning of the campaign. The story elements in both games aren't anything overwhelmingly special but are pretty decent and get the job done. In terms of the remastered elements, Gearbox didn't totally screw it up, but they did do a pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥poor job. If, like me, you have a fairly new AMD card with the latest drivers, you can't play either of the classic games as they will instantly CTD on launch. This issue has been around for several months and hasn't been fixed, and likely won't ever be fixed.  One graphical issue I've seen involves ships becoming completely see-through. This has been around since release and hasn't been fixed definitively, though there is a solution - its as overwhelming basic as changing the properties on the HW shortcut, so its pretty pathetic that its still around. In terms of campaign bugs, some missions or objectives fail to complete and particularly the infamous asteroid mission has artificial difficulty stemming from the stupidity of the pathfinding AI literally flying into rocks, and the long pause between being able to target split up asteroids. One of the main reasons you may want to get it is because of the brilliant mods made for classic that are being ported to remastered (though extremely slowly - none of the major ones have yet made the transition) that literally serve to make Homeworld a platform for simulating any space warfare universe imaginable. There's Freespace 2, Halo, BSG, Star Wars, Star Trek, even Wing Commander amongst other things. I'd say the game is still worth getting on sale, even despite all these faults. There is a net gain in enjoyment from playing this game, though be warned if you have an AMD card.  I'd give the game about a 7/10 on a scale where 5 is *the* average game, and not an "average game".

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												After falling in love with the original game, I jumped at this when it became availible.  The redesigned interface and beautiful storyline and game engine is such a joy.  I played a few missions from the single player campaign and heard there were a lot of bugs (I bought it day one) that I put it away and played other games until I was told by some friends when it had been fixed.Well, I reloaded this game a week ago and wow, what a difference.  Totally a train wreck of a game now.  The game 'dynamically' creates an enemy that will just curb stomp you no matter how well you build up.  The more you build up, the worse the enemy force will attack you.  Players have few choices now on how to approach the enemy.  This current game (single player campaign) is horrible.  Only one tactic can be used, you have to 'steal' as many of the higher end ships in order to win the objective.  Rubbish game now and stupid design since you can not adjust the difficulty even if you just want to 'learn' this, now lame, game.What a shame, the story is what made this game great.  If you prevent new players from experience it, you might as well close the store.Avoid this game like the palague...

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												I also helped make this and would recommend this game. I remember seeing this game on the shelf back when I was younger and at the time thought there was math or something was involved because of the full three axis it used(I was like 12 and didn't understand).  Never thought I would grow up and actually end up recreating art for  the remastered version. I grew to love the game very quickly, as I learned the basics of how to grow a fleet and what units fight best against another units. The battles are memorizing to watch. Its actually like watching an epic space battle from a movie, but you have control. I suggest to invest a little time, so that much more enjoyable time in the long run will be made. Was an honor and privilege to work on this RTS that inspired many games later on.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												When I was a tiny child, all I could do was just play the original Homeworld, and I played it every day for hours on end. I finished the campaign maybe only twice, though. On account that I wasn't very good at strategy at the time. When I found out that they made a second game, I also quickly got that one, and played it just as much, although I was never able to finish it at the time. In time, I moved onto other games, and I have long since lost the disks for both of these games.Every once in a while, I would check up on the status of the IP for the Homeworld series and would always be disappointed when I saw that it was tossed between companies, never to have a third game in the series. However, once I found out that it ended up with Gearbox and that they were going to be doing a remaster, I was ecstatic. At the time, many people were upset with the fact that Gearbox, who don't have a very good reputation with games, ended up with the franchise. I found no reason to doubt how good it would be, though. They would have actually TRIED to ruin a legitimate remaster in order to make it bad.Once the game came out, I quickly pre-ordered, and discovered that it lived up to expectations. Some parts were lacking, including tactics and some balance issues with multiplayer (to be expected. it's still a beta!) but besides that, the rich story was all the same. It still holds the special place in my heart as my favorite game series ever, and I'm excited to see where Gearbox goes with this next (I'm so excited for Sands of Kharak.)tl;dr: This game is very good. Please buy it. It's truly a classic and its story is incredibly rich and I recommend it to everyone!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Itt's good for what it is. Fairly bug "free" and very well optimized. BUT the remastered first game, Homworld, is pretty un true to it's roots. It's the liittle thing that totally change the wayy it plays and thus the overall experience. Formations are UTTERLY useless, fighters degrade into a cluster ♥♥♥♥ sworm of bees instead of attacking in formation. There are no longer any "stances" which determine how ships fight while IN a fight. They only inform what they do while not fighting. Which is totally useless. I'd say buy it if it's on sale. You can find plenty of information on how many things have changed in the porting of the first Homeworld into the Homeworld 2 engine, which was regarded by most fans as inferior. While I appreciate the revival of the series and did have a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of fun with the game these little things still irk me. Let alone the 2 original games that come with the title STILL do not work for me. Won't even launch.EDIT: It's clear what I was saying about HW 1 being totally different from original in terms of how ships operate. As devs spent nearly a year patching in the best fix possible. I thank the devs for their dedication to trying to get it right. Muchh appreciated and I will now purchase any and all games from them that I'm interested in. Game works MUCH better now too. Strike craft will actually form up sphherical formations around enemies now. Instead of doing straffing runs. And around friendly ships. The original games also launch now.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Itt's good for what it is. Fairly bug "free" and very well optimized. BUT the remastered first game, Homworld, is pretty un true to it's roots. It's the liittle thing that totally change the wayy it plays and thus the overall experience. Formations are UTTERLY useless, fighters degrade into a cluster ♥♥♥♥ sworm of bees instead of attacking in formation. There are no longer any "stances" which determine how ships fight while IN a fight. They only inform what they do while not fighting. Which is totally useless. I'd say buy it if it's on sale. You can find plenty of information on how many things have changed in the porting of the first Homeworld into the Homeworld 2 engine, which was regarded by most fans as inferior. While I appreciate the revival of the series and did have a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of fun with the game these little things still irk me. Let alone the 2 original games that come with the title STILL do not work for me. Won't even launch.EDIT: It's clear what I was saying about HW 1 being totally different from original in terms of how ships operate. As devs spent nearly a year patching in the best fix possible. I thank the devs for their dedication to trying to get it right. Muchh appreciated and I will now purchase any and all games from them that I'm interested in. Game works MUCH better now too. Strike craft will actually form up sphherical formations around enemies now. Instead of doing straffing runs. And around friendly ships. The original games also launch now.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												I never played the originals (back then) but i heard so much about them, tried to play the 1999 version and i simply couldnt, when i heard they were making a remake i followed the news until release when i patiently waited for a good discount before jumping in, my experiences are as follows:Homeworld 1 RemasteredThe gamePlay the tutorial, dont jump in recklessly. 3D movement is iffy, formations are useless-ish. The game looks beautiful and the intro missions really encourage you to continue on your quest. The balance of this game is off, leaning towards a mass of ion cannon frigates, destroyers and heavy cruisers. Hard counters are not hard enough, specially when facing a mass of fighters in one of the missions or several ion cannon frigates in another mission. It boils down to "can i outgun you before you destroy me?" with ion cannon frigates. The automatic balance worked very strangely during my run, giving me two very easy final missions. The AI can be wonky ni your favor or against you, some units may stay put, some will follow a single probe to infinity and beyond or sometime you may be relentlessly attacked, also movement in this game and the next takes time and theres no time compression. All in all if you played old time RTS like command and conquer (the first one) you should be fine with the interface and controls.Story and soundThe story has a good start a sluggish middle chapter and a fantastic resolution even thou the final battle itself is not that epic, i was enthralled at the start almost quit playing at mission 10 when a game breaking bug ocurred but pushed on to Mission 11 where stuff happens and it was one wild ride to the end. The voice acting is monotonous as it was on the first original game, i feel some of the "feels" were lost when no emotions are shown by the different voice actors with the exception of the mothership which is a "machine". Finally the soundtrack that really grabbed me in the entire game was the Homeworld version of Adagio for Strings that really enhances the scenes it is played on.Conclusion for Homeworld 1 RemasteredBear with the mechanics, enjoy the story, bask in the glow of ion cannons! Also someone needs to slow down those support frigates....Homeworld 2 RemasteredThe gameIf you played the first then the second uses the exact same mechanics but balances out some of the problems of the first game, small crafts comes in squadrons and fighters and bombers remain viable to the end game (mostly fighters). Ion cannon frigates are now for the most past useless-ish unless you can hide them properly behind destroyers and battleships. Formations are still broken, you need to macro manage your ship classes to prevent your corvettes or frigates form making contact with the enemy before your bigger ships which would result in the complete anhilation of your smaller craft. 3D movement is still wonky and the AI can be..how can i put this?...dense, for example in one of the missions you are tasked with destroying a ship, in the map theres another ship reinforcing or producing more units but these units stayed put until i destroyed the objetive and won the mission, so i felt no pressue. I did enjoy the tactical aspect more as i had to carefully position my ships to pull and counter the attacks during several missions. Small cradt counters work better now and capital ships can take move hits unlike Homeworld 1 were a few ion cannon frigates would melt a heavy cruiser or destroyer in seconds. In the end the balanced reamained in the capital ships and fighters craft to defend them.Story and soundThe story is much better told and presented, the soundtrack introduced songs with different rhythms like the one during the "boss" fights. The voice acting remains monotonous but the cast is more diverse this time around, still some of the "feels" are lost due to the voices.Conclusion for Homeworld 2 RemasteredBear with the interface (again), enjoy the story, enjoy the music, enjoy using tactics to engage some enemies.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I have only played a few skirmish matches so take this with a grain of salt, especially with the numerous bugs that are apparently still in the game. Gearbox have a bit of a♥♥♥♥♥♥track record in my book so I was sceptical.Well the game looks and feels great and is an absolute nostalgic blast. Once you hear the Ion beams and the delightfully nonchalant battle chatter (a welcome distraction from the try-too-hard cliché military gruff stuff we are used to nowadays) you feel right at home. Controls still hold up, though I would've wished a middle mouse button camera panning. It's a nice throwback to when RTS wasn't about unit spam or superhuman micro capabilities.The visuals are neat. Seing HW1 in this fidelity is a treat, HW2 also looks nicer but the leap isn't that big comparatively. Ship damage is still just pre-rendered 2d sprites but even those got increased resolutions. FOV is also cool but really gimmicky. Overall performance is decent, could be better though seeing as this isn't exactly cream of the crop visually despite all enhancements. This is still a 15 year old engine at its heart.Negatives are that the AI wasn't improved and is still kind of dumb. They'll get stomped even if they keep up with your economy. Also the UI scaling doesn't affect the ever obnoxiously large sidebar.Overall a recommended buy, for the ability to play this on current systems alone.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
What I liked:  3D space RTS ( no other game does this well or at all)  Captures the theme of space to a nice degree ( think 2001 space odyssey if it was a game)  The balance of the game ( advanced rock paper scissors style)  The soundtrack has some great relaxing tribal instrumental music  Your fleet carries from beginning to end(no other game does this, why haven't they it's so cool)What You Need to Know:  Played this when I was a kid( but this review is not biased because of nostalgia)  Game is very slow paced and story isn't strong at all ( big maps don't help this either)  No branching tech tree, just simple upgrades to new tech  Flanking is real in this game, 3D flanking bro  This game is so easy to understand, and isn't like a 4X stratergy game  All units have counters, it's not asymmetricMy Score:A+Paid: $14 HW 1 completed in:  11 hoursHW 2 completed in:  8 hoursGames similar:   Supreme Commander   Star Wars Empire at War Shallow Space Improvements and Changes in the sequel  Game speed is way faster as units move faster  Squadrons are now used for anything smaller than a frigate ( makes game easier to manage, and more epic)  You use boarding ships to capture and some units gain abilities that gets rid of some ships  You get a villian now, but the mission designs to me are just kill everything on map, ( less unknown suprises )  Research and upgrading is improved with small upgrades every ship, instead of just tech upgrades to unlock new shipsI know the first game is very slow, if you don't like it. Just skip it and go to the second one. You don't want to miss the best space RTS do you

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												When I was around 14 or so, I remember heading to a friend's house where he and his brothers had a number of gaming PCs set up, all networked in and online. We would play Everquest, Counterstrike, and a number of other games into the wee hours of the morning. There was one game there that stood out to me; that game was Homeworld.Homeworld is an amazing game. A journey through both an amazing, emotional story and wonderful gameplay. The score is driving, the visuals are breathtaking, and the whole experience is awesome.If you played this game at original release, then I'm sure you remember the first time loading it up, hearing Samuel Barber's Angus Dei and seeing the Mothership. I know you can recall the emotion felt when the fleet returns to Kharak only to find it burning under an enemy assault. Countless memories flood forth from the mere mention of this cult jewel. Why it wasn't more popular at the time, I will never know.A friend and I would play this title over Gameranger. We did for a good many years, actually. We would always joke about them doing an updated version of the game (if not a HW 3)...well, those jokes have become a reality. An awesome reality.If you're a fan of the original, or curious about this game...I say go for it. It is worth every penny.If you are new to the game, I envy you....you're about to take an amazing journey on your way home.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Sublime, gorgeous, majestic, epic - all of these terms aptly describe Homeworld.In this real-time starfleet combat strategy series you play as a spacefaring people in seach of their ancestral home planet, pursued by a merciless empire.Throughout your journey across the galaxy you encounter friends, foes, ancient alien artifacts, and the lost histories of your people.This is the most comprehensive remaster I've seen by far, and no series is more deserving of it than Homeworld.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Rose tinted glasses is a risk with the 'golden oldies'. Homeworld was a fantastic game back in the day, and to get that out of the way immediately: It still is. So, I recommend the game. But it is worth knowing ahead of buying that it is not a perfect game. It looks like a 2015 game. The game doesn't play like it, though. The campaign has a great story, but it has an unforgiving side and as your fleet stays with you throughout the game, it can be punishing or require loading. In that regard it's quite 'oldschool'. That is not necessarily bad - or good - but is something you should be aware of. As for the multiplayer, there's some region limiting that can be worked around, but you don't get more epic space battles than multiplayer Homeworld. Nothing even compares. I note that a lot mention bugs. I haven't run into any, for what it's worth.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Homeworld remastered is exactly that, the original homeworld with slightly improved wrapping. While this is generally a good thing and if you liked the originals (like I did, a lot) then buying this makes sense. You will get the same game with updated visuals and sounds.However there are some negatives, most of them are just missed opportunities, but they still count as negatives:- Models are extremely low poly for a 2015 game- objects (mostly ships) could be much more detailed - Textures look low res as well- effects look 5-6 year old at least (like engine glow as such)- voices are a bit more bland then the original, they seem more like script read than a person saying them.In general it is an improvement on the original for sure, but the original was revolutionary for its time, this is passable at best for 2015

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Rose tinted glasses is a risk with the 'golden oldies'. Homeworld was a fantastic game back in the day, and to get that out of the way immediately: It still is. So, I recommend the game. But it is worth knowing ahead of buying that it is not a perfect game. It looks like a 2015 game. The game doesn't play like it, though. The campaign has a great story, but it has an unforgiving side and as your fleet stays with you throughout the game, it can be punishing or require loading. In that regard it's quite 'oldschool'. That is not necessarily bad - or good - but is something you should be aware of. As for the multiplayer, there's some region limiting that can be worked around, but you don't get more epic space battles than multiplayer Homeworld. Nothing even compares. I note that a lot mention bugs. I haven't run into any, for what it's worth.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Homewolrd was on of those games where you either loved it or hated it. From my personal experience with the game, I really love it, had to really drag myself away from it at 2am this morning to et some rest for work later today.The game being re-mastered has managed to keep is atmosphere and environment, the story really pulls you in. Multitasking and designating your squads to defend carriers as well sending other squads to deal with the enemy carriers while you continuously harvest more resources and research. There is so much going on.The ui is slightly different, personally I liked the old UI but this new UI all it takes is getting used to.The PVP part of the game is where I think it will really make or break the game for the future. Personally I like the hyperdrive element brings in so many strategies like a decoy attack to the front of an enemy base while your team mate hyperdrives behind the enemy base and nukes.This game is awesome, if your in to RTS even as a solo player I would defo recommended it, the skirmishes against the CPU can be quite fun as well if you don’t like PVP.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Homeworld remastered is exactly that, the original homeworld with slightly improved wrapping. While this is generally a good thing and if you liked the originals (like I did, a lot) then buying this makes sense. You will get the same game with updated visuals and sounds.However there are some negatives, most of them are just missed opportunities, but they still count as negatives:- Models are extremely low poly for a 2015 game- objects (mostly ships) could be much more detailed - Textures look low res as well- effects look 5-6 year old at least (like engine glow as such)- voices are a bit more bland then the original, they seem more like script read than a person saying them.In general it is an improvement on the original for sure, but the original was revolutionary for its time, this is passable at best for 2015
