content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Well... As it stands right now they made HW2 okay but completely ruined HW1 in every way shape and form. Formations in the REAL Homeworld don't work properly, they don't stay in proper formation. Capital ships can't maneuver worth beans, Destroyers are no longer the ultimate utility ship of the fleet anymore. They were designed in HW1 to keep pace with and LEAD the frigate lines. Now they're slow, lumbering beasts that just♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. Frigates are now made of wet paper bags and fighters are slow and unmaneuverable, meaning point defenses and even heavier weapons could destroy them. Corvettes are now pointless to build. Basically you just build fighters bombers and super-capitals only and they are all that is worth building.The GUI is NOTHING like the original Homeworld which let you have a very clean experience which didn't block anything out. If you didn't need to see the GUI at that moment, it wasn't there. One of the things that made Homeworld loveable was that it assumed you were intelligent.Singleplayer's adaptive difficulty from HW1 is now gone from what I can tell and it is pathetically easy for an experienced HW Vet. I had little trouble in the first few missions, which was dissappointing to say the least.Fuel consumption no longer exists for fighters which means that when I eventually reach the Garden of Kadesh I can expect to be utterly massacred by the Kadeshi. This makes the Support Frigate a useless item. Honestly, why have them anymore at all?! The whole ballance is gone by removing fuel consumption, barring the other things they've utterly mucked up.I'm happy that they thought it worth the effort to do a remastered edition but they sacrificed the original Homeworld ENTIRELY in order to satisfy the Homeworld 2 players. The thing is... There is a LOT more Homeworld 1 fans that stayed true and bought this than there were Homeworld 2 fans (at least if my group of friends is any indication).Gearbox... Hear us! Fix your rather glaring mistakes! Homeworld 1 should have been the priority... Especially since THAT is the one that won Game of the Year in 1999. And lets be honest... It had some pretty TALL competition back then for that title. It didn't just win Strategy Game of the Year, it won overall Game of the Year.... Frankly I want a refund because this wasn't true to the Homeworld legacy at all... As far as I am concerned the basic models for the ships are the same and then cut-scenes are the same. The rest is garbage.

content:
Posted: January 10
												As a big fan of the original Homeworld titles (HW, HW:C, HW2) I felt compelled to write my own review of the "Remastered" collection. If you're looking to spend money through Steam to buy these titles, I encourage you not to. The "Remastered" HW is a huge disappointment, plagued with a sense of "Beta." I have the original HW and HW2 disc software and Win 10 on my PC's, and they have no issues running in compatibility. The Remastered collections crashes, freezes, and is plagued with bugs (as of 1/10/2017). The Remastered collection, I will admit has smoother renderings and neat eye candy. Unfortunately, being built on a broken HW2 platform, which IMO was not an improvement over the original HW, is even worse since the RM version is a severely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized HW2 platform, hence broken. All in all, if you really want to play HW & HW2, I recommend picking up the original software disc's (amazon, ebay, ect.,) and don't waste your money as I have. I wish I could get a refund.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
 Gearbox speculated on the Originals fanbase to drive the Hypetrain...when they decided to actually charge  32€  for this.Someone in the forum once wrote: "Ten years ago, this would have been called "HD-mod" and it would have been free. Today its called "Remastered" and costs 32 bucks" Oh BTW, look at this gem:


YouTube™ Video: Problems with formations and tactics in Homeworld 1 Remastered 

			Views: 8,615		



According to veterans of the original games, this reduces combat efficience of your vessels drastically. Which is fun in general, but this game also got "dynamic difficulty" or as i call it "Hurl so much s*hit at ya winning is almost impossible"-tactic.While its almost nonexistent in HW 1 RE (i was invincible after boarding my first battleship), HW 2 RE just loves to kick you in the groin.First you´ll learn that boarding changes from HW1 to HW2, instead of small salvage-corvettes you now have much bigger Marine-Frigates, which are weak as s*ht.As soon as they´re spotted, EVERYONE goes for them. Doesnt matter at all how many ships you use as decoys. So when you actually manage to cap a big enemy, youll be proud. "Wow, i capped a big ship, now my fleet´s awesome! Man that feels good!"  you´ll say. And then you reach the next mission. And then the game goes  "Whats that?! A big ship and YOU control it ?!?! PREPARE THE ARMADA!!! GET DAT MUDDAFOCKA!!!!!" Then you´ll end up getting destroyed. You load the last mission, scrap your fleet down to the basics and thus artificially cheat the difficulty down. Conclusion:  32€, no. Just no. Not for 32 Euros!

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												I am hugely disappointed with this game. Gearbox DOES NOT ADVERTISE that they took HW1 and stuck it in the castly inferior HW2 engine. This results in a number of glitches and inferior results during play, including formations and tactics that are meaningless, resourcers that quit gathering while there's still resources on the map, and AI fleet numbers that are ferequently ridiculous. I quit on the 8th mission, since the HW2 enemy force calculator saw fit to add an insanely unbeatable number of AI ships to that mission, making it impossible to finish.If you're a huge fan of HW1 like I am, don't buy this. It's a massive disappointment.

												In terms of gameplay and a space rts, this game beats basically all in my opinion.  The combat system is very balanced, and the game is very enjoyable.  It does not get repetitive in terms of the campaign, and even if you beat the campagn and are bored with multiplayer and friends the steam mods are insane and fun.  However, the support page and forums are a joke in terms of helping to find/fix a bux.  My launcher stopped working for who knows why, and after looking for 3 months without an answer I sadly rate this game negatively. 												Amazing remastering. They could have updated only what was needed, which they did (you get the classics too).But now you get update models, textures, backgrounds and UI. I can't wait for Homeworld Shipbreakers and eventually, Homeworld 3.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This one is a classic and well worth getting. A lot of reviews say that the game aged well and that Homeworld never really needed the remastering treatment it got. And yet. And yet the work Gearbox did in concert with the original development team, the original voice actors, the concept artists, and the original game's modders shows a loving respect for a series that should never have gone fallow since Homeworld 2 came out. The remastered version is gorgeous and the gameplay hasn't aged a bit. I still tear up hearing the choir singing Barber's Agnus Dei.This is a great game and a work of art well worth having in your collection. I look forward to seeing what Gearbox's enthusiasm will bring to the series in the future.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Unfortunately this one simply does not live up to the hype. I am an old Homeworld player, and have invested hundreds of hours in all three original releases. So far this version has, in my opinion, taken multiple steps backwards from the originals. Even the classic releases don't play as well as the original versions. I find myself screaming myself hoarse at the frustration of stupid ships that do whatever they feel like, regardless of commands sent, enemy ships that arrive and destroy your fleets many times faster than you can possibly retaliate or build, and limitations that were not it the originals that make no sense at all. Why research a ship type if you can't build it? Why tell a harvester to  gather resources if it is going to park itself the moment it's finished it's first rock? Why leave hundreds of exhausted rocks littering the place? And why weigh the skew so heavily in favor the of the enemy in the single player games that frustration instead of enjoyment is the only possible result? And they lost Cataclysm. Bah!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												A beautiful remastering of an already favourite classic of mine. Homeworld Remastered lives up to its promises and delivers exactly what a remastered version is supposed to. Graphics are touched up to the point of pure art, the sound is clean and clear, the gameplay is smooth and user friendly, and any upgrades necessary from the original are present for all.And of course if you wish to stick to the original, that is also present as well. This remastering has something for everyone, both the old school fans and newcomers, including the branches between those who prefer one version over the other.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												This game is fantastic! Taking me back to playing it day one back in 1999. However i will say this, the learning curve for HW1 remasterd is far less then what was required back in 1999 (the jump from mission to mission early on was much harder and faster hitting in the enemy) i feel it does lack alot of its depth with the removal of fuel. (had to actualy load up my old HW1 on my old system to see the differences) The game is still fantastic and looks great, UI is different which took some getting use to but easily jump back into and play. I will forever miss the how difficult this game was in 1999 for single player and how many hours it took to advance through the first 5 missions.*EDIT*so after playing hours in this game i have come to realise that Homeworld Remastered is a huge let down. The stratigy requirements of the first Homeworld where amazing and required so much more work and thought to use formations and flight tactics. Plus the physics engine/bullets are completely different now, it is using an RNG so shooting and moving is irrelavent. Very sad to see HW1 ported into HW2. HW2 was a step back, still enjoyable but nothing compared to its big brother.Yes the lack of fuel is a bumer but no game changer. I had orginally recommended this game, now i have changed my mind because its not Homeworld it use to be. Still a fun game but its no homeworld. Very disappointing to see Homeworld redone this way. I have not played homeworld 2 remastered yet,not really feeling it right now because of the changes with Homeworld and all the bugs in the game it a huge let down. So if you play this enjoy all the bugs to include huge game changer bugs (skipping cut scences and screwing up the spawn so you never have to fight any enemy or just a couple ships but not the endless onslaught it should have been) also the combat is totaly different and far easyer, however that being said always keep your salvage corvettes on hand! free ships! (oh whats with the AI not shooting salvage corvettes or harvesters? i remember the AI destroying them when they showed up now.) all in all, Homeworld is a fantastic game, Homeworld Remastered is a mediocre remake of one of the worlds best games.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												It's Homeworld 1 and 2 with allot of new paint (especially the former) so I will just state the good bits and bad (mostly linked to HW1). Good bits:Salvage vettes work just as well as they always have... possibly a bit too well(I nicked every single corvette the Turanic Raiders threw at me... if the Standard Corvettes could salvage, neither they nor the missile vettes can use their special abilities, I'd be set for life but as is I gotta keep a 12-16 strong wing of "nice ship you have there...shame if someone were to.... enlighten you of it".Even on medium settings the game looks magnificent, both cutscenes and regular play, and the gameplay of Homeworld 1 is fully intact.Not much else to say, it does everything right almost.Nitpicks: 1. My biggest problem with Remastered is that in Homeworld 1 you can no longer choose to play as either Kushan or Taiidani nor can you alter the paint scheme. The former can be excused, with ample applications of salvette, but the latter is a bit aggravating as a veteran of the original.2. The cutscenes, both between missions and in-game, in Homeworld 1 seem a bit faster than the original versions... it's nitpicky but it kind of feels off to me slightly.3. The streamlining of Homeworld 1 in terms of screens (no more separate build or research screeen from the normal one) though welcomed in certain regards also makes it a bit painful to macromanage everything. In the original the gameplay would pause when you were in the other two screens ergo it is a bit missed somewhat.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												EDIT: (Having played a bit through the HW1 Campaign on Remastered)By all means, Homeworld set the bar on what it really meant to have a space RTS. The original was ground-breaking, and the particularly leisurely pace of the missions as well the ability to keep your fleet between missions reinforced the desire to use tactics, and made each loss of a destroyer a tear-jerker. Needless to say, the game was memorable. Homeworld 2 was another great game, but I wasn't as much a fan of the strict Rock-Paper-Scissors, and completely transient nature of my fleets. I felt like I was rebuilding from scratch every mission, as if my ships were made out of paper. Some of the grander tactics were substituted with spamming the proper counter, making ground, rinse and repeat. I didn't feel as connected to it, but regardless, Some people prefer its interface and overall playablity. In the Remastered Edition, Homeworld 1 is basically Homeworld 2, with a story and ships from the first game. Now, on the surface (and for the first few missions), this works fine. The ability to use Evasive or Aggressive tactics (which increases evasion or accuracy respectively) are gone in favor of general 'behavior'. A few missions later, and I realized that even my strike craft were not staying in formation. If one has played the first game, one may understand the importance of this, as I'm sure many of the other reviews have noted. Now, I can take this loss in Homeworld 2; the game was different. But there is a problem in Homeworld 1. Homeworld 1 fleets and missions were not built with the intention of using the Homeworld 2 engine (duh). First of all, a lack of fuel (for both your units as well as the AI's) is okay... until you reach the Garden of Kadesh, and the main element of the Kadeshi forces is their constant need to refuel. Without fuel, this mission has completely changed in nature. A couple missions later, one is fighting the ghost ship... and the mission has completely changed (due in part to the changes to the ships), one is forced to use Corvettes and Fighters against Anti-fighter and Anti-corvette  frigates (an entire fleet mind you!) without squadron tactics or formations... see the dilemmia? Now, this may seem like I'm ragging on this game pretty hard, but I don't want to come off too hard. This is NOT a bad game, this is still a great game. But, this is not the same game that came out in 1999. It looks like it, (and damn is it beautiful), but it's not the same at the core... not ultimately. As for Homeworld 2, and multiplayer, I'm sure this is going to be a fantastic game. I haven't had a chance to play the multiplayer or 2 yet, but considering this is the Homeworld 2 engine, I'm not going to assume much as changed since. Consensus: If you're interested in the game, then play it. It's a great game. But if you're looking to play the Homeworld 1 campaign, stick with the original. It's just... better. If they update this game, and patch it, then I'm sure it will be even better. Gearbox, you've done well, but wearing the skin of my girlfriend and trying to give me a kiss just isn't as appetizing as the real thing.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												The exiles have returned. It's been 16 years since we first left Kharak but now we make the journey once again.Research reports new technologies to aid us:+ Highly detailed visuals of our fleet and the enemy fleet will increase targetting.+ Those that completed the journey before will be able to relive the best once again.+ Recon tells us that enemy numbers will be based on the size of our fleet. (Missions now scale based on fleet size so that amassing a huge fleet early on won't make the game too easy later)+ AI Tactician Software that allows one to match the fleets of ole with the fleets of new. (You can play HW1 / HW2 sides in multiplayer).The Mothership is taking light damage...- Some bugs in the programming may need to be worked out.- Strikecraft and corvettes are overally suboptimal currently. Requesting research upgrades.- Rookie pilots are unable to stand in formation correctly.- Ship Captains are unable to use stances accurately.- Asteroids.....Assessment: While the Mothership was unable to complete all of its subsystems, given time it will be repaired.Incoming video feed from an alternate timeline: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLZUnRwcrejYgIMohjgAdX1nhRTdR0K8u

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												RE-TINKERED? Re-HASHED? In the music industry when a work is re-mastered, it generally means that technologies unnavailable at the time of the original recording are used to clear away the audio artifacts of an analog mastering process and hopefully present a truer version of the artist's work. In other words, it's "cleaned up" and will sound better than it ever has - especially on the new higher fidelity systems available.What Gearbox implies in their title is that they've done this with a game - whith higher resolution. Same work, by the same artists - just more enjoyable on modern systems.That's not what happened.What happened is more like a REMIX. The new artist can't help themselves and attempts to add to the original: to improve it or make it their own. And that's fine under two conditions:1. The new artist is honest about what's going on2. The new artist is talented enough to succeedNeither is the case here.What we have is a game that's somewhat better to look at, with a host of new bugs, newly broken mechanics, and at least one story breaking bug that stops progression several levels in and has you sitting there in deep space with nothing to do wishing it hand't cost you $34 dollars and many frustrating hours to get there. I wish I had avoided this one. But the allure of Relic's artistry was too great. If you are reading this and considering the purchase out of a nostalgic memory of what once was I'll say this: playing Gearbox's version of Homeworld is like going back to your home town after four years away at colledge. Many things are familiar, many are jarringly not, and the Home(world) you remember exists only in the past.It's too bad these hacks don't know their trade.RE-JECT this.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												The game still stands as one of the greatest space opera ever made and now with a new coat of paint. A truly wonderful story about a race threatened with extinction looking for their Homeworld accompanied with unique atmosphere and daunting orchestral score. There are drawbacks to this remaster however including missing gameplay mechanics from the original such as physics simulated ballistics and relies on Homeworld 2's system of random number generator for combat simulation and while it has the original fleet formation coupled with the new ones the older ones tend to be bugged, alongside some pathing issues and missing fuel system, but those issues are due to remaking the original Homeworld in the Homeworld 2 some are certain to be fixed with patches while others can be addressed with re balancing. f you're new to Homeworld none of this should bother you as the RNG mechanics of Homeworld 2 are just as playable, as for the purists who prefer the original gameplay over the newer one, the collection has the original HW1 untouched and fully compatible with modern operating systems with the trade off of having antiquated graphics. Recommend it to anyone interested in space RTS games or a fantastic space saga in general. Truly one of the greatest games ever made and I can't be more excited for having this gem brought back to life instead of having it locked away in obscurity and intellectual property limbo.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												For $35 one gets a game full of quirks and bugs. Unit behaviors and the balance of combat elements is changed substantially. It is confusing at first and then frustrating, as some of the most effective tactics (e.g. small units working in tight formation) can be ordered but don't actually happen. They would have done better to leave the game engine alone. The original Homeworld stands out as an all-time classic among 3D strategy/combat sims. I can only hope a few dollars got back to the original developers.

content:

												I highly recommend this game! I played the crap out of it back in 1999.. and I'm gonna play the crap out of it today.An excellent RTS Space game. Collect RU's, research new technologies, build a massive fleet, and attack and kill enemy forces. The graphics aren't just HD re-textures, there's new bloom features, and field of depth, and particle effects. It's an amazing upgrade from one of 1999's greatest RTS's.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												This brings back memories. I absolutely love the remastered visuals and cleaned up audio. Some people are reporting bugs and glitches but I haven't really seen anything glaring out at me. One particular thing I could mention is when designating groups with multiple ship types the quantity numbering on the group selection to the lower left is difficult to read.I can see myself spending a huge amount of time with this collection. They did a lot of this out of passion and love for the original game. The developers were gamers themselves who want this to be a great rendition of a timeless classic, and you can tell they wanted this to have the soul of the original classics while being re-made for the modern system. The audio work alone merits a huge amount of praise but to see that they sensitively updated the visuals is also such a great bonus. You won't go wrong getting this. The most jaded and indifferent people will still be impressed by the quality of the arts presented by this collection. Great job Gearbox, this does a lot of goodwill towards bringing your reputation back into the good graces of gamers. I hope it sells like gangbusters.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												To start, if you have never played the original than you will probably like this game a lot more, this is the review of an old homeworld fanatic, and my complaints are mostly about infidelities to the originals. (Well the formation thing obviously needs fixing).I am very dissapointed with the remastered versions of these games. HW and HW2 handle formations and tactics very differently.  These mechanics could be reconciled, but aren't. Individual strikecraft built by kushan/taiidan do not stay in formation and tactics aren't as usefull (originally evasive ships were harder to hit and would spread on attacking, agressive ships would stay tight and fire as fast as possible). These features should be preserved, and the ui should simply adapt depending on what race you play, (taiidan/kushan get formations, hiigaran/vagyr strikegroups). If this was fixed I would be deeply satisfied. The graphics are wonderfully remastered and it has potentiall to be a brilliant rebirth of a personally treasured classic.I mostly just use this to play HW classic on my mac.PLEASE FIX THIS GAME

												this is my favorite RTS. and i can't recommend it.  It's been a while since I've been insulted by buying a game.  bought this game new for about $30, no big deal, except it said preorder and get the original game free, except you always get it free, misleading/lie.  then it instantly goes on sale for 66% off.  add insult to injury.  but it gets worse, the cpu multiplayer is STILL unplayable after multiple updates.  and the final insult: the new deserts of kharak looks amazing! but if you buy the game new you get homeworld for free. but if youre a fan of the series and already bought the game for $30 you get $10 off the new game.  I took elementary math once and $30 is more than $10.  so i should have never given my money for this game. because i could have saved money by not buying the game until the new one. and thats B.S.  way to punish the fans of the series.  like i said I'm insulted, and disgusted by this.  so I refuse to recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												"The mothership has cleared the scaffold. We are away."It's a time warp back into the past. One of my favorite RTS games makes a return with remastered enhancements that bring new life back to the Homeworld universe. Gearbox and Blackbird Interactive did a good job with the enhancement and I hope this success will continue to drive forward as they expand on the series. I haven't played any multiplayer yet as I'm focusing on the campaign and skirmishes. This is one of those games you want to bath in the full treatment and not rush any one particular feature. There's plenty to do and much value to absorb.Graphics+ Plenty of in-game options to enhance graphical quality.+ Models and textures are pretty sharp and detailed.+ Nice explosion effects.+ Lots of tiny details like ship damage decals, resource extraction effects, lens flares, sun rays, etc.+ Space environments are beautiful.- Shadows are a bit "noisy" around the edges. Not as high calibre like other games.- UI is a bit dated looking and could have been enhanced better.Audio+ Music suits the gameplay and the environments well. Quality is very crisp.+ Sound quality is pretty good and feels crisp as well.+ Explosions and cannons have a good punch on my sub.- Game lacks 3D positional audio, which would have enhanced the immersion as your camera rotates around ships and battles.Gameplay+ AI gives a good challenge. It keeps the pressure on as you foucs on survival.+ Good balance of combat & time investment. Skirmishes are not to long and not to short. You're always on the move.+ Classic RTS that sticks to the tried and true formula. Research, build, and tactics all within a space theme.- Little awkward there's no easy way to pan around quickly, or that the camera has a limit on the zoom-in/out range. In most modern RTS games, you move around quickly. Given the 3D positions in Homeworld, it can be awkward to get your camera in the right position without first orienting it on an object nearby, then moving over to where you want to go.Campaign / Single Player+ Just like the original, only better with the new HD visuals and audio.+ Challenging missions and interesting story with a sense of adventure.Quality+ Haven't run into any breaking issues so far.- ESC key doesn't bring up the menu like you would expect in most PC games.- PrintScreen is not the default screenshot key. ScrollLock is (like what?). Can't seem to bind it to PrintScreen either.Overall+ Would recommend this game. Homeworld is fun RTS, now with better visuals and audio. Combined with modding support, the possibilities are open for the community to introduce new scenery, new game modes, total conversions, etc. Add on 2 games + the originals, plenty of campaign missions, adventerous story, good music, AI skirmishes, and multiplayer. There's a lot of value here and if you haven't tried the Homeworld series before, consider checking this little gem out.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Now, I will make a note right now, I am a diehard Homeworld Fanboy. I played Homeworld 2 just a few months ago at the most recent. I also played Cataclysm fairly recently. However, Homeworld 1 eluded me after my childhood. You see, when I was 8, we got Homeworld 1 and I enjoyed it... that is, up until the asteroid mission where I could never get past it and never truely knew how the game evolved or even the ending.In fact, this, was the first time I have ever seen the ending of the original Homeworld.I loved it.It wasn't without its faults, but I couldn't really expect them to take a 15 year old game, ship it into a new engine, and fully remaster it without some issues being present. If you expected it to be perfect, you are a fool.They kept a lot of the basic gameplay elements that I remember while improving the bad things I forgot about. Here is a quick list of pros, cons, and bugs that I experienced.Bugs:Mission 3 broke for me on the first playthrough. I killed the frigates, but never got the objective to salvage the trays. Luckily it was a short mission and it was the only time I had to restart a mission. Might be worth checking out though.Pathing/AI seems to be extremely poor. The biggest issue I saw with this has an obvious answer too. Its the Homeworld 2 engine and that engine was not designed for single ships put into a chosen formation by the player. This causes OBVIOUS issues when you try to do it. Ships will immediatly drop out of their formations when combat starts and make no attempts to have any sembelence of sanity until the battle ends. Of course, this causes Homeworld 1 fighters to be damn near useless and you are way better off just running all frigates and capital class ships because they are useful past being cannon fodder... In most situations. On the Asteroid mission I got stuck on as a kid, I lost like 8 frigates to really terrible pathing which seemed to be caused by buggy asteroids. Pros:Homeworld is to this day considered the greatest designed space based RTS game ever created by a wide number of people. For good reason. This remastering brings the game into the current age of technology and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥did I just hear every other space based RTS♥♥♥♥♥♥themselves?Amazing Story that I finally got to enjoy fully for the first time in my life. I must say that the story telling in this game is a huge upturn to the current generation of games.Great gameplay mechanics for sure. The greatest being the persistent fleet between missions which can either make for an extremely fun situation or doomed to fail scenarios.Updated Graphics! This speaks for itself really.Updated Voice work!!!! This I was NOT expecting when I heard they would be remastering the game. They got the original voice actors and had them redo the lines with the higher quality recording technology and boy does it SHOW! If you watch the cutscenes from the original homeworld and compare it to these, you can not only see the difference in art, but you can HEAR the difference in voice acting too!Cons:Homeworld 2 Engine... I would have been WAY happier if they had used a different engine or maybe spent the time to make a new one. Perhaps one they could have used for Homeworld 3? ;) The Homeworld 2 engine is sloppy and actually causes the majority of the problems with the game as it sits. It was never that great, but I understand that it had to be done, it just makes me sad :(No difficulty setting - The best thing about Homeworld Cataclysm, was that at 8 years old you could set the difficulty to easy and blow through it and have fun with it. I had always wished a difficulty setting would have been in homeworld 1 so I could have beaten it as a kid and gotten way more enjoyment out of it. Now some other poor kid who might want to enjoy this game wont be able to either because it is too hard? Difficulty settings exsist so the player can choose their pace for the game and get the maximum enjoyment out of it. The point it was removed in Homeworld 2 and completely ignored still in this remastering simply reminds me of when I stopped bothering with homeworld 1 because I couldn't get past one mission. Then, by the time I was old enough to want to try again, it didn't work anymore on my computer. :'(

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I remember playing the old school Homeworld...I was 15...damn I feel old.Anyway, I couldn't fully appreciate it back then. For me it was just 'pew pew...splosions!" Granted, compared to most RTS games coming out today, it's punishingly difficult. It doesn't hold your hand, but growing up on Atari and Nintendo, without the joy of save files and regenerating health, I was used to it. It was and still is one of my favorite RTS games (perhaps my favorite). If grew up with this game, it'll feel like home. If you're like me, your jaw will probably drop when you see the facelift it's gotten. It's absolutely beautiful. The space battles are as intense as ever. And remastered, the laser heavy dog fights and resulting explosions is some of the most satisfying gaming you'll experience all year. Go watch the PAX demonstration if you need further proof. Let me just mention one more thing. Mission 3 of Homeworld 1...the music combined with the imagery...it's goosebump inducing. Don't go look it up and ruin it for yourself. It's something you need to experience free of spoilers. It'll be on your top ten list of best gaming moments, trust me. This is a no brainer, in my opinion. If you loved Homeworld 1 and 2 in their original forms then this will be like revisiting an old friend from high school that got really really hot and now wants to sleep with you. If you didn't play this game back in the day, but you love the RTS genre, it's a no brainer. This is one of the finest entries in the genre and it now looks as good as anything else on the market.For all of you with older machines, this is really well optimized. So if you've got a laptop or perhaps a couple year old gaming rig, don't worry too much, it should be fine.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Now, I will make a note right now, I am a diehard Homeworld Fanboy. I played Homeworld 2 just a few months ago at the most recent. I also played Cataclysm fairly recently. However, Homeworld 1 eluded me after my childhood. You see, when I was 8, we got Homeworld 1 and I enjoyed it... that is, up until the asteroid mission where I could never get past it and never truely knew how the game evolved or even the ending.In fact, this, was the first time I have ever seen the ending of the original Homeworld.I loved it.It wasn't without its faults, but I couldn't really expect them to take a 15 year old game, ship it into a new engine, and fully remaster it without some issues being present. If you expected it to be perfect, you are a fool.They kept a lot of the basic gameplay elements that I remember while improving the bad things I forgot about. Here is a quick list of pros, cons, and bugs that I experienced.Bugs:Mission 3 broke for me on the first playthrough. I killed the frigates, but never got the objective to salvage the trays. Luckily it was a short mission and it was the only time I had to restart a mission. Might be worth checking out though.Pathing/AI seems to be extremely poor. The biggest issue I saw with this has an obvious answer too. Its the Homeworld 2 engine and that engine was not designed for single ships put into a chosen formation by the player. This causes OBVIOUS issues when you try to do it. Ships will immediatly drop out of their formations when combat starts and make no attempts to have any sembelence of sanity until the battle ends. Of course, this causes Homeworld 1 fighters to be damn near useless and you are way better off just running all frigates and capital class ships because they are useful past being cannon fodder... In most situations. On the Asteroid mission I got stuck on as a kid, I lost like 8 frigates to really terrible pathing which seemed to be caused by buggy asteroids. Pros:Homeworld is to this day considered the greatest designed space based RTS game ever created by a wide number of people. For good reason. This remastering brings the game into the current age of technology and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥did I just hear every other space based RTS♥♥♥♥♥♥themselves?Amazing Story that I finally got to enjoy fully for the first time in my life. I must say that the story telling in this game is a huge upturn to the current generation of games.Great gameplay mechanics for sure. The greatest being the persistent fleet between missions which can either make for an extremely fun situation or doomed to fail scenarios.Updated Graphics! This speaks for itself really.Updated Voice work!!!! This I was NOT expecting when I heard they would be remastering the game. They got the original voice actors and had them redo the lines with the higher quality recording technology and boy does it SHOW! If you watch the cutscenes from the original homeworld and compare it to these, you can not only see the difference in art, but you can HEAR the difference in voice acting too!Cons:Homeworld 2 Engine... I would have been WAY happier if they had used a different engine or maybe spent the time to make a new one. Perhaps one they could have used for Homeworld 3? ;) The Homeworld 2 engine is sloppy and actually causes the majority of the problems with the game as it sits. It was never that great, but I understand that it had to be done, it just makes me sad :(No difficulty setting - The best thing about Homeworld Cataclysm, was that at 8 years old you could set the difficulty to easy and blow through it and have fun with it. I had always wished a difficulty setting would have been in homeworld 1 so I could have beaten it as a kid and gotten way more enjoyment out of it. Now some other poor kid who might want to enjoy this game wont be able to either because it is too hard? Difficulty settings exsist so the player can choose their pace for the game and get the maximum enjoyment out of it. The point it was removed in Homeworld 2 and completely ignored still in this remastering simply reminds me of when I stopped bothering with homeworld 1 because I couldn't get past one mission. Then, by the time I was old enough to want to try again, it didn't work anymore on my computer. :'(

												A MASTERWORK of the RTS genre gets not only the best remaster available,  but is now preserved for newer generations of gamers to experience. content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Even though I've not played these games for long so far, I can tell this is exactly what I wanted and was buying. Gearbox didn't dissapoint this time with this flawless remastering of a classic. These game's mechanics still hold up to this day and with updated graphics it leaves all other current RTS of this kind. It's very hard to describe the feeling you get when you combine nostalgia with a great game and then polish it to this level of sheen. This should be an instant purchase for past lovers of these games. Newcomers should also try these if they are fans of RTS games. The controls are smooth and intuitive. They work well for 3d navigation in 3d space. The HUD is relatively easy to navigate as well. My only complaint about the HUD is the upgrading and building menus. Those I have always considered somewhat clunky. Large scale space combat in these games is fun and cinematic. These games also feature a great soundtrack fit for space exploration. The added workshop compatibility for mods just makes this package too sweet to ignore. Can't wait for someone to redo Cataclysm and put it on there. All in all, a solid buy even at full price. It should be noted that I even dislike RTS games for the better part, but would place this game solidly on a top 10 games of all time list.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I remember playing the old school Homeworld...I was 15...damn I feel old.Anyway, I couldn't fully appreciate it back then. For me it was just 'pew pew...splosions!" Granted, compared to most RTS games coming out today, it's punishingly difficult. It doesn't hold your hand, but growing up on Atari and Nintendo, without the joy of save files and regenerating health, I was used to it. It was and still is one of my favorite RTS games (perhaps my favorite). If grew up with this game, it'll feel like home. If you're like me, your jaw will probably drop when you see the facelift it's gotten. It's absolutely beautiful. The space battles are as intense as ever. And remastered, the laser heavy dog fights and resulting explosions is some of the most satisfying gaming you'll experience all year. Go watch the PAX demonstration if you need further proof. Let me just mention one more thing. Mission 3 of Homeworld 1...the music combined with the imagery...it's goosebump inducing. Don't go look it up and ruin it for yourself. It's something you need to experience free of spoilers. It'll be on your top ten list of best gaming moments, trust me. This is a no brainer, in my opinion. If you loved Homeworld 1 and 2 in their original forms then this will be like revisiting an old friend from high school that got really really hot and now wants to sleep with you. If you didn't play this game back in the day, but you love the RTS genre, it's a no brainer. This is one of the finest entries in the genre and it now looks as good as anything else on the market.For all of you with older machines, this is really well optimized. So if you've got a laptop or perhaps a couple year old gaming rig, don't worry too much, it should be fine.

And now, the remastered version, and the same is coming, hours and hours of campaing and skirmishes, it's probably the best space RTS ever. Can't recommend it enough. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I first played this back in '99 and I was sorely impressed, I used to take the 100+ page manual (I miss those days) to read all over the place. It was the first game to get an actual emotional response out of me (that wasn't frustration), and you really felt for the protagonists for the story putting yourself right into their shoes (or that of S'jets).This remaster of such a beloved classic is incredible, and should probably be a benchmark by which other remasters compare themselves too. The improved graphics are rich with detail, and the audio (songs and dialog) is oh so much crisper now. it's not 100% perfect, but bug patches will surely fix things - or modders will. The fleet formations for HW1 strike craft don't quite work how they're supposed to which is a bit disappointing, and the enemy scaling between missions seems a bit overly harsh at times. There are a couple others such as black screens but I have not seen them yet. They also got rid of fuel which made me a little sad, since it reduces the need for resupply ships.Pro-tip; Steal everything that isn't nailed down. If it is nailed down, bring more salvagers. Also, don't overbuild your fleet. If you smash the enemy it might be wise to retire some strike craft before the next mission - otherwise you might find yourself in quite the pickle.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												To be fair, the HW1 remaster is kind of awful, since there are a bunch of gameplay issues created by dropping HW1 assets into the HW2 engine. Corvettes don't behave as they did in the original, you have to micro some things that didn't have to be microed before, a particular critical limitation of strike craft is gone, etc. That said, the original game was included, so you can play that instead. It's far from unplayable, so I went through it anyway to see the graphics and reexperience the plot.The HW2 remaster is beautiful, though. I spent more of my time replaying HW2 than HW1, so personally I would have been satisfied paying full price for only the HW2 remaster and nothing else. Full mod support has been promised, and we have it from the head of the Complex mod that they've done a good job on that front. I liked 2's gameplay better; some people liked 1 better. Probably a lot of these issues will be addressed in the coming days - the problems with the HW1 remaster seem correctable, and the modding community should have a good time.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												A Great remaster of an RTS classic 9 out of 10 [Was an 8.5] So far I have run into only one bug and mostly it is just a random annoying Crash to desktop when a mission loads first time in HW1 and I am not even sure it is the game all of my games have been crashing randomly since the last steam client update.[Addendum: Found a hot fix for the CTD I have been having reducing texture size stops the crash however for some reason all my saves from yesterday are broken so I had to restart I am assuming this was caused by an update of some kind]I can't speak for bugs other people have had but most of them seem fairly minor and avoidable (ie. compleating an objective before it is assigned makes it impossible to beat the mission without reloading). Save often so that a crash/bug won't hurt as bad (besides the HW games get HARD so saving helps a lot even if you never run into a bug).As for improvements from the classic games HW1 basically now uses the HW2 UI, it feels like some things have been rebalenced so it no longer is as unforgiving as the original, and of course the graphics are insanely good seriously watching the ships fly around is half the fun. Also thank Fraking god they made it so you collect all of the maps rescorces at the end of a mission extra .5 to score for that. [Some people have been complaining about this fix but the whole you have to collect everything in HW1 was anoying it didn't make the game more difficult it made it tedious and unfriendly to new players.]Oh and did I mention you get the classic versions of HW1 and HW2 so if worse comes to worse and your rig can't play the remaster you can always boot up the original.A few problems I have with the game- salvagers now need massive micro managing.- Formations only hold for the first few seconds of combat - The alternate mothership design/ unit designs from the original were removed this annoys me because I like them better than the ones used in this game.- The credit song from the original is gone (I suspect there were rights issues which is why I am not to angry but still...)If you are into RTS games buy this.(Note: I will update this as I play if I run into anything major.)
